Authors: Haghighat N., McCandless D.W.
Title: Effect of ammonium chloride on energy metabolism of astrocytes and C6-glioma cells in vitro
Affiliations: Department of Cell Biology, Finch University of Health Sciences, Chicago Medical School; Department of Cell Biology, Finch University of Health Sciences, Chicago Medical School, 3333 Green Bay Road, North Chicago, IL 60064, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haghighat, N., Department of Cell Biology, Finch University of Health Sciences, Chicago Medical School; McCandless, D.W., Department of Cell Biology, Finch University of Health Sciences, Chicago Medical School, Department of Cell Biology, Finch University of Health Sciences, Chicago Medical School, 3333 Green Bay Road, North Chicago, IL 60064, United States
Abstract: Increased ammonia has been considered a key factor in the pathogenesis of hepatic encephalopathy. The high concentration of ammonia interferes with oxidative metabolism in the brain through an inhibitory effect on the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA). Inhibition of the TCA cycle may result in depletion of ATP. Due to the involvement of astrocytes in brain detoxification of ammonia, these cells are good candidates for studying ammonia's effect on energy stores in the brain. C6-glioma cells, which have altered glycolytic rates, may show greater sensitivity to the toxicity of ammonium chloride than astrocytes. To study the effect of ammonium chloride on energy storage of both astrocytes and C6-glioma, we observed the acute and chronic effects of NH4Cl (7.5 or 15 mM) on the metabolism of isolated astrocytes and C6- glioma cells. Primary astrocytes were isolated from the cerebral hemispheres of 1-2 day old Sprague Dawley rats, and C6-glioma cells were purchased from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC). Following treatment of the cells with ammonia, glucose, lactate, glutamate, ATP, and PCr were assayed. Our data showed that at 15 min following treatment with NH4Cl, there were no significant differences in the concentration of metabolites measured in astrocytes. However, following 15 min of treatment with NH4Cl, the concentration of some metabolites, for example, ATP and lactate, changed significantly in C6- glioma cells. We have shown that 24 h of treatment was sufficient time to see significant biochemical changes but not morphological changes in either cell type. Simultaneous biochemical and morphological changes were observed 48 h following treatment in C6-glioma cells and at 9-10 days following treatment in primary astrocytes. In primary astrocytes at 24 h following treatment, glucose utilization increased. This high utilization of glucose was in accordance with the increase in lactate and glutamate production and the decrease in ATP and PCr formation. In C6-glioma cells the utilization of glucose increased but this high utilization of glucose was consistent with a significant decrease in the concentration of lactate, glutamate and ATP.
Author Keywords: Ammonia; Astrocytes; C6-glioma cells; Energy metabolism; Glucose metabolism; Hepatic encephalopathy
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; ammonium chloride; creatine phosphate; glucose; glutamic acid; lactic acid; animal cell; animal tissue; article; astrocyte; cell metabolism; energy metabolism; fetus; glioma cell; glucose utilization; hepatic encephalopathy; neurotoxicity; nonhuman; rat; Adenosine Triphosphate; Ammonium Chloride; Animals; Astrocytes; Energy Metabolism; Glioma; Glucose; Rats; Tumor Cells, Cultured; Animalia

Authors: Gurrappa I.
Title: Surface engineering for hotcorrosion resistance
Affiliations: Def. Metall. Research Laboratory, Hyderabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Gurrappa, I., Def. Metall. Research Laboratory, Hyderabad, Pakistan
Abstract: HOT CORROSION is a major problem in many energy systems such as batteries and fuel cells, coal-conversion and -combustion systems, solar-energy and energy-storage systems, nuclear-energy systems, gas turbines, gas- and oil-recovery systems, etc. However, the type of hot-corrosion attack varies depending on the application. Surface engineering, which is concerned with all aspects of engineering related to the modification of surface properties of the components, is the ideal solution to combat hot corrosion effectively and prolong the life of the components to their designed life. Therefore, surface engineering must now be considered as an integral part of the energy components, providing both their environmental resistance and the development of appropriate strength capabilities for the base material. This paper is concerned with the problems faced by many energy systems, in particular gas turbines, and the improvements in the surface property of hot-corrosion resistance by a variety of surface-modification techniques. Different surface coatings and their processes related to gas turbines are surveyed and brief mention is made of other systems. To achieve optimum properties for a given energy-system environment, the combination of diffusion and overlay coatings to a suitable thickness can offer significant advantages. The paper also reviews some different techniques currently available for the evaluation of materials and coatings for hot-corrosion resistance. It also covers the advantages and disadvantages each technique, and the importance of electrochemical techniques. Further, the work carried out at the Defence Metallurgical Research Laboratory relating to hotcorrosion activity, the recent results obtained with CM 247 LC superalloy, and the surface coatings developed for hot-corrosion resistance are also reviewed. Finally, a best suitable coating pattern is suggested for the efficient and effective functioning of gas-turbine engines, which in turn enhances their operational life.
Index Keywords: Diffusion; Gas turbines; Protective coatings; Service life; Surface properties; Surface treatment; Hot corrosion resistance; Surface engineering; Corrosion resistance; corrosion resistance; gas turbine

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Advanced energy systems
Abstract: The scope of this book covers mature state-of-the-art advanced systems and those emerging energy technologies that have already proven their feasibility in large-scale demonstration projects and are therefore on the brink of full-scale commercialization. The forthcoming millennium will set new demands for more energy production at lower cost and reduced environmental impact. Ecological problems have become more severe primarily because of steadily increasing CO2 emissions from fossil fuel burning plants, including those used for power production, transport, and industry. The ultimate global warming effect can cause dangerous climatic changes on Earth. Steadily increasing emissions of other atmospheric pollutants such as sulfur and nitrogen oxides are also very damaging to the environment. Therefore reduction of all emissions from the energy sector is of the utmost importance. These concerns create new challenges in the area of energy technology. The existing power production technology cannot fulfill these requirements in the most sensitive areas of efficiency and pollutant emissions. At present, energy technology is marked by tremendous efforts aimed at achieving higher efficiencies in energy conversion with reduced environmental impact and at lower costs. Therefore advanced energy systems that have been developed in the last decades become mature contenders to the conventional energy technology based predominantly on coal-fired central steam power stations. Although conventional energy technologies have been consistently improving in terms of efficiency, economics, and reduction of environmental impact in the last decade, modern power stations have achieved the ultimate degree of intrinsically limited efficiency. Further improvements are possible only by revolutionary changes of the energy technology. The 21st century will drastically change energy production and will become the era of more efficient combined power plants. The development trends are directed at the changeover from basically steam power technology to combined-cycle power based on such plants as gas turbines, fuel cells, MHD generators, as well as the advanced energy systems based on the utilization of renewable energy sources. The book deals with all those advanced energy systems that have reached a sufficiently mature state of development to conform to the requirement for commercial application before the end of this century. These are predominantly combined-cycle gas turbine and steam turbine power plants, various improved gas turbine configurations, second- and third-generation gas turbines with intercooling, reheat, water/steam injection, air-conditioning, etc., coal-based low-emission power systems such as integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) and fluidized bed combustion (including second-generation pressurized bed combustion, i.e., PFBC), means of reduction of environmental impact of energy systems, low-emission combustors and furnaces, advanced cogeneration plants, advanced solar and wind systems, as well as advanced energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: energy; fluidized bed; gas turbine; pollution; power supply

Authors: Guma I.R., Alonso S.I.
Title: Germination and seedling growth in Elytrigia scabrifolia and E. scabriglumis
Affiliations: U. Integrada Fac. de Cie. Agrarias, Univ. Nac. Mar Plata-Estac. Exp. A., INTA, P. O. Box 276, 7620 Balcarce, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Guma, I.R., U. Integrada Fac. de Cie. Agrarias, Univ. Nac. Mar Plata-Estac. Exp. A., INTA, P. O. Box 276, 7620 Balcarce, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Alonso, S.I., U. Integrada Fac. de Cie. Agrarias, Univ. Nac. Mar Plata-Estac. Exp. A., INTA, P. O. Box 276, 7620 Balcarce, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Abstract: Elytrigia scabrifolia and E. scabriglumis are native perennial grasses of Argentina and are considered important forage resources. The objective of this study was to analyse the effect on germination and seedling growth of five incubation temperatures (15°C, 20°C, 10°C/15°C, 15°C/20°C and 20°C/30°C) in seeds of wild populations stored under two conditions (4°C and ambient conditions). Germination percentage at the 5th day (energy), final germination percentage, germination index, shoot length and root length were recorded. The optimum temperature for germination and initial seedling growth of E. scabrifolia seeds was 15°C/20°C. Root length was not affected by incubation temperature or storage condition. The thermic regimes 15°C and 15°C/20°C promoted shoot growth and the values were significantly higher in seeds conserved at 4°C. In E. scabriglumis, the final germination percentage was unaffected by the incubation temperature. Interaction between temperature and storage conditions was significant for energy and germination index, and the highest velocity was registered at 20°C and 20°C/30°C. Seedling growth was increased at temperatures higher than 15°C.
Index Keywords: Elytrigia scabrifolia; Elytrigia scabriglumis

Authors: Manz H., Egolf P.W., Suter P., Goetzberger A.
Title: TIM-PCM external wall system for solar space heating and daylighting
Affiliations: Swiss Fed. Labs. Mat. Test. and Res., CH-8600, Duebendorf, Switzerland; Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-8092, Zurich, Switzerland; Fraunhofer Inst. Solar Ener. Syst., D-79100, Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Manz, H., Swiss Fed. Labs. Mat. Test. and Res., CH-8600, Duebendorf, Switzerland; Egolf, P.W., Swiss Fed. Labs. Mat. Test. and Res., CH-8600, Duebendorf, Switzerland; Suter, P., Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, CH-8092, Zurich, Switzerland; Goetzberger, A., Fraunhofer Inst. Solar Ener. Syst., D-79100, Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: An external wall system for solar space heating and daylighting composed of transparent insulation material (TIM) and translucent phase change material (PCM) is presented. This system enables selective optical transmittance of solar radiation. Visible light is mainly transmitted and invisible radiation is mainly absorbed and converted to heat, causing in particular phase change. The storage medium is also the absorber. The concept of the system is presented in detail together with the investigations carried out, including a brief outline of modeling, optical experiments on PCM samples and long-term experiments on a prototype wall as well as numerical simulations. The results indicate a promising thermal-optical behavior of the system. For instance in a Swiss lowland climate (Zurich-airport) a mean energy flux of 13 W m-2 (system efficiency 0.27) was calculated through a south facing TIM-PCM wall into the building during the month with the lowest irradiation (December). The parameters of the prototype wall with a mean melting temperature of the PCM of 26.5°C were assumed. When considering the percentage of time in which the building does not lose energy through the south facing TIM-PCM wall, a maximum can be reached with a mean melting temperature of approximately 20 to 21°C. In this case energy losses through the facade occur only during 1% of the time. With regard to the practical application of the system in buildings, aspects of reliability and durability have to be further investigated.

Authors: Das K.K., Pradip, Natarajan K.A.
Title: The effect of constituent metal ions on the electrokinetics of chalcopyrite
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Tata Res. Devmt. and Design Centre, 54 Hadapsar Industrial Estate, Pune 411 013, India; Department of Metallurgy, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Das, K.K., Tata Res. Devmt. and Design Centre, 54 Hadapsar Industrial Estate, Pune 411 013, India; Pradip, Tata Res. Devmt. and Design Centre, 54 Hadapsar Industrial Estate, Pune 411 013, India; Natarajan, K.A., Department of Metallurgy, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Abstract: Chalcopyrite in contact with water is thermodynamically unstable in the presence of oxygen. Oxidation of chalcopyrite may take place due to various factors, e.g., geological environment, mining/comminution, and storage. In this work oxidation of chalcopyrite has been investigated through interfacial electrokinetics. The characteristics of samples obtained from different geological locations as well as the effects of ageing and laboratory oxidation have been delineated. Variation of the solid-liquid ratio was found to have a significant effect on the zeta-potential characteristics of chalcopyrite. The role of constituent metal ions, namely copper and iron, has been studied in the absence and presence of externally added metal ions. The results indicated that the ratio of Cu/Fe on the surface of oxidized chalcopyrite determines the Stern layer potential and under appropriate solution chemistry conditions influences charge reversals. The mineral surfaces, thus, could be either copper-rich or iron-rich as reflected by a shift in pH(iep)(s). The observed charge reversals have been explained on the basis of a model proposed by James and Healy.
Author Keywords: Chalcopyrite; Electrokinetics; Metal ions; Oxidation
Index Keywords: chalcopyrite; copper; iron; metal ion; mineral; oxygen; unclassified drug; water; article; electrophoretic mobility; energy; kinetics; oxidation; priority journal; spectroscopy; X ray diffraction

Authors: Kojima A.
Title: Flywheel stores energy
Affiliations: Nippon Oil Co.Ltd., 8-Chidori-cho, Naka-Ku, Yokahama 231, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kojima, A., Nippon Oil Co.Ltd., 8-Chidori-cho, Naka-Ku, Yokahama 231, Japan
Abstract: Nippon Oil Co.Ltd have designed an energy storage system that uses a carbon fibre-epoxy composite flywheel. The flywheel is made from unidirectional (hoop) wound carbon fibres using a filament winding process. There are three different types of carbon fibre used in the flywheel: the inner part of the rotor is constructed with a medium modulus carbon fibre; the outer sections use an ultra high modulus fibre; and an intermediate modulus fibre is used in the mid-section. Overall the energy storage device is extremely compact.
Index Keywords: composites, carbon-fibre-reinforced; energy conservation; winding, filament

Title: Integrated analysis of video and radiation data for nuclear material monitoring system

Abstract: The analysis algorithm, which simultaneously interprets the transfer route and types of nuclear materials and the types of transfer container, has been developed for the radioactive material transfers in the nuclear facility. This method can be accomplished by integration of video images based on pixel differences and radiation data imported by NDA radiation sensors in real time. This technology, based on pattern recognition by neural networks, is well suited for surveillance systems of large automated facilities, spent fuel storage facilities and new conceptual hot cell facilities such as DUPIC(Direct Use of spent PWR fuel in CANDU reactors) facility.

Authors: Mikkelsen A., Rønn B., Skibsted L.H.
Title: Formation of white spots in the shell of raw shrimps during frozen storage. Seasonal variation and effects of some production factors

University, Rolighedsvej 30, DK-1958 Frederiksberg C, Denmark
Abstract: During frozen storage of raw pink shrimps, Pandalus borealis, calcium carbonate tends to precipitate in the exoskeleton, giving the shrimps a spotted appearance. Seasonal variations in the formation of white spots and the influence of shrimp size, production time, chemical treatment, and storage temperature on white spot formation was determined. A significant effect (P = 0.003) of day of catch was observed and shrimps caught in the summer period showed a greater tendency of white spot formation than shrimps caught during the rest of the year. Treatment in a sulphite, a phosphate or a phthalate solution prior to freezing retards calcium carbonate crystallisation (P < 0.05) while treatment in a borax solution promotes crystallisation (P < 0-05). Prolonged time from catch to chemical treatment and increased storage time increase the risk of white spot formation. Storage temperature has a significant effect on white spot formation for which process the rate at different temperatures was described by the Arrhenius equation with a high energy of activation of 90 kJ mol-1. The size (age) of the shrimps did not influence white spot formation (P = 0-69). From these findings it is concluded that calcium carbonate precipitation resulting in white spots in shrimp shell can be retarded or possibly prevented by short production time, appropriate chemical treatment and very low storage temperature.
Author Keywords: Calcium carbonate crystallisation; Chemical treatment; Frozen storage; Pandalus borealis; Pink shrimp; Production time; Shrimp size; Storage temperature; White spots

Authors: Singh N.P.
Title: Is plutonium really a threat to man and his environment?
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry
Affiliations: Intercontinental Consultants (ICC) Inc., 4412 Fortuna Way, Salt Lake City, UT 84124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, N.P., Intercontinental Consultants (ICC) Inc., 4412 Fortuna Way, Salt Lake City, UT 84124, United States
Abstract: Plutonium is a vital source of energy. The importance of plutonium as a source of energy can easily be understood by a simple fact that the amount of energy produced from one gram of plutonium is equal to the energy produced from 100 g of uranium and/or one ton of oil. Plutonium poses little or no problem as a high level waste. This can be predicted from our earlier studies on Th in man which has indicated that the general population of the United States exposed to insoluble Th throughout the life times accumulates the amount of Th contained in 1-6 g of soil. Furthermore, the vitrification process can prevent the translocation of Pu into the environment from the waste storage site quite effectively. Plutonium is a great asset to the human race only if they are civilized and use this great element for their prosperity as a source of energy. However, if the people and/or their leaders become barbaric, inhumane, crazy and misguided, then Pu could be the greatest threat to the survival of human race. Therefore, man himself could become the greatest threat to the human race.
Index Keywords: oil; plutonium; plutonium 239; plutonium 240; uranium; conference paper; energy resource; environmental exposure; environmental radioactivity; nuclear energy; radioactive waste disposal; united states

Authors: Ditschuneit H., Ditschuneit H.H.
Title: What is visceral obesity?
Affiliations: Med. Universitätsklinik Ulm, Blaustein, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ditschuneit, H., Med. Universitätsklinik Ulm, Blaustein, Germany; Ditschuneit, H.H., Med. Universitätsklinik Ulm, Blaustein, Germany
Abstract: Fat tissue is a very important energy reservoir. Its Lipolysis protect the vital necessity of subtrate-supply for all cells, even food intake is interrupt for a long time. Produced by positive energy, balance the fat will be distributed to different compartments. The most part is subcutaneously deposited. The intraabdominal (visceral) portal compartment located in the omentum and mesentery processing a special metabolic sense due to its direct drainage via vena portae to the liver and its high lipolytic rate. The deposition of triglycerides into the portal compartment is regulated by food- supply and in addition by gender and age as well as hormonal and neural controllmechanisms via hypothalamus and pituitary. Smoking and alcohol seems to promote the deposition of fat into the intraabdominal compartment too. Males show a better fat deposition intraabdominally than females. In females this compartment is growing not before the postmenopausal period. By this the gynoid form takes on android traits. The enlargement of the portal fat tissue is decribed as android obesity. In contrast to the gynoid obesity with favoured fat deposition in the region of the hips and buttock the android obesity correlates significantly with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, and their risk factors: Hypertension. Dyslipoproteinaemia (high VLDL, low HDL-Cholesterol, increased small dense LDL), impaired glucose tolerance/Typ II diabetes, Hyperinsulinaemia. The increased lipolysis in the visceral fat tissue is decisive for the pathophysiologic base of this metabolic syndrome.
Index Keywords: adipose tissue; body fat; cardiovascular disease; cerebrovascular disease; dyslipoproteinemia; human; hyperinsulinemia; hypothalamus hypophysis system; impaired glucose tolerance; lipid storage; lipolysis; mesentery; non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus; obesity; omentum; portal vein; priority journal; review; risk factor; sex difference; viscera

Title: A parametric study of Wind Energy Conversion Systems with energy storage in reduced load conditions

Abstract: A parametric study of Wind Energy Conversion Systems (WECS) with energy storage in reduced load conditions is carried out to determine the effect of mean wind speed and various load, WECS and storage system parameters on energy storage size. A computer code is developed based on an already established WECS with energy storage model, suitably modified for reduced load conditions. It is confirmed that load duration considerably affects energy storage size. In addition, the results indicate a substantial effect of load, WECS rating and minimum energy storage level on energy storage size. This effect is also a function of load duration. The mean wind speed effect on storage size is negligible.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Electric energy storage; Energy conversion; Loads (forces); Wind effects; Wind energy conversion systems (WECS); Wind loads; Wind power; energy converter; wind power; wind speed

Mathematical simulation of the surface migration of the adsorbed metal atoms has been performed. Prospective media for the storage of optical information are suggested.

Title: Efficient pumping of discharge gas lasers by generators with inductive energy storages

Abstract: The present report describes gas lasers pumped by generators with inductive energy storage and semiconducting opening switch. It is shown that these generators significantly improves output parameters of different gas lasers. Longitudinal small-scale N2 laser and CO2 and non-chain HF transverse discharge lasers are developed using this pumping technique. Efficiencies of CO2 and HF lasers up to 17% and 5,5%, respectively, were demonstrated. Advantages of generators with inductive energy storage are discussed.

Abstract: We present a new type of effective photoregulation of the LC orientation on an aligning surface through light action upon the liquid crystal bulk. The illumination of an azo-containing LC bulk with polarized light is found to induce both stable (in time and temperature) high-resolution alignment onto the rigid surface and dynamic sliding of the director over the surface. Typical times of the director sliding over the aligning surface are of the order of 1 ms. Both effects are characterized by extremely small light intensities (as low as 10-1 J/cm2) and seem to be very promising for the development of optical devices for information processing and high density information storage. Light-induced surface memory effects are also observed in these systems as a consequence of induced anchoring of the molecular director. This technique has been applied to record both stationary and dynamic holograms with a spatial resolution of 7 μm. The surface memory effects have been applied to record both binary and gray scale images. As compared to other methods used in these materials the highest sensitivity and spatial resolution can be achieved: energy densities as low as 10-1 J/cm2 were sufficient to write gratings with a resolution better than 100 lines/mm.
Author Keywords: Aligning surface; Anchoring of the molecular director; Surface memory effect
Index Keywords: Crystal orientation; Doping (additives); Dyes; Holograms; Light polarization; Shape memory effect; Photoregulation; Liquid crystals

Authors: Choban E.A.
Title: The CPT-invariance examination in muonium and antimuonium process creation

Abstract: The processes of the muonium and antimuonium creation on electron and positron intersecting storage rings are considered. The total cross section and the differential cross section via the muon-muonium invariant mass are calculated. The estimates of the modern accelerator possibility are maked at LEP-2, FNAL (Tevatron-DIS) and HERA. The possibility of CPT invariance examination due to time life of muonium and antimuonium measurement is declared.

Authors: Zarnikau Jay
Title: Taking advantage of real-time pricing programs to reduce energy costs in manufacturing
Source title: Proceedings ACEEE Summer Study on Energy Efficiency in Industry
Affiliations: Planergy, Inc
Authors with affiliations: Zarnikau, Jay, Planergy, Inc
Abstract: Increasingly, utilities are offering optional real-time pricing programs to their industrial customers. In many of these programs, the price of electricity changes on an hourly basis to reflect the projected cost of providing electricity to the consumer during that hour. Real-time pricing of electricity will become more prevalent in the future as competitive spot markets or power exchanges for electricity are developed. Real-time pricing can provide industrial energy consumers with new opportunities to reduce energy costs. Under real-time pricing, it may prove cost-effective to reschedule operations from high-price periods to low-price periods, reschedule maintenance activities, or endure voluntary curtailments in electricity service during high price periods. Investments in standby generation, energy storage devices, and control systems may prove attractive. Successfully exploiting this option requires the development of an effective strategy for responding to changing electricity prices. A number of reports and guides have been prepared under the sponsorship of the electric utility industry to assist utilities and regulators in designing effective real-time pricing tariffs. Yet, industrial energy consumers wishing to exploit real-time pricing have been provided little guidance. This paper examines the potential benefits and costs of real-time pricing programs from the perspective of industrial energy consumers in hopes of filling some of this gap. This paper outlines how industrial energy consumers can develop effective energy cost reduction strategies to take advantage of real-time pricing programs. Typical pricing algorithms and program design features are first described. Common measures and operating strategies for energy cost reduction under real-time pricing are discussed. Practical advice is provided to assist energy managers in analyzing cost reduction opportunities from real-time pricing programs.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cost effectiveness; Electric rates; Electric utilities; Energy management; Real time systems; Strategic planning; Real time pricing tariffs; Energy conservation

Authors: Fridman B.E.
Title: Programmed discharge of a capacitive energy store. The synthesis of a given current pulse
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The acting of the devices, on which the capacitive energy store is discharged, mainly depends on the form of a current pulse. The programmed discharge mode permits to generate a current pulse of the given form, at which conditions of work of a load will be closed to optimum. The approximate theory of the `slow' transient processes of the programmed discharge is considered in the paper. The synthesis of a given current pulse is provided by the choice of the temporary program of capacitors sections discharge initiation as well as by the setting of the initial voltage of these sections. The modes, that were found by the approximate methods, have to be checked up by the computations, taking into account all elements of discharge circuits. The problems of the synthesis of the load current forming are considered.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric network analysis; Programmed discharge mode; Capacitor storage

Authors: Dobson Monika, Greenfield Murray
Title: Process of suspended particulate emission compliance at a Portland cement manufacturing facility in Mississauga, Ontario
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Affiliations: ORTECH Corp, Mississauga, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dobson, Monika, ORTECH Corp, Mississauga, Canada; Greenfield, Murray, ORTECH Corp, Mississauga, Canada
Abstract: St. Lawrence Cement Inc., situated in Mississauga, Ontario along the western shores of Lake Ontario, has the capacity to be one of the largest producers of Portland cement in North America. There are several hundred air emission points where dust is emitted at this facility, including stacks, vents, transfer points, storage piles and roads. A program was established with the aim of reducing dust emissions from this plant to acceptable levels as specified by the Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy (MOEE). Emission rates were determined through measurements and/or calculated with the use of emission factors. Initial measurements included extensive stack tests and determination of road silt loadings. AP-42 and other emission factors were used to determine emissions from handling, wind erosion and road emissions, requiring the measurement of other parameters such as material moisture. The MOEE's air dispersion model was run to determine dust concentrations at the receptors adjacent to this plant. It was determined that controls were required on a number of sources, and an iterative process was undertaken to determine predominant sources and control effectiveness. Wind tunnel tests were conducted on various storage piles to determine the potential effectiveness of surface compacting. Dust suppressants were recommended and applied to the roads and piles. Operational controls, including rerouting traffic, paving roads, and limiting and/or relocating certain operations, were established. In the end, compliance with the 100 ug/m3 Ontario 1/2-hour point-of-impingement total suspended particulate standard was shown to be achievable at this plant. This paper elaborates on some of the methods undertaken during the iterative process of determining representative emission estimates and preferred controls for the dust sources.
Index Keywords: Cement manufacture; Dust control; Iterative methods; Mathematical models; Particulate emissions; Portland cement; Emission factors; Suspended particulate emission compliance; Air pollution control

Authors: Eichinger Frithjof T., Dake Stephan H., Wagner Edward D., Brown Grant S.
Title: Great Lakes Steel - PCI facility

Abstract: This paper discusses the planning, design, and start-up of the 90 tph PCI facility for National Steel's Great Lakes Steel Division in River Rouge, MI. This project is owned and operated by Edison Energy Services, and was implemented on a fast-track basis by Raytheon Engineers & Constructors, Babcock Material Handling, and Babcock & Wilcox. This paper presents important process issues, basic design criteria, and the challenges of engineering and building a state-of-the-an PCI facility in two existing plants. Pulverized coal is prepared at the River Rouge Power Plant of Detroit Edison, is pneumatically conveyed 6,000 feet to a storage silo at Great Lakes Steel, and is injected into three blast furnaces.
Index Keywords: Coke; Fuel injection; Pulverized coal injection; Blast furnace practice

Authors with affiliations: Kobuchi, Ajisman Jun, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Oobayashi, Ken, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Shimada, Ryuichi, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the experimental results of using He (helium) and SF6 (sulfur-hexaflouride) gas mixtures in order to reduce windage loss of vertical shaft type generator/flywheel system. Helium reduces the loss much more, but its electric breakdown voltage is the lowest. The results show that between 15 and 5 percent of He and SF6 mixtures could reduce the windage loss significantly compared to that of air. The gap and surface breakdown voltages of the gases used in the experiment have also been measured.

Authors: Songping W., Ben H.
Title: State description through the Energy-Potential Function and the Generalized Exergy Equation
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Thermodynamic Analysis and Improvement of Energy Systems, TAIES'97
Affiliations: South China Univ of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Songping, W., South China Univ of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Ben, H., South China Univ of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: The essence of energy is measure and expression of motions and variations of the substantial world. Based on this general philosophic viewpoint, in this paper, first of all, a definition of Energy-Potential Function (EPF) has been advanced, and a mathematical method for establishing EPF has been presented. Thus, the essence of the State Postulate and State Equation has been pointed out as being energy correlation and Energy-Potential Equation (EPE). Then, based on the EPF and the definition of exergy (availability), a Generalized Exergy Equation (GEE) has been deduced through mathematical work. The GEE can express not only the existent well-known thermodynamic correlation but the universal exergy equation, which include all types of exergy in any possible domain, such as mechanical, surface, electrical, magnetic and even nuclear exergy.
Index Keywords: Correlation methods; Electric energy storage; Equations of state; Nuclear energy; Surface phenomena; Thermodynamics

Authors: Li S.S.
Title: Feasibility study on using cooling capacitance from ice storage system to save energy costs of operating chiller AC system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Engineering Department, 2320D Tarleton Lane, Baltimore, MD 21234, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, S.S., Engineering Department, 2320D Tarleton Lane, Baltimore, MD 21234, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the economical feasibility of various ways to apply the cooling capacitance from an ice storage system to a chiller air-conditioning system. A parameter of equivalent energy efficiency is defined for the ice-assisted chiller system, and a validity criterion is proposed to judge the feasibility. Several possible ways of applying the ice storage cooling source are described. By using the proposed methodology, a case study via computer simulation is conducted. In this simulation, the validity criterion is so chosen that the improvement to the chiller system would be economically equivalent to increase a chiller efficiency from 0.55 kW/ton to 0.47 kW/ton. A discussion of the simulation results is given. Under the assumed working conditions, to apply the cooling resources to the condensation process or to the liquid line sub-cooling is difficult to be economically feasible. The only better way to use the cooling resource is to cool the chilled water directly. However, in the best case, this system configuration would become one of the working modes of an ice storage system.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Cooling capacitance; Ice storage systems; Refrigerating machinery

Authors: Fleming Mike, Flores Robert, Stoyack Joe
Title: Design, verification and testing of the International Space Station photovoltaic radiator
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Vought Systems, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fleming, Mike, Lockheed Martin Vought Systems, Dallas, United States; Flores, Robert, Lockheed Martin Vought Systems, Dallas, United States; Stoyack, Joe, Lockheed Martin Vought Systems, Dallas, United States
Abstract: The Photovoltaic Radiator (PVR) is designed to reject the waste heat of the PV power generation and storage system. The requirement has been added to provide heat rejection for the Early External Active Thermal Control System to support the Assured Early Research phase of the International Space Station (ISS) Mission. The new requirement has resulted in the reanalysis and some redesign of the hardware. In addition, the new use of the PVR hardware has resulted in a significantly earlier launch date. This paper describes the PVR design with emphasis on the design changes made to incorporate the new mission requirements. The verification methods are discussed and the results of analysis and testing accomplished to date are summarized. Single panel thermal and modal tests have been conducted. Ambient deployment testing and thermal vacuum deployment/thermal performance tests have also been successfully conducted. Additional testing planned include a repeat of the single panel thermal vacuum test for the silver Teflon coating, a stowed acoustic test, a qualification test of the heater system and an acoustic and modal test of three of the units installed on the Flight 4A launch package. All of this testing must be completed by the end of 1997. Structural and thermal analyses have been conducted for the new design requirements and have resulted in several design changes to the structure and thermal design. Thermal analysis is continuing to determine the final thermal design.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Photovoltaic cells; Space stations; Structural analysis; Waste heat; International space station (ISS); Thermal control systems; Direct energy conversion

Authors: Avrillaud G., Lassalle F., Bayol F., Foussat A., Kovacs F., Lample R., Leon J.F., Mechenin J., Monjaux P., Morell A., Roques B., Vezinet R., Kovalchuk B., Kim A., Cassany B., et. al.
Title: SYRINX project: design of the GSI, a 640 kJ inductive energy storage generator
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference

Abstract: The research module GSI, a 640 kJ inductive energy storage generator, is one of the two prototype candidate to bring the future MAG3 z-pinch load driver into operation. The GSI is made of 4 capacitor banks, a water transmission line, a vacuum storage line and a plasma opening switch. Results of parametrical circuit simulations that have been performed on SABER and SCREAMER to chose its electrical features are given. Also, design details of each element and schedules are presented.
Index Keywords: Asynchronous generators; Capacitors; Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric loads; Electric network analysis; Switches; Capacitor banks; Inductive energy storage generator; Parametrical circuit simulations; Plasma opening switch; Vacuum storage line; Water transmission line; Z pinch load driver; Electric generators

Authors: Gladis Sam P.
Title: Slurry ice thermal energy storage for cheese process cooling
Affiliations: Paul Mueller Co, Springfield, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gladis, Sam P., Paul Mueller Co, Springfield, United States
Abstract: Many industrial processes require a large load to be cooled in a relatively short period. These loads often utilize supply chilled-water temperatures in the range of 34°F (1.1°C) to 36°F (2.2°C). The low water temperatures can be supplied from conventional 'on-demand' chillers, such as falling film water chillers or shell-and-tube chillers using a brine solution. The low water temperatures can also be supplied from thermal energy storage (TES) systems, such as static ice builders, or dynamic ice systems, such as an ice harvester or slurry ice maker. The benefits of using a TES system in industrial processes, versus an 'on-demand' chiller, include smaller refrigeration equipment, 'reserve' cooling capacity, lower electrical capacity requirements, and lower energy costs. This paper outlines a unique type of dynamic slurry ice system applied to a cheese processing plant. Dynamic ice systems separate the manufacture of ice from the storage of ice. These systems are capable of satisfying very large loads of short duration by rapidly melting stored ice. Rapid melting of ice is achievable with dynamic ice-type TES systems because the warm water returning from the load comes in direct contact with the ice in storage.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Ice; Temperature; Thermal load; Chillers; Thermal energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Sadeghzadeh S.M., Ehsan M., Said N.H., Feuillet R.
Title: Multi-machine power system transient stability improvement using fuzzy sliding mode control of SMES
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sharif Univ of Technology
Authors with affiliations: Sadeghzadeh, S.M., Sharif Univ of Technology; Ehsan, M., Sharif Univ of Technology; Said, N.H., Sharif Univ of Technology; Feuillet, R., Sharif Univ of Technology
Abstract: A fuzzy sliding mode control is proposed to improve the transient stability and damping requirements of the large power systems. This control strategy is applied to a super-conducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit. The SMES unit is installed at a mid-point along a transmission line and is controlled locally. The modeling aspects of the power system, the SMES unit and the simplified system for controller design are presented. The generalization of the sliding mode control and fuzzy control to the proposed problem are discussed. The simulation results of the New-England test system are clearly demonstrated. Finally the conclusions are provided.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control; Electric power transmission; Fuzzy sets; System stability; Transients; Superconducting magnetic energy storage unit; Electric power systems

Authors: Fridman B.E., Rutberg Ph.G.
Title: Installation for pulse compression with use of the heavy current pulse discharge
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, Ph.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The pressure, arising at passage of the large pulse current through the cylindrical liner, can be used for creation of super-high pressure and pulse compression of specimens. Such pressure is necessary for various physicals researches, for study of phase conversions of substances. The installation for creation of the pulse pressure in the z-pinch scheme is described in the paper. The installation is connected to the terminal of E7-25 Capacitive Energy Store and it is designed on 10 MA current pulse with 20 kV voltage. The first test results of the installation are submitted.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Pressure effects; Pulse compression; Electric discharges

Authors: Bastrikov A.N., Kim A.A., Kovalchuk B.M., Kumpjak E.V., Loginov S.V., Manylov V.I., Visir V.A., Yakovlev V.P., Etlicher B., Chuvatin A., Frescaline L., Leon J.F., Monjaux P., Kovacs F., Huet D., et. al.
Title: Fast primary energy storage based on linear transformer scheme
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: RAS, Tomsk, Russian Federation

Abstract: The concept of the primary storage based on linear transformer scheme is well known for many years. The challenge has been to build a fast linear transformer driver (LTD), providing both high efficiency of energy transfer into the secondary turn and the current rise time below approx. 1 μs. To date, several LTDs that meet this challenge have been developed.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitors; Electric transformer insulation; Electrodes; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Gaskets; Pulse generators; Ground potential; Linear transformer driver; Marx generator; Electric transformers

Authors: Nelms R.M.
Title: Comparison of resonant converters operating with a double-layer capacitor source
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelms, R.M., Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Abstract: Double-layer capacitors, with their high energy storage capability, may be utilized to supply peak power requirements in systems such as electric vehicles. As energy is drawn from a bank of double-layer capacitors, the voltage at the terminals of the capacitor bank decreases. Seventy-five percent of the initial energy stored in the capacitor bank can be utilized if the voltage is allowed to decrease to one-half of its initial value. The capacitor bank can be augmented with a dc-dc converter to present a constant voltage to an external system as the capacitor bank voltage decreases. Discussed in this paper is a comparison of three basic resonant dc-dc converter circuits when used as the converter with such a capacitor bank. Simple equivalent circuits are developed for each converter using a single frequency approximation of the various converter waveforms. Expressions for the voltage gain and the phase angle of the input current for each converter are derived from these equivalent circuits and plotted as a function of frequency. Issues related to the selection and design of a converter for this application are discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Equivalent circuits; Frequency domain analysis; Resonant circuits; Double layer capacitors; Electric converters

Authors: Fridman B.E., Rutberg Ph.
Title: Multimegajoule capacitive energy stores for generating pulses with large current integral
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, Ph., Russian Acad of Sciences, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The problems of the design multimegajoule and multimegaampere capacitive energy stores for generating pulses with large current integral are considered. The essence of these problems is described on an example of E7-25 type Capacitive Energy Store of Institute of Problems of Electrophysics of RAS. The E7-25 energy store was tested and it generated the 10 MA current pulse with current integral up to 5·109 A2s.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Current voltage characteristics; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric rectifiers; Energy dissipation; Equipment testing; Pulse generators; Current integral; Current pulse; Multimegajoule capacitive energy store; Energy storage

Authors: Spyker R.L., Nelms R.M.
Title: Discharge characteristics of high energy storage double layer capacitors
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spyker, R.L., Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States; Nelms, R.M., Auburn Univ, Auburn, United States
Abstract: The double-layer capacitor is a recent innovation that combines high surface area electrode materials with the high capacitance per unit area of the chemical double layer. Commercially available devices with a capacitance of 1500 F are now available. This improvement in rated capacitance has presented opportunities for the use of double layer capacitors in high power and/or high energy storage applications. This paper examines the discharge performance characteristics of several capacitors, including both aqueous and organic electrolyte devices. A useful simplified model is assumed for the double layer capacitor, consisting of an equivalent series resistance (ESR) and a capacitor in series. Values for these two parameters are determined in this investigation under various discharge conditions, along with peak current during short circuit conditions.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Electric discharges; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Electrolytes; Equivalent circuits; Mathematical models; Equivalent series resistance (ESR); High energy storage double layer capacitors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Wilhelm Thomas E.
Title: Borates used in porcelain enamels
Affiliations: U.S. Borax Inc, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilhelm, Thomas E., U.S. Borax Inc, Chicago, United States
Abstract: The historical background and widespread use of borates are highlighted. Use in porcelain enamel frits, mill additions, and metal cleaning is described. Different types of borates and their water content, stability, storage and handling characteristics, particulate emissions, energy aspects, and other production-related issues are discussed.
Index Keywords: Boron compounds; Materials handling; Metal cleaning; Particulate emissions; Porcelain; Storage (materials); Water; Borates; Porcelain enamels; Enamels

Authors: Chang Jie
Title: Design tradeoffs and technology outlook of highly compact integrated AC motors
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference - Nagaoka, PCC
Affiliations: Rockwell Int Corp, Thousand Oaks, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Jie, Rockwell Int Corp, Thousand Oaks, United States
Abstract: Integrated AC motors offer many desirable features, such as high compactness, reduced material cost, reduced engineering time for installation or integration, and better protection against short circuiting and over-voltage due to dv/dt induced voltage reflection waves. This paper discusses the basic considerations of temperature sensitive component selection, device availability, design tradeoffs, and reduction of the dc-link capacitor which is the weakest component in the system. Preliminary experimental results are reported to verify the design concept. A brief technology outlook is given to prepare future challenges.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric drives; Energy storage; Overvoltage protection; Power converters; Power electronics; Semiconductor devices; DC link capacitor; Integrated AC motors; AC motors

Authors: Saitoh Takeo S., Hoshi Akira
Title: Analysis of close-contact melting with inner wall temperature variation in a horizontal cylindrical capsule
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo S., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Hoshi, Akira, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Melting and solidification of a phase change material (PCM) in a capsule is of practical importance in latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) systems which are considered to be very promising to reduce a peak demand of electricity in the summer season. Two melting modes are involved in melting in capsules. One is close-contact melting between the solid bulk and the capsule wall, and another is natural convection melting in the liquid region. In recent years, close-contact melting processes for a single enclosure have been solved using several numerical methods (e.g. Saitoh and Kato (1994)). However, there is no theoretical solution considering the inner wall temperature variation within cylindrical or spherical capsules. In this report close-contact melting heat transfer characteristics including melt flow in the liquid film under inner wall temperature distribution were analysed and simple approximate equations are presented, which facilitates designing of the practical capsule bed LHTES systems. The effects of Stefan number and variable temperature profile etc. were clarified in detail. And the melting velocity of the solid bulk under various conditions was also studied theoretically. In addition the effects of variable inner wall temperature on molten mass fraction were investigated.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Energy storage; Flow of fluids; Melting; Numerical analysis; Temperature distribution; Velocity; Approximate equations; Latent heat thermal energy storage; Melt flow; Molten mass fraction; Stefan number; Temperature profile; Heat transfer

Authors: Zhu Zheng, Carlson Bradley S.
Title: Critical voltage transition logic: An ultrafast CMOS logic family
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: SUNY at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Zheng, SUNY at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, United States; Carlson, Bradley S., SUNY at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, United States
Abstract: We present a new kind of CMOS logic circuit that has a different structure and different operation mechanism compared to the existing logic circuits. Its unique delay propagation characteristic makes it much faster than the conventional CMOS logic gate. Gate outputs are preconditioned to a voltage level between Vdd and Vss using a new clocking scheme and circuit design. We give a buffer design example which is about 6.5 times faster than the conventional buffer. The total energy consumed by the new circuit structure is slightly more than conventional CMOS domino logic; however, the energy-delay product is smaller.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; CMOS integrated circuits; Logic gates; Timing circuits; Critical voltage transition logic; Logic circuits

Authors: Zuchowicki Waldemar A., Hryniewicz Tadeusz, Twardowska Wanda M., Kuczynski Wojciech

Abstract: A new technical solutions of waste management in the region of Central Pomerania, Poland is described. The disadvantageous interaction/influence of stockyard gas-cap driving and processing is eliminated and a renewable energy source is gained. Beside the biogas production and its management, the reduction in pollution and rendering waste harmless is achieved resulting in unspoken effects/advantages in the environment protection. It is also essential that acceding/joining the adaptational process for full participation in the European Union, Poland puts a special stress on the waste management problems by making efforts leading to the protection of natural environment.

Abstract: This paper presents the results of a team approach to the design and construction of an electrical system for a solar electric vehicle. The design proceeds from the selection of solar cells to the electric drive with solar tracking and optimal battery storage. The vehicle design is being implemented for construction in the 1997 Sunrayce.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Sensors; Solar cells; Systems analysis; Telemetering; Electrical system design; Instrumentation; Optimal battery storage; Power conversion; Power input; Solar electric vehicle; Solar tracking; Electric vehicles

Authors: Byam Brooks P., Radcliffe Clark J.
Title: Statistical Energy Analysis model and connectors for automotive vibration isolation mounts
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byam, Brooks P., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States; Radcliffe, Clark J., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Abstract: Consumer comfort is a top priority in today s vehicle design. Reduction of noise and vibration enhances comfort and improves the overall quality of the vehicle. Linear elastic vibration isolation mounts are traditionally applied within complex structures to combat noise and vibration. Statistical Energy Analysis (SEA) is becoming an established and tested noise and vibration modeling methodology that is frequently used to model the flow of noise and vibration in complex structures. A SEA model of a linear elastic vibration isolation mount is developed here which enables SEA analysis of elastically isolated systems for the first time. A vibration isolation mount model has been absent from SEA models because of the lack of an SEA formulation. Linear elastic vibration isolation mount SEA equations are developed here for the first time. The basis of SEA theory is energy sharing among vibrational mode groups. Traditionally, vibration isolation mounts were thought of as compliant elements with no modes suitable to SEA analysis. An example mount is defined and the number of energy storage modes computed. The results show that a linear elastic vibration isolation mount should be modeled in SEA analysis and provide the equations for a SEA isolation mount model. Also included is the analysis for three unique SEA connectors, a mount to acoustic volume connector, a beam to mount connector, and a mount to flat plate connector.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Elasticity; Mathematical models; Statistical methods; Vibration control; Linear elastic vibration isolation mounts; Statistical energy analysis (SEA) models; Engine mountings

Authors: Matsui Mikihiko, Akiyama Toshio
Title: Basic study on a parallel resonant link converter for a high frequency link system
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference - Nagaoka, PCC
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Kanagawa, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsui, Mikihiko, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Kanagawa, Japan; Akiyama, Toshio, Tokyo Inst of Polytechnics, Kanagawa, Japan
Abstract: The parallel resonant link high frequency power distribution system can be an attractive system as a supplementary local distribution line linked with existing ac commercial system line in a building or a plant, if some new energy sources and energy storage systems are combined and connected with the link. This paper deals with some basic issues of a unit converter for such system from both microscopic (stable switching operation) and macroscopic (energy flow) points of view. A PDM (pulse density modulation) gate control circuit for stable operation and self start-up from stand still is tested. Effect of PDM sampling period on steady state waveforms is compared on three cases. Bad effect of parasitic capacitance of switching arm is shown, and its countermeasure is given. Based on probabilistic switching function technique, a dc equivalent circuit model suited for simulating macroscopic energy flow is proposed.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Equivalent circuits; Pulse modulation; Resonant circuits; Switching circuits; Waveform analysis; Gate control circuits; Probabilistic switching function technique; Pulse density modulation (PDM); Power converters

Authors: Koeneman P.B., Busch-Vishniac I.J., Wood K.L.
Title: Feasibility of micro power supplies for MEMS
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, United States; University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States; University of Texas, United States; Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Acoustics Research Department, Bell Labs.; Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States; Acoustical Society of America, United States; Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States; California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Mech. Systems and Design Division, University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States; AT and T Bell Laboratories, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koeneman, P.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, United States, University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States, University of Texas, United States; Busch-Vishniac, I.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States, Acoustics Research Department, Bell Labs., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States, Acoustical Society of America, United States; Wood, K.L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States, University of Texas, United States, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, United States, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Mech. Systems and Design Division, University of Texas, Austin, TX, United States, AT and T Bell Laboratories, United States
Abstract: Most microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) designed today use macroscopic power supplies, thereby placing limits on the functionality of MEMS in many applications. An alternative to this approach is to design MEMS with integral microscopic distributed power supplies. This paper examines the feasibility of creating micro power supplies by considering three functions common to MEMS power systems: 1) capture energy; 2) store energy; and 3) drive actuation. Of these, only the capture energy function is highly dependent on the specific application. For each of the three functions, a table is presented which compares various means of performing the function. This information makes it possible to determine what design alternatives are feasible for the creation of a micro power supply for any specific application of MEMS. We use smart bearings with active surface features as an example application and develop a design for a micro power supply suitable for this work. [234].
Author Keywords: Energy densities; Micro power supplies; Smart hydrodynamic bearings
Index Keywords: Actuators; Electric energy storage; Electric transformers; Microelectromechanical devices; Sensors; Energy densities; Micro power supplies; Microelectromechanical systems; Smart hydrodynamic bearings; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Miller N.W., Zrebiec R.S., Delmerico R.W., Hunt George
Title: Design and commissioning of a 2.5 MWh battery energy storage system
Affiliations: GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, N.W., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Zrebiec, R.S., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Delmerico, R.W., GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States; Hunt, George, GE Power Systems Engineering Dep, Schenectady, United States
Abstract: Momentary and sustained power interruptions are one of the most difficult and important power quality problems facing many industrial and commercial users. A particularly challenging problem is the need to supply an economical, dependable, efficient and controllable source of real and reactive power, which is available instantly to support a large (>1.0 MW) load, if the utility connection is lost. Battery energy storage systems (BESS) have the potential to provide versatile solutions to this problem for utility, industrial and commercial applications. This paper describes the design and installation 5 MW peak, 2.5 MWh BESS which is now in commercial operation at the BNG Battery Recycling Facility in Vernon, California. Results of commissioning test are discussed. The BESS at Vernon provides the required power combined with both voltage and frequency control necessary to allow the Vernon facility to tolerate disconnection from the utility grid without suffering unacceptable impacts on critical loads.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric frequency control; Electric loads; Voltage control; Battery energy storage systems; Standby power systems

Topics discussed include: electric disturbances and overvoltages; network harmonic impedance assessment; active compensator-rectifier load interactions; flicker prediction and simulation; grid connected wind turbines; electric power supply quality; AC and DC drives; voltage dips and interruptions; battery energy storage systems; electromagnetic compensators; superconducting magnetic energy storage systems; DC links; fault induced voltage sag elimination; contact voltage and grounding resistance determination; standardized transforming centers; earth faults; low-, medium-, and high-voltage networks; and overvoltage protection.
