Authors: Marchetti G.
Title: Mathematical models for the construction of a twice renewable energy plant
Affiliations: Scuola di Specializzazione in TLC, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Marchetti, G., Scuola di Specializzazione in TLC, Roma, Italy
Abstract: In order to develop renewable energy sources technology in stand-alone power supply plants, it is necessary to provide designers with tools capable of recognizing at short notice any areas of convenience in their utilization, including projects with twice renewable generators. Typical renewable sources considered are solar and wind energy, but the results are general anywhere energy sources with random emissions are available. For this purpose it is necessary to know in advance the Cost-Law for this kind of power plant in order to make possible comparisons with the costs for traditional power supply plants, and therefore to be in a position to make a correct decision. Block diagram of the plants includes: - two renewable generators (PS and PW) - storage battery (B) and electronics. Project data and power emission law, in turn customized by the meteorological parameters with probabilistic-statistic algorithms are processed to define sizing parameters evaluating cost/load-power Q/PL that depends on three factors: I: a = PS/ (PS+PW) PL sharing factor of the two nominal power PS, PW assigned of each of the sources S and W; II: b = battery-energy/PL autonomy assigned to the battery; III: u = estimated maximum unavailability. The overall cost can be therefore determined through a minimum cost algorithm, such a cost being a function, for a fixed u, of the two variables a and b.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric generators; Mathematical models; Secondary batteries; Renewable energy plants; Electric power plants

Authors: Menegaz Paulo J.M., Vieira Jose L.F., Simonetti Domingos S.L.
Title: Magnetically coupled regenerative turn-on and turn-off snubber configuration
Affiliations: Universidade Federal do Espirito, Santo, Vitoria, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Menegaz, Paulo J.M., Universidade Federal do Espirito, Santo, Vitoria, Brazil; Vieira, Jose L.F., Universidade Federal do Espirito, Santo, Vitoria, Brazil; Simonetti, Domingos S.L., Universidade Federal do Espirito, Santo, Vitoria, Brazil
Abstract: This paper presents a magnetically coupled regenerative turn-on and turn-off snubber configuration applied to a boost converter which operates at continuous conduction mode (CCM). In addition to reducing the stresses in the switch, providing soft transitions in its turn-off voltage and turn-on current, it transfers the energy stored in the snubber capacitor to the load. This is achieved by using a coupled inductor mounted on the main inductor of the converter, which resets the capacitor voltage at each switching period. Design equations, as well as experimental results are presented, showing the high efficiency of the boost converter by using the proposed snubber.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Energy efficiency; Energy transfer; Mathematical models; Power converters; Power inductors; Boost converters; Continuous conduction mode (CCM); Regenerative snubbers; Electric switches

Authors: Goldfarb V., Budny R., Dunton A., Shneerson G., Krivosheev S., Adamian Yu.
Title: Removal of surface layer of concrete by a pulse-periodical discharge
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goldfarb, V., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States; Budny, R., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States; Dunton, A., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States; Shneerson, G., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States; Krivosheev, S., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States; Adamian, Yu., Textron Systems, Wilmington, United States
Abstract: To clean concrete (e.g., floor) contaminated by hazardous chemicals or radionuclides, its surface layer has to be removed. In our experiments and large area trials, 0.5 cm to 3 cm thick concrete layers have been removed either by the shock waves and cavitation initiated in water by a discharge or by a direct breakdown through concrete. The discharge mode is defined by the PFN design and operation parameters. In both cases, the spark discharge took place between two parallel linear electrodes. Concrete is crushed and spalled by a series of tens or hundreds of pulses following at 2 to 20 Hz frequency. Discharge through water follows breakdown at 20-30 kV, and effective concrete layer removal takes place for 30-50 kA, 20-40 μs current pulses. Consumption of capacitance-stored energy is about 1.5 kJ per 1 cm3 of concrete. Discharge through concrete requires much higher (100-150 kV) voltage, but only a few kA current amplitude of a 3 to 5 μs pulse is required. In this case, energy consumption is lower-about 0.8 kJ/cm3. The presentation provides a description of the prototype industrial unit, results of trial runs, energetic characteristics and decontamination quality.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Concretes; Electric breakdown of solids; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electrodes; Hazardous materials; Radioisotopes; Shock waves; Surface cleaning; Pulse periodical discharges; Electric sparks

Authors: Ford R.D., Dorr G., Reams R., Toepfer A.J.
Title: High coulomb triggered vacuum flashover switch
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Science Applications Int Corp, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ford, R.D., Science Applications Int Corp, Albuquerque, United States; Dorr, G., Science Applications Int Corp, Albuquerque, United States; Reams, R., Science Applications Int Corp, Albuquerque, United States; Toepfer, A.J., Science Applications Int Corp, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: As high energy pulsed power sources become more compact, switching components are needed which complement the reduced size energy store while maintaining high discharge capability previously performed by several individual switches. This paper discusses an operational triggered vacuum switch which holds off voltages to 20 kV for several minutes duration. It can be triggered reliably over a range from 2 kV to 20 kV, discharges at peak current as high as 1 MA, and operates with a charge transfer of up to 50 coulombs for hundreds of discharges without requiring maintenance. Triggering is accomplished by irradiating a dielectric flash-over surface from a low voltage (2-5 kV) spark source. Triggering delay is less than 600 ns at 10 kV or higher. The switch design is derived from an earlier high power vacuum flash-over switch prototype originally developed as a 40-kV isolation switch within a closed vacuum inductive energy store. Modifications include re-design of the flash-over dielectric to serve both as a vacuum enclosure and discharge cable support, reduction of the number of vacuum to atmospheric interface surfaces to improve sealing, use of aluminum electrodes with ceramic lining to reduce size and weight while minimizing conductor erosion during discharge, and designing small expendable electrode inserts for simple, low cost replacement. The switch is used routinely in applications including operation of a 56-kJ, 700 kA magnetic swager for forming high current cable terminations, where discharge occurs at approximately 5 minute intervals.
Index Keywords: Charge transfer; Electric conductors; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric sparks; Electrodes; Flashover; Interfaces (materials); Trigger circuits; Vacuum technology; Closed vacuum inductive energy storage; High coulomb triggered vacuum flashover switches; Electric switches

Authors: Jacob T.
Title: Pumped storage in Switzerland: Outlook beyond 2000
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Stucky Consulting Engineers Ltd., Switzerland; Stucky Consulting Engineers, 61 av. d'Ouchy, CH-1000 Lausanne 6, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Jacob, T., Stucky Consulting Engineers Ltd., Switzerland, Stucky Consulting Engineers, 61 av. d'Ouchy, CH-1000 Lausanne 6, Switzerland
Abstract: Hydraulic storage Is the most attractive solution for the power modulation of an electric grid. When the natural storage capacity is limited, pumped storage can enhance the modulation cycle. Switzerland has a long tradition of hydro generation, and pumped-storage plants from the 1920s are still in service. With the opening of the national electricity market to the European Community, the economic evaluation of new projects will become more favourable to pumped storage on the continental scale. This paper discusses future developments, in terms of electric grid management strategies and technical progress in pump-turbine design.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power systems; Electricity; Energy utilization; Hydraulic storage; Power modulation; Switzerland; Pumped storage power plants

Authors: Bitterly Jack G.
Title: Flywheel technology past, present, and 21st century projections
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Flywheel Systems, Newbury Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bitterly, Jack G., U.S. Flywheel Systems, Newbury Park, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the present status of flywheel energy storage technology, or mechanical batteries, and discusses realistic future projections that are possible based on stronger composite materials and advancing technology. The origins and use of flywheel technology for mechanical energy storage began several 100 years ago and was developed throughout the Industrial Revolution. One of the first 'modern' dissertations on the theoretical stress limitations of rotational disks (isotropic only) is the seminal work by Dr. A. Stodola [1] whose first translation to English was made in 1917. The next big milestones were during the 1960's and 1970's when NASA sponsored programs proposed energy storage flywheels as possible primary sources for space missions. However, it was not until the 1980's when micro electronics, magnetic bearing systems and high power density motor-generators became enabling technologies. The next decade proved that a mechanical battery could surpass chemical batteries for many applications.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Energy storage; Magnetic bearings; Rotors; Synchronous generators; Synchronous motors; Chemical batteries; Mechanical batteries; Flywheels

Authors: Grob Eric W., Chalmers Douglas R., Bennett Charles W.
Title: Thermal design & verification of the EOS-AM1 nickel hydrogen batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grob, Eric W., Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States; Chalmers, Douglas R., Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States; Bennett, Charles W., Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States
Abstract: The EOS-AM Spacecraft, which will launch in July 1998, will carry one of the most sophisticated Electrical Power Subsystems (EPS) on any Spacecraft to date. The subsystem has been designed to supply the spacecraft with regulated 120 V power for the planned 5 year mission in Low Earth orbit, using advanced state-of-the art techniques. A key EPS element is the energy storage system, which is based on two 54 cell 50 amp-hr nickel hydrogen (NiH2) batteries. The thermal design represents Lockheed Martin Astro Space's first conductively coupled, vertically mounted battery panel design with active thermal control. The thermal environment is crucial to battery performance given the 30% DOD utilization. Battery performance and electrochemical stress are dependent upon the operating temperatures and gradients. The challenge in developing the Battery thermal design and details of the thermal design verification, along with thermal balance test results to date, is the subject for this paper.
Index Keywords: Electrochemistry; Electrolytic cells; Secondary batteries; Spacecraft power supplies; Temperature control; Thermal effects; Thermal gradients; Nickel hydrogen cells; Fuel cells

Authors: Veermani Sudha, Wereley Norman M.
Title: Modeling and experimental validation of a sandwich plate with isotropic face plates and viscoelestic core
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Maryland/Coll. Park, Coll., Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Veermani, Sudha, Univ. of Maryland/Coll. Park, Coll., Park, MD, USA; Wereley, Norman M., Univ. of Maryland/Coll. Park, Coll., Park, MD, USA
Abstract: We analyze and experimentally validate an analysis of a sandwich plate structure, where anisotropic face plates sandwich a viscoelastic core. Existing analytical models have been modified to incorporate piezo-actuation in anisotropic and 3-layered thin plates, using the variational energy method. The 3-layered sandwich consists of anisotropic face- plates with surface bonded piezo-electric actuators, and a viscoelastic core. The analysis includes the membrane and transverse energies in the face plates, and shear in the viscoelastic core. A constant, complex shear modulus was used for the dissipative core, thus frequency and temperature dependence of viscoelastic properties is neglected in this model. Simplified forms of the equations are stated based on neglecting shear in face-plates. Experiments were conducted on sandwich plates with aluminum face-plates under clamped boundary conditions to validate the simplified model. Symmetric and asymmetric sandwiches were tested. The maximum error in the first eight natural frequency predictions obtained via the assumed modes solution is less than 10%. Analytical studies on the influence of the number of assumed modes in the Galerkin approximation, and the core storage modulus variation, were conducted. The importance of the in- plane extension modes in sandwich plate analysis was demonstrated. Error in the first natural frequency is nearly 100% when in-plane modes are ignored; error reduces and converges to 6.7% as number of modes is increased to 16 in each of the in-plane directions for each face plate.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Boundary conditions; Error analysis; Intelligent control; Membranes; Piezoelectric devices; Thermal effects; Viscoelasticity; Isotropic face plates; Sandwich plates; Plates (structural components)

Authors: Yang Sheng-Hui, Lee Chi H., Lowry Curt, Johnson Fred, Stone Dennis
Title: High-power tunable picosecond lasers at 1.55 μm wavelength
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting-LEOS
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Sheng-Hui, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Lee, Chi H., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Lowry, Curt, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Johnson, Fred, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Stone, Dennis, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: A strained layer InGaAsP multiple quantum well ridge waveguide laser consisting of a gain section and a voltage-controlled absorber section is investigated. The length of the absorber section is designed to have the L-I characteristics show large (approximately 5 mW) and abrupt `jumps' at a high injection current in the gain section. This permits a large energy storage as well as an effective voltage-controlled loss modulation using only moderate RF power. The high power, tunable picosecond pulses are generated by the Q-switched 1.55 μm MQW laser. The wavelength tuning is achieved by external continuous wave (CW) seeding, which is more flexible than the self-seeding scheme. A large tuning range of 33 nm and near 20 dB side-mode suppression ratio is obtained.
Index Keywords: High power lasers; Laser pulses; Laser tuning; Optical fibers; Optical waveguides; Q switched lasers; Semiconducting indium compounds; Voltage control; Dispersion compensated fibers (DCF); External continuous wave (CW) seeding; High power tunable picosecond lasers; Side mode suppression ratio (SMSR); Quantum well lasers

Authors: Pun Kwok Cheung
Title: New activity model for scene adaptive quantization
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Information, Communications and Signal Processing, ICICS
Affiliations: Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Pun, Kwok Cheung, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: A new activity model has been developed for scene adaptive quantization. It is fitted into a discrete cosine transform (DCT) very-large-scale integrated circuits (VLSI) chip set to remedy the occlusions produced in active pictures. The design is based on the human perception Gabor function and the maximum energy of a resonant R-L-C electrical circuit. Consequently, a theoretical region for optimum use of quantization bits has been charted and, new and simple mathematics are derived to cope with the block artifacts in moving pictures under a controlled buffer.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Mathematical models; Mathematical transformations; Resonant circuits; Vision; VLSI circuits; Discrete cosine transforms; Scene adaptive quantization; Image coding

Authors: Troxell John R., Harrington Marie I., Perisho Jr. Robert A., Thoeny Michael, Borzabadi Ali F., Dikeman J.Mark, Borowitz Peter J., Sakurada Hiroshi, Shinya Souichi, Yano Kazuyuki
Title: 9600 ftL AMVF display with integrated driver circuitry
Source title: SID Conference Record of the International Display Research Conference
Affiliations: General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States
Authors with affiliations: Troxell, John R., General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Harrington, Marie I., General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Perisho Jr., Robert A., General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Thoeny, Michael, General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Borzabadi, Ali F., General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Dikeman, J.Mark, General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Borowitz, Peter J., General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Sakurada, Hiroshi, General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Shinya, Souichi, General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States; Yano, Kazuyuki, General Motors R&D Cent, Warren, United States
Abstract: A 9600 ftL reconfigurable, Active Matrix Vacuum Fluorescent Display (AMVFD) has been developed. An integrated isolation grid structure, CMOS pixel memory and display addressing circuitry yield a compact, energy efficient reconfigurable flat panel image source with the highest reported brightness.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Data storage equipment; Electric conductivity of solids; Luminescence; Phosphors; Active matrix vacuum fluorescent (AMVF) displays; Head up display (HUD) systems; Fluorescent screens

Authors: Simmonds Peter, Braam Toon
Title: Thermal storage incorporated in the mechanical system for printing works to offset peak loads
Affiliations: Flack + Kurtz Consulting Engineers, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simmonds, Peter, Flack + Kurtz Consulting Engineers, New York, United States; Braam, Toon, Flack + Kurtz Consulting Engineers, New York, United States
Abstract: The electrical consumption of a printing works can be reduced by utilizing thermal storage to offset loads. In order to achieve a balance between 100% outdoor air and conditioned air, different ventilation schemes were compared. The subsequent cooling load derived from the comparison was further evaluated to see if a chiller plant together with a thermal storage system would reduce energy costs.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Printing; Thermal load; Ventilation; Chiller plant; Energy costs; Printing works; Heat storage

Authors: Orphelin Matthieu, Adnot Jerome
Title: Electric storage water heaters: from laboratory measurements to field electricity consumption
Affiliations: Cent for Energy Studies at the Ecole, des Mines de Paris, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Orphelin, Matthieu, Cent for Energy Studies at the Ecole, des Mines de Paris, Paris, France; Adnot, Jerome, Cent for Energy Studies at the Ecole, des Mines de Paris, Paris, France
Abstract: A technical and economic analysis of demand-side management (DSM) actions on electric storage water heaters (ESWH) must be based on a reliable consumption and electric load curve calculation. Water heater stocks and typical hot water needs to be taken into account are generally well defined at a certain stage of DSM studies. The remaining problem is to take into account real operating conditions to determine power demand and energy consumption. This study provides elements with which to answer the following questions: How are the intrinsic parameters of a water heater linked to global consumption or peak demand? How to compute field standby losses, which are generally far from laboratory test measurements? How much energy and peak demand can be transferred through night/day control? How does this influence overall energy consumption of ESWH? A model has been developed to perform simulations. Influential parameters have been tested to produce practical correlations. Results are given in terms of energy consumption for the 'night/day control' and 'no-control' extreme simulations.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Economic and social effects; Electric load management; Electric power utilization; Energy utilization; Standards; Electric storage water heaters; Laboratory test measurement; Water heaters

Authors: Kaplan M.S., Harrison R.L., Vannoy S.D.
Title: Coherent scatter implementation for SimSET
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kaplan, M.S., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States; Harrison, R.L., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States; Vannoy, S.D., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: At 140 keV, 3% of photon scatter interaction in human tissues are coherent scatter; at Tl-201 emission energies, this fraction increases to approximately 7%. However, since coherent scatter at these energies is sharply forward-peaked, it is often the dominant scatter interaction at small angles. SimSET (Simulation System for Emission Tomography), which previously modeled only photoelectric absorption and Compton scatter, has been extended to include coherent scatter. The current implementation uses form factor and anomalous scattering amplitude data from the Livermore Evaluated Photon Data Library. Interaction probability and angular distribution tables for several human tissues and common detector materials were calculated using the independent atoms approximation and human-tissue composition data from the ICRP Reference Man. These data were also used to generate new tables for photoelectric absorption and Compton scatter, significantly improving the accuracy of SimSET and extending its photon tracking capability to lower photon energy (from 50 keV to 1 keV). The form, content, and structure of the tables were carefully designed for efficient data storage, access, and use by the software. The derived data tables and implementation of coherent scatter were validated by comparing simulation results to published differential cross-section data.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Computer simulation; Computer software; Diagnostic radiography; Light scattering; Photodetectors; Table lookup; Tissue; Coherent scatter; Software package SimSET; Computerized tomography

Authors: Lassalle F., Avrillaud G., Bayol F., Cassany B., Foussat A., Kovacs F., Lample R., Leon J.F., Monjaux P., Morell A., Roques B., Vezinet R., Kovalchuk B.
Title: SYRINX project: first results on a 160kJ, 700ns fast MARX module
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France
Authors with affiliations: Lassalle, F., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Avrillaud, G., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Bayol, F., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Cassany, B., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Foussat, A., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Kovacs, F., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Lample, R., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Leon, J.F., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Monjaux, P., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Morell, A., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Roques, B., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Vezinet, R., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France; Kovalchuk, B., Cent d'Etudes de Gramat, Gramat, France
Abstract: This work is part of technological developments carried out within SYRINX project in order to implement future multi megajoules drivers, using multi module Inductive Energy Storage (IES) concept. One of the two 640kJ IES modules developed for that purpose requires a compact, sub-microsecond MARX generator. This paper presents first results on a 10 stages, one capacitor per stage Marx module whose parameters are as follows: 90kV charging voltage, 160kJ stored energy, 670nH internal inductance, 470kA peak current, and a 700ns current risetime. Specific capacitors, gas switches and connections have been developed in the scope to reach stringent requirements in terms of low inductance value, high current switching, voltage insulation and reliability. Performances of those components and of the complete Marx including erection process and voltage and current diagnostics for various loads (short circuit, 0.5Ω and 2.1Ω resistances) are presented. Those results are correlated with numerical simulations using the circuit analysis code PSPICE.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric loads; Electric network analysis; Electric resistance; Inductance measurement; Insulation; Performance; Reliability; Switching circuits; Voltage measurement; Fast capacitors; High current switching; Inductive energy storage; Low inductance connection; Marx generator; Pspice circuit analysis code; Voltage insulation; Electric generators

Authors: Palomino G.Ernest, Wiles John, Stevens John, Goodman Frank
Title: Performance of a grid connected residential photovoltaic system with energy storage
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: SRP, Phoenix, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palomino, G.Ernest, SRP, Phoenix, United States; Wiles, John, SRP, Phoenix, United States; Stevens, John, SRP, Phoenix, United States; Goodman, Frank, SRP, Phoenix, United States
Abstract: In 1995, Salt River Project (SRP), a public power utility located in Phoenix, Arizona, collaborated with the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and Sandia National Laboratories (Sandia) to initiate a research project to evaluate the feasibility of using a photovoltaic (PV) power system with battery energy storage to match PV output with residential customer peak energy demand periods. The PV power system, a 2.4 kW PV array with 25.2 kWh of energy storage, was designed and installed by Southwest Technology Development Institute (SWTDI) at an SRP-owned facility, known as the Chandler Research House during August 1995. This paper presents an overview of the system design, operation and performance.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Photovoltaic cells; Photovoltaic power system; Solar cells

Authors: Gasparyan P.D., Demin A.N., Subbotin A.N., Usenko P.L.
Title: Diagnostics of the soft X-ray emission in a plasma focus device
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: All-Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhnii Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gasparyan, P.D., All-Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhnii Novgorod, Russian Federation; Demin, A.N., All-Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhnii Novgorod, Russian Federation; Subbotin, A.N., All-Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhnii Novgorod, Russian Federation; Usenko, P.L., All-Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhnii Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: Experimental results of the soft x-ray spectra investigation from a hot plasma produced by impulse discharge of a dense plasma focus in pure neon are presented. The spectral-energy characteristics of x-ray emission were measured in the photon energy range of (0.5-5.0) keV with the help of thin absorber filters set and silicon semiconductor p-i-n detectors SPPD11-04. A study was made at the filling gas pressure PNe = (2.0-6.0) Torr and at the stored capacitor bank energy W = (15-21) kJ. High degree of monochromatization for the soft x-ray emission (approximately 90%) was obtained. According to the experimental data characteristic plasma electron temperature in the time duration of x-ray pulse τ1/2 = (10-100) ns has been estimated as Te to approximately (0.2-0.3) keV. The plasma parameters obtained are compared with the results of computer simulation of the emission process.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Photons; Plasma diagnostics; X ray spectroscopy; Plasma focus devices; Plasma devices

Authors: Lisowski L., Baille G.
Title: Specifications of a small electric vehicle: Modular and distributed approach
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems
Affiliations: INRIA Rhone-Alpes, Saint-Martin, France
Authors with affiliations: Lisowski, L., INRIA Rhone-Alpes, Saint-Martin, France; Baille, G., INRIA Rhone-Alpes, Saint-Martin, France
Abstract: In this paper we describe a small electric vehicle equipped with automatisms that allow autonomous motion. A fleet of such vehicles could be one element of a novel urban transportation system to door-to-door displacement in closed area (city centers but also touristic resorts, campuses, ...) if they are used in self-service and car-sharing mode. The specifications in the matter of performances (range, max speed, ...) or energy storage agree with this application within this kind of evolution space (several short trips at low speed). A stylish look and an original electro-mechanical structure with four steering and driving wheels was adopted. By the fact of its utilization opened to different users not having necessarily driving-license, the vehicle must be friendly, easy to handle and secure not only for the driver but also for the pedestrians walking in the same area (computer aided driving). The driver must be care-free of parking or batteries re-charging. The recent progresses of Electronics and Robotics allow to envisage that these maneuvers could run automatically without human intervention. We have designed a modular and distributed hardware architecture with intelligent components (actuators and sensors) linked together by a field bus. Several solutions for the implementing of our software control architecture are examined.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Computer architecture; Distributed computer systems; Electric vehicles; Modular robots; Navigation; Robot applications; Sensors; Computer aided driving; Intelligent vehicle highway systems

Authors: Savage M.E., Simpson W.W., Sharpe R.A., Reynolds F.D.
Title: Switch evaluation test system for the National Ignition Facility
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Savage, M.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Simpson, W.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Sharpe, R.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Reynolds, F.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Flashlamp pumped lasers use pulse power switches to commute energy stored in capacitor banks to the flashlamps. To lower the total cost of these switches, Sandia National Laboratories has a research program to evaluate large closing switches. The National Ignition Facility (NIF) is one of the applications of the program designed by Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Los Alamos National Laboratory, and Sandia National Laboratories. The target value of the energy switched by single devices is 1.6 MJ, from a 6 mF, 24 kV capacitor bank. The peak current is 500 ka. The lifetime of the NIF facility is 24 thousand shots. The goal of the experiment in Sandia is to test switches with the full NIF wave shape, and the correct voltage.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric charge; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Pulse shaping circuits; Pumping (laser); Resistors; Flashlamp pumped lasers; Pulsed power switches; Electric switches

Authors: Hall III Carsie A., Glakpe Emmanuel K., Cannon Joseph N., Kerslake Thomas W.
Title: Parametric analysis of cyclic phase change and energy storage in solar heat receivers
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Howard Univ, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hall III, Carsie A., Howard Univ, Washington, United States; Glakpe, Emmanuel K., Howard Univ, Washington, United States; Cannon, Joseph N., Howard Univ, Washington, United States; Kerslake, Thomas W., Howard Univ, Washington, United States
Abstract: A parametric study on cyclic melting and freezing of an encapsulated phase change material (PCM), integrated into a solar heat receiver, has been performed. The cyclic nature of the present melt/freeze problem is relevant to latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES) systems used to power solar Brayton engines in microgravity environments. Specifically, a physical and numerical model of the solar heat receiver component of NASA Lewis Research Center's Ground Test Demonstration (GTD) project was developed. Multi-conjugate effects such as the convective fluid flow of a low-Prandtl-number fluid, coupled with thermal conduction in the phase change material, containment tube and working fluid conduit were accounted for in the model. A single-band thermal radiation model was also included to quantify reradiative energy exchange inside the receiver and losses through the aperture. The eutectic LiF-CaF2 was used as the phase change material (PCM) and a mixture of He/Xe was used as the working fluid coolant. A modified version of the computer code HOTTube was used to generate results in the two-phase regime. Results indicate that parametric changes in receiver gas inlet temperature and receiver heat input effects higher sensitivity to changes in receiver gas exit temperatures.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Freezing; Heat losses; Heat radiation; Heat storage; Materials testing; Mathematical models; Melting; Thermal effects; Cyclic phase change; Software package HOTTube; Solar absorbers

Authors: Saksena Vikas, Montross Michael D., Maier Dirk E.
Title: Site specific NA/LT drying strategies for white food corn
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saksena, Vikas, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States; Montross, Michael D., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States; Maier, Dirk E., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States
Abstract: Eight different strategies of Natural Air/Low Temperature drying were simulated to determine the best `what if' strategy based on the results of an on-farm drying test with white corn during 1996-97. The strategies were ranked on the basis of energy consumption, least DML, shrink compared to the target moisture content of 14.5%, date when drying was completed, and best moisture uniformity of the grain mass. The top three ranked strategies were simulated using 29 years of weather data (1961-90) for Evansville, Indiana and reranked. Based on the parameters evaluated, low temperature drying with 2.8 °C of supplemental heat followed by SentryPAC storage appeared to be the best strategy when harvest took place in early November.
Index Keywords: Cracks; Energy utilization; Low temperature drying; Moisture; Stresses; Natural air drying; Grain (agricultural product)

Authors: Hoberecht Mark A., Green Robert D.
Title: Use of excess solar array power by regenerative fuel cell energy storage systems in low Earth orbit
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoberecht, Mark A., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States; Green, Robert D., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: The International Space Stations (ISS) application was chosen for evaluation and comparison of battery and regenerative fuel cells (RFC) energy storage systems. Combined altitude and orientation effects, seasonal variations, and beginning-of-life solar array performance were examined for individual orbits at and above specified reference points. Charging characteristics of the battery system were also investigated. The evaluation allowed a comparison of the solar array size required with the existing battery energy storage system to the projected solar array size required with a possible RFC system.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Electric energy storage; Fuel cells; Orbits; Secondary batteries; Solar cell arrays; Space stations; International space stations (ISS); Regenerative fuel cells (RFC); Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Khan Md.Mesbah-ul Ghani
Title: Sowing wind turbines for reaping the clean and competitive energy - a renewable free energy resource able to supplement energy needs of Bangladesh
Affiliations: Dhaka Electric Supply Authority, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Khan, Md.Mesbah-ul Ghani, Dhaka Electric Supply Authority, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: The implementation of wind power projects in Bangladesh utilizes methodologies for site selection; wind data collection and regime modeling; power availability, conversion and storage; turbine performance monitoring and augmenting wind speed using cloth scoops including costs and environmental impact assessment. Bangladesh geography, assessment of energy resources, strategies for meeting deficit demand and global wind development are discussed.
Index Keywords: Electricity; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Wind power; Global wind development; Wind turbines

Authors: Clemens Libby S., Callis C.L., Bednarz C.A., Garrett D.L., Boris G.F.
Title: DOE approach to removal of radioactively contaminated tank inventory
Source title: Hazardous and Industrial Wastes - Proceedings of the Mid-Atlantic Industrial Waste Conference
Affiliations: CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clemens, Libby S., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Callis, C.L., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Bednarz, C.A., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Garrett, D.L., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Boris, G.F., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: An innovative, cost-effective approach to remove radioactively contaminated sludge from underground storage tanks has been developed by the U.S. Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL). The approach combines a time-saving administrative approach to site cleanup with the demonstration of a technology proven in the mining industry. The `Borehole Miner' extendible nozzle system will be used to sluice the contents of five inactive underground tanks at the ORNL inactive waste disposal test site. The contents will then be pumped to the active on-site waste management system. The work is a non-time-critical removal action under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA).
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Environmental protection; Nozzles; Radioactive waste disposal; Sewage tanks; Sludge disposal; Steel tanks; Underground structures; Waste management; Industrial waste treatment

Authors: Sakai Takami, Kawaguchi Akira, Yonemoto Tsuyoshi
Title: SMES system with snubber loss free type current source converter
Affiliations: Toshiba Corp
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, Takami, Toshiba Corp; Kawaguchi, Akira, Toshiba Corp; Yonemoto, Tsuyoshi, Toshiba Corp
Abstract: Toshiba has developed a new type of Snubber Loss Free Current Source GTO Converter (CSC). Applying this type of GTO converter, Toshiba studied converter system for 30 MW-SMES system. Current Source Converter and Voltage Source Converter (VSC) with DC Chopper were compared from viewpoint of Cost, dimensions and loss. SMES system using CSC and its control model are simulated by EMTDC. Many advantages in Current Source Converter were found if it was applied for SIMES system, because the DC Power Source, Superconducting Magnet, is inherently a current source.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Superconducting magnets; Thyristors; Current source converters (CSC); Superconducting magnet energy storage systems (SMES); Voltage source converters (VSC); Power converters

Authors: Senior P., Hackett C.D., Novac B.M., Smith I.R.
Title: Switch characteristics for a high efficiency 20 kJ electromagnetic launcher
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Loughborough Univ, Loughborough, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Senior, P., Loughborough Univ, Loughborough, United Kingdom; Hackett, C.D., Loughborough Univ, Loughborough, United Kingdom; Novac, B.M., Loughborough Univ, Loughborough, United Kingdom; Smith, I.R., Loughborough Univ, Loughborough, United Kingdom
Abstract: During the development of a high-efficiency single-turn electromagnetic launcher, it became apparent that the main limiting feature was the closing switch used to connect the launcher coil to the charged capacitor forming the initial energy source. Both experimental and theoretical considerations established that, even by the time the projectile attained the terminal velocity, more than 30% of the initial capacitor energy had been absorbed in the simple and low cost nail switch that was being used. In an attempt to maximize the launcher efficiency, the characteristics of five different switch technologies were investigated. The initial capacitor voltage could be up to 30 kV and the launcher coil current peaked at up to 900 kA in about 1 μs, and in addition to the nail switch, those considered were triggered spark gaps, nail switches, surface switches, metal-to-metal detonator switches and solid dielectric switches.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric spark gaps; Electric switches; Detonator switches; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Denkmann James L.
Title: Inhibited glycols in piping distribution systems - some disasters that could have been easily prevented
Affiliations: Denkmann Thermal Storage Ltd, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Denkmann, James L., Denkmann Thermal Storage Ltd, Chicago, United States
Abstract: Use of an inhibited glycol (IG) as a freezing point depressant is common. Numerous chilled-water piping distribution systems, particularly in northern climates, use a small IG concentration to prevent rupture of chilled-water coils during winter months. Many ice-based thermal storage systems use higher IG concentrations as the primary heat transfer fluid for freezing water in the storage modules. When a system has been designed for inclusion of an IG fluid and all necessary precautions are taken, these systems perform at expected capacity and without difficulty. But there have been some rather notable disasters, all of which could have been prevented had proper precautions been taken. This paper will address several systems that are indicative of the first corollary of Murphy's Law, which states, 'the cost of the fix varies to the cube of the cost had the system been correctly built from the outset.'
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Heat transfer; Hot water heating; Installation; Piping systems; Inhibited glycol; Piping distribution systems; Thermal energy storage; Glycols

Authors: Sapru Krishna, Stetson Ned T., Ovshinsky Stanford R., Yang Jeffery, Fritz Greg, Fairlie Matthew, Stuart Andrew T.B.
Title: Development of a small scale hydrogen production-storage system for hydrogen applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sapru, Krishna, Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Stetson, Ned T., Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Ovshinsky, Stanford R., Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Yang, Jeffery, Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Fritz, Greg, Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Fairlie, Matthew, Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States; Stuart, Andrew T.B., Energy Conversion Devices, Inc, Troy, United States
Abstract: The successful introduction of hydrogen for transportation, consumer and military applications will require the simultaneous introduction of small scale hydrogen production-storage and distribution systems for central depot and residential use. These systems will have to be flexible, safe and economical. An integrated photovoltaic-electrolyzer-metal hydride system will meet these requirements. The system makes use of high efficiency, low cost amorphous silicon photovoltaic panels coupled to alkaline electrolysis cell stacks. The produced hydrogen is in turn stored as a metal hydride. The system can be scaled from a few watts to several kilowatts and installed in virtually any location. Metal hydride hydrogen storage is an inherently safe, low-pressure storage method. The system can be designed to be coupled directly to the application device or used to refill other storage containers. It will therefore be applicable to virtually all hydrogen applications such as fuel cells, combustion and chemical processes. The development of economical, small-scale hydrogen production-storage systems, especially utilizing renewable energy sources, will enable the successful introduction of hydrogen applications in the marketplace. This paper will address the conceptual design, integration and sizing of the system components.
Index Keywords: Amorphous silicon; Electrolysis; Fuel storage; Hydrides; Photovoltaic cells; Amorphous silicon photovoltaic panels; Hydrogen production storage system; Hydrogen fuels

Authors: Zahedi Ahmad
Title: Entirely renewable energy-based electricity supply system (small scale)
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Monash Univ, Caulfield
Authors with affiliations: Zahedi, Ahmad, Monash Univ, Caulfield
Abstract: This paper presents a system comprising of a renewable source of energy and an energy storage device to smooth the power fluctuations. In order to investigate the performance of the system, an exact mathematical model for the system has been developed. Because of non-linearity of the mathematical model a computational method is used for performance investigation of the system. The objective of the paper is to present an entirely renewable energy based electricity supply system (small scale), to suggest the mathematical model of the system and computational method to analyse the performance of the system.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Equivalent circuits; Mathematical models; Electricity supply system; Energy storage device; Solar energy

Authors: Saitoh Takeo S., Hoshina Hidehiro, Yamada Kenichi
Title: Theoretical analysis and experiment on combined close-contact and natural convection melting in thermal energy storage spherical capsule
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo S., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Hoshina, Hidehiro, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Yamada, Kenichi, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Melting and freezing of a phase change material (PCM) in a spherical capsule is of practical importance in heat storage systems which are considered very promising to reduce peak electricity demand in the summer season. Heat transfer with melting and freezing of PCM in a capsule is quite complicated because of two heat transfer modes occurring within a capsule, i.e. one is close-contact melting mode between PCM and capsule material, and another is natural convection heat transfer in melt pool under or above the solid PCM. Owing to this complicated nature, there has been reported no detailed analysis up to date. In comparison with the cylindrical capsule type unit, the spherical capsule unit has a great advantage from the viewpoint of the thermal performance and care of installation. In this article, we will present a mathematical formulation and the numerical results on the transient melting (charging) heat transfer in a spherical heat storage capsule under inner wall temperature distribution. In recent years, efforts have been devoted to clarify the mechanism of close-contact heat transfer for a single enclosure with various shapes. However, there is no theoretically exact numerical simulation considering both close-contact and natural convection melting processes within a spherical capsule. Three years ago, the world largest district heating and cooling (DHC) system was opened in Yokohama, near Tokyo, in which about six million spherical ice balls (diameter: 80mm) were installed in two vertical storage tanks with height of 28 meters. The results of the present analysis can be effectively applicable to the practical plant for a thermal design.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Mathematical models; Melting; Natural convection; Numerical analysis; Temperature distribution; Close contact melting; Natural convection melting; Thermal energy storage spherical capsule; Heat transfer

Authors: Reid Robert L., Hoeppner Bruce D.
Title: Five years of solar powered boat racing at Marquette University
Affiliations: Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reid, Robert L., Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States; Hoeppner, Bruce D., Marquette Univ, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: Marquette was the first university in the United States to build a solar powered racing boat in 1990-91 and has been participating in races since 1992. The first events for Marquette in 1992 were open competitions in Minneapolis, Seattle and Japan. These were the first competitions in the U.S. but races had been held in Japan since 1989. Mainly companies and inventors participated in the competitions with no other universities except for a few in Japan. The same situation existed in 1993. In 1994, initiated by Marquette through the Solar Energy Division of ASME, the world's first international intercollegiate solar boat regatta was held in Milwaukee, named Solar Splash and attracted ten universities from the U.S. and Japan. Solar Splash has been held annually in Milwaukee since 1994 with about sixteen universities now participating in the two-hour endurance races and the 300 m sprints. The rules for the maximum 6 m long boats allow for 480 watts of solar collectors and 1000 watt-hrs of battery storage such that in the two-hour endurance race, approximately 50 percent of the power is from solar directly and the other 50 percent from stored solar energy. Marquette also has continued to race in Japan every year since 1992 and has been the only team from outside of Japan to compete. These competitions have been an exciting interdisciplinary learning experience for the students at a cost much less than other prototype-size solar competitions.
Index Keywords: Boats; Energy storage; Solar energy; Solar powered boat racing; Engineering education

Authors: Bugby David C., Stouffer Charles J., Rich Michael
Title: Experimental verification of a 60 K thermal storage unit
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bugby, David C., Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States; Stouffer, Charles J., Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States; Rich, Michael, Swales Aerospace, Beltsville, United States
Abstract: To reduce the cooling power requirements and weight of space-based IR sensor systems with time varying focal plane loads, cryogenic thermal storage units (TSUs) with embedded phase change materials (PCMs) represent a viable solution. This paper describes the design and verification of a dual-volume 60 K TSU, which uses nitrogen trifluoride (NF3) as the working fluid. The dual-volume design divides the TSU into a cryogenic temperature heat exchanger volume and an ambient temperature storage volume. This approach increases TSU energy storage capacity and thermal stability while reducing total weight and volume. The TSU heat exchanger has a beryllium shell to ensure CTE compatibility with beryllium focal planes. The heat exchanger core is constructed of a 40 ppi, 6101 aluminum foam, compressed to 35% relative density. Developmental testing has shown that the aluminum foam core, which is vacuum furnace brazed to the beryllium end-caps, tends to suppress NF3 single-phase supercooling. Also, by virtue of its slight capillary wicking capability, the foam core eliminates concerns over heat exchanger filling in 0-g. The TSU will be tested on-orbit in a Hitchhiker GAS Canister flight experiment (designated as CRYOTSU) on the STS is late-1998. In this flight experiment, the TSU storage tank will be made of thin-walled stainless steel and the system will be pressurized to less than 100 psi to minimize safety concerns.
Index Keywords: Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Nitrogen compounds; Thermal expansion; Thermodynamic stability; Nitrogen trifluoride; Thermal storage unit (TSU); Cryogenic equipment

Authors: Reisner David E., Xiao T.Danny, Strutt Peter R., Salkind Alvin J.
Title: Nanostructured materials for energy storage and energy conversion devices
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reisner, David E., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States; Xiao, T.Danny, US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States; Strutt, Peter R., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States; Salkind, Alvin J., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States
Abstract: US Nanocorp, Inc. (USN) has developed an aqueous solution reaction (ASR) technique scalable for high volume production of nanostructured materials (n-materials) for a wide range of applications. By definition, nanophase materials have at least one physical dimension less than 10 nanometers (nm) in length, an attribute which imparts exceptional properties to them because the particle dimensions are close to atomic dimensions and there are a very high fraction of atoms residing at nanocrystalline grain boundaries. The high surface area of these materials has significant implications with respect to energy storage devices with electrochemical active sites (batteries, ultracapacitors) and energy conversion devices depending on catalytic sites or defect structure (e.g., fuel coils and thermoelectric devices). Potential application areas in both energy conversion and energy storage are discussed. Morphological studies of manganese dioxide have revealed the existence of both nanoporosity and mesoporosity within unusual superstructures comprised of nanorod building blocks. Nanophase nickel hydroxide has also been synthesized. Preliminary electrochemical studies are reported.
Index Keywords: Catalysis; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Grain boundaries; Grain size and shape; Manganese compounds; Morphology; Nickel compounds; Solutions; Synthesis (chemical); Aqueous solution reaction (ASR) techniques; Nanostructured materials

Authors: Haines J.E., Levins D., Robben A., Sepers A.
Title: Meteosat Second Generation (MSG) power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: European Space Technology Cent, (ESTeC), Noordwijk, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Haines, J.E., European Space Technology Cent, (ESTeC), Noordwijk, Netherlands; Levins, D., European Space Technology Cent, (ESTeC), Noordwijk, Netherlands; Robben, A., European Space Technology Cent, (ESTeC), Noordwijk, Netherlands; Sepers, A., European Space Technology Cent, (ESTeC), Noordwijk, Netherlands
Abstract: Under the direction of the European Meteorological Satellite Organization (EUMETSAT) and the European Space Agency (ESA), space industries within Europe are in the process of developing a new series of larger and more performant geostationary weather satellites. The initial three spacecraft within this new series, which are known by the name of Meteosat Second Generation (MSG), are due to be progressively launched as from the year 2000 onwards. The major objective of this mission is the continuation of the European weather watch and space borne atmospheric sensing services provided by the present series of Meteosat spacecraft. To satisfy this mission requirement, the payload compliment to be supported by MSG will be consist of a comprehensive earth viewing instrument capable of operating in both the infra-red and visible spectrum, an earth radiation measurement system and a search and rescue facility. In furnishing the power needs for these payloads, the power generating element on the spin stabilized MSG spacecraft consists of a body mounted solar array, capable of providing 628 watts of electrical power at the end of seven years of geosynchronous orbital lifetime. The energy storage elements for the spacecraft consists of two, 29 ampere-hour batteries, whilst centralized power management is achieved by the Power Control Unit (PCU), which satisfies the payload and battery re-charge demands by controlling the available solar array power. Power distribution for the spacecraft electrical loads and heaters is achieved by the Power Distribution Unit (PDU) and for the pyrotechnic devices by the Pyrotechnic Release Unit.
Index Keywords: Dosimetry; Geostationary satellites; Infrared radiation; Power control; Solar cell arrays; Weather satellites; Power distribution; Electric power systems

Authors: Taylor G.A., Burden A.B.
Title: Wide area power quality - decision processes and options for sensitive users
Affiliations: Reyrolle Projects Ltd (Rolls-Royce, Industrial Power Group), United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, G.A., Reyrolle Projects Ltd (Rolls-Royce, Industrial Power Group), United Kingdom; Burden, A.B., Reyrolle Projects Ltd (Rolls-Royce, Industrial Power Group), United Kingdom
Abstract: Modern production equipment increasingly need some form of external protection to prevent damage or shut-down during supply disturbances. A power quality survey suggests voltage dips to be the prime cause of supply related downtime. Various solution options are presented including non- or partial plant operation, uninterruptible power supplies, cogeneration, electric energy storage, solid state transfer switches, dynamic voltage restorers, and distribution statcoms. For large users, wide area protection of supplies that, in particular, decrease sensitivity to voltage dips provides the simplest solution, while providing minimum impact on surrounding distribution networks.
Index Keywords: Cost accounting; Decision making; Electric energy storage; Electric power distribution; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Electric utilities; Voltage regulators; Distribution statcoms; Dynamic voltage restorers; Solid state transfer switches; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Wide area power quality; Electric equipment protection

Authors: Esteban P., Bautista A., Gutierrez-Iglesias J.L., Rodriguez J.M., Urretavizcaya E.
Title: SMES systems applications to improve quality service
Affiliations: ASINEL, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Esteban, P., ASINEL, Spain; Bautista, A., ASINEL, Spain; Gutierrez-Iglesias, J.L., ASINEL, Spain; Rodriguez, J.M., ASINEL, Spain; Urretavizcaya, E., ASINEL, Spain
Abstract: This article presents the contribution of SMES (Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage) systems to improvement quality of service, either as a mitigating element or as a power support for critical loads. It also describes these systems and its operation. Finally, a description is shown of the state of the art of this technology in Spain, as developed until now in the AMAS500 project.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric utilities; Superconducting magnets; Quality of service (QoS); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems; Electric energy storage

Authors: Kumar Ratan, Slayton Simeon
Title: Construction of a solar collector for domestic usage
Affiliations: Univ of North Texas, Denton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Ratan, Univ of North Texas, Denton, United States; Slayton, Simeon, Univ of North Texas, Denton, United States
Abstract: The following paper discusses the design of a solar collector that can be used for domestic purposes. The goal is to build a long life, low maintenance, economically feasible solar collector that can be manufactured from off-the-shelf products requiring little fabrication. This collector will be used as part of a residential heating system. The basic system consists of a parabolic reflector that focuses the heat from the sun onto a black pipe with water circulating in it. The water is stored in an insulated tank. When space heating is required, this same water is circulated through a radiator in the air handler of the conventional heating system. Air circulates through the radiator and warms the living space. The issues that are addressed are the design of the parabolic reflector, availability of solar energy, storage of the heated water, usage of the heated water, building construction, climate, load factor, and the return on investment.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Space heating; Residential heating system; Engineering education

Authors: Christopher David A., Beach Raymond F., Barton John R.
Title: Flywheel energy storage system test on the international space station
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Christopher, David A., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Beach, Raymond F., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Barton, John R., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: A test program was initiated to develop and demonstrate a flywheel energy storage device on the International Space Station (ISS) as a flight experiment. The long-term goal was to upgrade the energy storage capability of ISS by replacing degraded batteries with flywheel energy storage units. The demonstration units will be placed on ISS in early 2000.
Index Keywords: Design; Electric batteries; Electric charge; Electric discharges; Electric losses; Energy storage; Space flight; Space stations; Technology; Depth of discharge; Flywheel energy storage demonstrate unit; International space station; Flywheels

Authors: Khouzam Kame
Title: Prospect of domestic grid connected PV systems under existing tariff conditions
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Queensland Univ of Technology, Brisbane
Authors with affiliations: Khouzam, Kame, Queensland Univ of Technology, Brisbane
Abstract: The abundance of natural fossil fuel resources in Australia adds a new dimension to the obstacles to be overcome when introducing photovoltaics (PV) into the electric utility market. Regulations are been considered to enforce a form of penalty unto non-environmentally friendly energy producers. Electric utilities are required to offer a purchase tariff and structure to private producers of electricity. Under the current conditions, it is technically feasible to introduce small-scale roof-top PV generation systems with or without battery storage. Economic analysis have shown that the electricity tariff structure for PV and other renewables needed a major change to allow a reasonable and acceptable pay-back period if PV is to become an attractive economic investment to private owners.
Index Keywords: Electric rates; Electric utilities; Photovoltaic cells; Solar power generation; Electricity tariff; Solar cells

Authors: Brylevsky V.I., Kardo-Sysoev A.F., Lelikov Y.S., Smirnova I.A., Tchashnikov I.G., Karavaev V.V.
Title: Fast power thyristors
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Brylevsky, V.I., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kardo-Sysoev, A.F., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Lelikov, Y.S., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Smirnova, I.A., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Tchashnikov, I.G., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Karavaev, V.V., Acad of Science, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Properties of two types of fast pulse power thyristors are presented. The first type, high current thyristors (HCT), have been designed for switching on pulse current from 500 A to 6000 A. The second type, middle current thyristors (MCT) have been designed for switching on pulse currents from 100 amperes to 1000 amperes. Operating voltage for both types of thyristors can be as high as 1800 V. Presented thyristors have reverse conductivity and have been designed for short pulse application (submicrosecond range of pulse duration). Their physics has been described in. Thyristor testings have been made in low inductance LSCSRL circuits with active loads (RL). The following parameters have been registered: current rise time (at 0.1-0.9 levels), maximum pulse current, delay time and voltage. Pulse power and energy losses have been calculated by using current-time and voltage-time transient curves. It has been shown, that there is a range of currents in which current rise time is nearly constant and switching efficiency is high enough for both types of thyristors.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Current voltage characteristics; Electric conductivity of solids; Oscillographs; Power electronics; Semiconductor device testing; High current thyristors (HCT); Middle current thyristors (MCT); Thyristors

Authors: Alferov D.F., Ivanov V.P., Sidorov V.A.
Title: High current vacuum switching devices for pulsed power technologies
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: All-Russian Electrotechnical Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Alferov, D.F., All-Russian Electrotechnical Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ivanov, V.P., All-Russian Electrotechnical Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Sidorov, V.A., All-Russian Electrotechnical Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Lasting many years of experience at the All-Russian Electrotechnical Institute (VEI) with design of vacuum interrupters and AC vacuum circuit-breakers was used successfully for the design of triggered vacuum switches (TVS) and DC vacuum circuit-breakers. The application of sealed-off TVS for fast reliable and reliable commutations of high voltage energy storage and power networks is presented. Experiments using DC vacuum circuit breakers for commutation of currents 10-50 kA with voltage level which corresponds to switching power about 109 W. With increase of energy accumulated in inductive storages, it is possible to design new generation of DC circuit breakers with huge switching power of order 10-100 GW.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Circuit breaking arcs; Electric charge; Electric commutation; Electric commutators; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electrodes; Trigger circuits; Vacuum technology; Alternating/direct current vacuum circuit breakers; Triggered vacuum switches (TVS); Vacuum interrupters; Electric circuit breakers

Authors: Kirk James A., Walsh Gregory C., Hromada Lou P., Zmood Ronald B., Sullivan Gary E.
Title: Open core composite flywheel
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Walsh, Gregory C., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Hromada, Lou P., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Zmood, Ronald B., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Sullivan, Gary E., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: In low-earth orbit satellite applications, spacecraft power is provided by photovoltaic cells and batteries. Unfortunately, use of batteries present difficulties due to their poor energy density, limited cycle lifetimes, reliability problems, and the uncertainty in measuring the state of charge. Flywheel energy storage offers a viable alternative to overcome some of the limitations presented by batteries. This paper discusses the University of Maryland's operational 300 Wh open core composite flywheel, called the Engineering Development Unit, and the research being conducted to enhance its performance. Current research in this area focuses on the control system, the touchdown surface material, and the magnetic bearing actuator. FARE, Inc. has designed a state-of-the-art 50 Wh flywheel energy storage system. This system, called the Open Core Rotator, is based on the Engineering Development Unit and will incorporate some of the innovative features of the University of Maryland system as well as those under development by its subcontractors. The OCR is intended to be a prototype energy storage device for low-earth orbit satellite applications.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Control systems; Energy storage; Magnetic bearings; Satellites; Space applications; Spacecraft; Low earth orbit satellite; Magnetic bearing actuator; Open core composite flywheel; Touchdown surface material; Flywheels

Authors: Volkov Gennadiy K., Lyagushin Sergey F., Polyakova Lyubov P., Pryakhin Gennadiy N., Statsenko Ivan N.
Title: Power pond
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Volkov, Gennadiy K., Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine; Lyagushin, Sergey F., Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine; Polyakova, Lyubov P., Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine; Pryakhin, Gennadiy N., Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine; Statsenko, Ivan N., Dniepropetrovsk State Univ, Dniepropetrovsk, Ukraine
Abstract: A solar power system for simultaneous production of heat and electric energy is proposed. Electric and thermal generating module is a main unit of the system. Solar cells with concentrators cooled with water is a power source. Placing the modules on the pond surface provide some advantages in the system operation. Heat is stored inside the pond equipped with a barbotage appliance.
Index Keywords: Cooling water; Electric power generation; Heat storage; Solar cells; Solar concentrators; Solar energy; Barbotage appliance; Electric generating module; Thermal generating module; Solar power generation

Authors: Burgan Launce L.
Title: Micro superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) technology insertion program
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United States Air Force, McClellan AFB, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burgan, Launce L., United States Air Force, McClellan AFB, United States
Abstract: In September 1993, the United States Air Force (USAF) initiated an aggressive 3 year program to field and evaluate five Micro SMES devices at selected federal government sites. The sites were: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York; Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA) Megacenter, Tinker AFB, Oklahoma; Wright Laboratory Air Base Technology Branch, Tyndall AFB, Florida; and Buildings 618/620, McClellan AFB, California. This program brought together government agencies, commercial industry, university scholars, and government customers worldwide to identify cost effective military and commercial applications in power quality. Data collected has resulted in new applications and significant system improvements, while encouraging the entry of a second vendor into the industry. Although the project was scheduled to end September 1996, a program extension of one year has been requested. The unit developed by the second source vendor has not been fielded, and a second DC unit is scheduled for delivery mid 1997. The project cannot be considered complete until the preceding actions occur and results are evaluated.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Data acquisition; Data reduction; Electric power generation; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric energy storage

Authors: May G.J., Lenain P.
Title: Batteries for solar photovoltaic applications in telecommunications service
Affiliations: Hawker Batteries Group, Leics, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: May, G.J., Hawker Batteries Group, Leics, United Kingdom; Lenain, P., Hawker Batteries Group, Leics, United Kingdom
Abstract: OLDHAM FRANCE first developed lead/acid batteries for renewable energy sources in 1977 and today thousands of solar installations all over the world are equipped with our specialized storage batteries. This paper describes the criteria which allow the system designer or the user to choose a battery suitable for particular applications. We must differentiate the batteries for renewable energy sources and identify what makes them different from existing starter, traction and standby batteries. We must also be aware of the selection criteria such as storage conditions, climatic, environment, operating endurance (cycling, overcharge, water consumption, maintenance). A discussion regarding the conditions of commissioning, recharging and charging voltage control as well as the regulations to be followed for control on site will complete this paper. At the early stages of development of renewable energy sources in 1977, OLDHAM FRANCE was one of the first companies to supply batteries especially adapted for this type of application and provided specifications for batteries used for photovoltaic systems, wind power and other primary energy generators for renewable power sources. Twenty years later, in 1997 thousands of solar power installations in many parts of the world are equipped with lead/acid batteries developed for this particular duty cycle providing the reliability they have come to expect from the market leader.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Photovoltaic cells; Secondary batteries; Solar energy; Telecommunication services; Voltage control; Wind power; Lead/acid batteries; Solar cells

Authors: Caldwell D.B., Fox C.L.
Title: Advanced developments in NiH2 dependent pressure vessel (DPV) cell and battery technology
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Technologies Div., Eagle-Picher Ind., Inc., P.O. Box 47, Joplin, MO 64802, United States; US Naval Academy, United States; McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, United States; Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc., United States; Power Subsystems Department, United States; EPI's Advanced Systems Operation; Technologies Division
Authors with affiliations: Caldwell, D.B., Technologies Div., Eagle-Picher Ind., Inc., P.O.
