Authors with affiliations: Marongiu, Maurice J., MJM Engineering Co, Naperville, United States; Clarksean, Randy, MJM Engineering Co, Naperville, United States
Abstract: Phase-Changing Materials (PCM) heat exchangers are being designed that will actively store energy during high load periods and release it during low load periods. These heat exchangers are to be made of an aluminum tube bundles in which encapsulated PCM materials are included. Preliminary results indicate favorably that PCM heat exchangers work relatively well in maintaining target temperatures. Furthermore, flow and heat transfer characteristics appear to be well predicted by the modeling of the heat exchangers.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Design; Electronic equipment; Enclosures; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Heating; Electronics enclosures; Phase change materials; Thermal energy; Thermal energy storage systems; Thermal management; Energy management

Authors: Morash Richard T.
Title: Application of written-pole motors and generators with integrated flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: Written-Pole is a method of changing the magnetic field in motors and generators while the machines are operating. Written-pole motors starts across-the-line with very low starting current and can readily accelerate inertial loads 50 times greater than conventional motors can start. Written-pole motors operate at synchronous speed at unity power factor and with high efficiency.
Index Keywords: Electric generators; Electric motors; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Flywheels; Magnetic fields; Technology; Flywheel energy rides; Uninterruptible power supply systems; Written pole generator; Written pole motors; Electric machinery

Authors: Anantha A.
Title: Solar photovoltaic as an energy source for India
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rural Electrification Corp Ltd, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Anantha, A., Rural Electrification Corp Ltd, New Delhi, India
Abstract: Solar photovoltaic based power and energy systems is gaining recognition due to the availability and high solar insolation in most parts of India and its inherent advantage of direct conversion to power unlike a solar thermal system. Solar Photovoltaic technology, its application in the remote areas, its advantage as a stand alone system, environment friendly and inexhaustible source are some of the positive features of this wonderful source of nature. However, the limitations of day and night cycle and high costs in comparison to other sources of energy apply partial brakes on its ready acceptance. More and more research is called for in the area of solar photovoltaics along with discovery of alternative materials with higher efficiency of conversion, reduced panel areas per kW and effective, economic and durable storage systems for sustained production of power. This source alone, if costs can be reduced substantially, can meet the entire requirement of the country. Solar photovoltaics can also be utilised for bulk power for grid interconnected applications. It has a good scope for utilisation on the hybrid system, for pumping of drinking water and remote area power systems. This paper discusses all the features of the solar photovoltaic system, its cost comparison with other sources, its merits and demerits as of now, Government policy support, R&D efforts in India and strategies for commercialisation.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Electric power generation; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Energy storage; Research and development management; Electrification; India; Solar cells

Authors: Ghali Fadia M.A., Abd El Aziz M.M., Syam Fathy A.
Title: Simulation and analysis of hybrid systems using probabilistic techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference - Nagaoka, PCC
Affiliations: Electronics Research Inst, Dokki, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Ghali, Fadia M.A., Electronics Research Inst, Dokki, Egypt; Abd El Aziz, M.M., Electronics Research Inst, Dokki, Egypt; Syam, Fathy A., Electronics Research Inst, Dokki, Egypt
Abstract: In this paper, a PV/Wind hybrid autonomous system with a battery bank as a storage subsystem is optimally designed to supply pre-specified load. The implemented design criteria is the Loss of Power Supply Probability (LPSP). For selected locations, long term data of wind speed and irradiance recorded for every hour of the day are deduced to produce the probability density function of combined generation. For considered load distribution, the probability density function of the storage is obtained and consequently The battery size is calculated to give the relevant level of the system reliability using the LPSP technique. Different combinations of PV / Wind system are tested, for each the optimum size of storage facility is determined.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy conversion; Mathematical models; Probability density function; Secondary batteries; Integrated renewable energy system; Power supply probability technique; Wind energy conversion system; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Oka M.
Title: Direct contact melting process on a spherical heating wall with an arbitrary temperature distribution
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Panda Lab., 1642-406 Nagae, Hayama, Kanagawa, 240-01-0113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oka, M., Panda Lab., 1642-406 Nagae, Hayama, Kanagawa, 240-01-0113, Japan
Abstract: Direct contact melting process takes place in a lot of technological processes. One of the important applications is in the thermal storage system. In this system, phase change material is stored in small spherical capsules. Diameter of the capsule is about 4 inches. Millions of capsules are packed in a thermal storage tank. Capsules are heated and cooled through brine. Direct contact takes place in the melting process of the thermal storage system. In this system, latent heat energy is used effectively. This paper presents a theoretical study of the direct contact melting process on a spherical heating wall that has arbitrary temperature distribution. Governing system of equations with heat convection terms is solved analytically. It is shown that it can be transformed into ordinary differential equations system by a similarity transformation. Temperature is solved using perturbation method. This solution is valid for almost all practical Stefan number. Analytical solution is obtained for a typical temperature distribution. It is shown that melting rate is enhanced by more than 10% by the effect of temperature distribution.
Index Keywords: Differential equations; Heat convection; Perturbation techniques; Temperature distribution; Thermal effects; Spherical heating wall; Stefan number; Melting

Authors: Clemens Libby S., Callis C.L., Womble F.B., Bednarz C.A., Garrett D.L., Boris G.F.
Title: OHF tank riser installation
Source title: Hazardous and Industrial Wastes - Proceedings of the Mid-Atlantic Industrial Waste Conference
Affiliations: CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clemens, Libby S., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Callis, C.L., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Womble, F.B., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Bednarz, C.A., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Garrett, D.L., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States; Boris, G.F., CDM Federal Programs Corp, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has installed new access risers on five inactive underground storage tanks that are partially filled with mixed and transuranic waste. Installation of new risers was necessary to provide access for sluicing system that will be used to remove the waste inventory from the tanks, at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) in Oak Ridge, Tennessee. The tanks are part of the Old Hydrofracture Facility (OHF), an inactive waste disposal test site. The total waste inventory for the five tanks exceeds 42,000 gal and is divided between a supernatant phase and a layer of sludge that has settled to the bottom of the tanks.
Index Keywords: Materials handling equipment; Sewage settling tanks; Transuranium elements; Underground structures; Tank risers; Waste inventory; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Wienhold Paul D., Wozniak John J.
Title: Application of SCRIMP VARTM fabrication technology to the compressed natural gas integrated storage system
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins Univ Applied Physics, Lab, Laurel, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wienhold, Paul D., Johns Hopkins Univ Applied Physics, Lab, Laurel, United States; Wozniak, John J., Johns Hopkins Univ Applied Physics, Lab, Laurel, United States
Abstract: A low-cost composite structure was developed for The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory's Advanced Natural Gas Vehicle Integrated Storage System as part of a multiyear project funded by the Department of Energy to advance the technology of light-duty, natural gas powered vehicles. The Integrated Storage System structure consists of two mating shells that, when assembled, contain three high-pressure filament-wound cylinders (or pressure cells) for carrying compressed natural gas. A removable valve cover attaches to the assembly to protect the associated gas plumbing. The Seemann Composites Resin Infusion Molding Process (SCRIMP) vacuum assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM) was selected for fabrication of the shell and protective cover. This paper describes the major design details, evaluation and selection of materials, process development, tooling, fabrication methods, test results, and lessons learned.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Light weight vehicles; Natural gas; Vacuum applications; Valves (mechanical); Seemann composites resin infusion molding process (SCRIMP); Vacuum assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM); Transfer molding

Authors: Butler Paul C., Crow J.Terry, Taylor Paula A.
Title: Battery evaluation methods and results for stationary applications
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Butler, Paul C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Crow, J.Terry, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Taylor, Paula A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Evaluation of flooded lead-acid, Valve Regulated Lead-Acid (VRLA), and advanced batteries is being performed in the power sources testing labs at Sandia National Laboratories (SNL). These independent, objective tests using computer-controlled testers capable of simulating application-specific test regimes provide critical data for the assessment of the status of these technologies. Several different charge/discharge cycling regimes are performed. Constant current and constant power discharge tests are conducted to verify capacity and measure degradation. A utility test is imposed on some units which consists of partial depths of discharge (pulsed constant power) cycles simulating a frequency regulation operating mode, with a periodic complete discharge simulating a spinning reserve test. This test profile was developed and scaled based on operating information from the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) 20 MW battery energy storage system. Another test conducted at SNL is a photovoltaic battery life cycle test, which is a partial depth of discharge test (constant current) with infrequent complete recharges that simulates the operation of renewable energy systems. This test profile provides renewable system designers with critical battery performance data representative of field conditions. This paper will describe the results of these tests to date, and include analysis and conclusions.
Index Keywords: Computer control; Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Battery energy storage systems; Frequency regulation operating mode; Valve regulated lead acid (VRLA) battery; Secondary batteries

Authors: Russo L., Morana G., Ceraolo M., Pelacchi P.
Title: Distribution power quality improvements using DC links with battery storage in existing networks
Affiliations: Univ of Palermo, Palermo, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Russo, L., Univ of Palermo, Palermo, Italy; Morana, G., Univ of Palermo, Palermo, Italy; Ceraolo, M., Univ of Palermo, Palermo, Italy; Pelacchi, P., Univ of Palermo, Palermo, Italy
Abstract: The use of DC links with battery storage in low-voltage distribution networks provides several advantages for both the final user and the utility. In particular, with the use of DC links between the low-voltage windings of the distribution transformers and the load, the following advantages can be obtained: improvement of the power quality of the energy supplied to the user, in particular because the DC link with battery storage can eliminate short voltage interruptions and dips of up to a few minutes; and possibility of using for the DC line a higher voltage level than those presently used for the AC ones, thus increasing the link power carrying capability. These features are very important in urban areas, where the installation of new cables is costly (and sometimes very difficult to realize), and the request for power quality is ever increasing due to the growth in the number of electronic appliances. In this paper several possible alternatives for realizing such a DC link are presented, and their feasibility is shown, both in terms of normal and faulty operation and of reliability. Some economic considerations are also dealt with, with particular attention given to a case-study.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric loads; Electric utilities; Industrial economics; Transformer windings; Direct current links; Low voltage distribution networks; Electric power distribution

Authors: Hardan F., Bleijs J.A.M., Bromley P., Jones R., Ruddell A.J.
Title: Fast-response bi-directional power electronic converter for a flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hardan, F., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Bleijs, J.A.M., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Bromley, P., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Jones, R., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Ruddell, A.J., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Abstract: In weak grid-connected and autonomous power systems, supplied from wind turbine generators (WTGs), there is a need for short-term storage as the wind speed fluctuates rapidly and consumer loads are unpredictable. The work presented in this paper is part of an EC JOULE funded project in which the University of Leicester, CEGELEC Industrial Controls Ltd. and Rutherford Appleton Laboratory (RAL) are working in close collaboration to develop a 45 kW flywheel energy storage system using an induction machine (IM) vector-controlled drive. The key factors in selecting such a drive, which will operate in conjunction with a WTG of similar rating, is given with a brief description of the drive's features and functionality. It is shown that a fast power response, adequate for smoothing the WTG power, can be achieved. Simulation results, demonstrating the performances of active and reactive power controls, obtained from the vector-controlled flywheel drive, are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: Asynchronous machinery; Computer aided analysis; Computer simulation; Electric drives; Electric energy storage; Flywheels; Power control; Reactive power; Turbogenerators; Wind power; Wind turbine generators (WTG); Electric converters

Authors: Schenk Kurt, Cuk Slobodan
Title: Small signal analysis and design of a single active switch converter providing power factor correction and full regulation
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schenk, Kurt, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Cuk, Slobodan, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: A new mode of operation of a SEPIC-type power factor corrector was recently analyzed and presented. Compared with the previously known mode it reduces the harmonic distortion by a factor of about 10. In addition, the applied control method provides a well regulated output voltage at no extra cost. Furthermore, the voltage in the energy storage capacitor is no longer load dependent. This improvement is achieved by means of a fast output feedback loop. It is essential to know the small signal behavior of the power cell in order to optimize the control loop. In this paper the small signal equations are derived for two different control modes. As a byproduct, an efficient way of using state space averaging for discontinuous conduction mode is developed. This is particularly useful for circuits with more than one discontinuous state. The paper also includes measurements to confirm the validity of the analysis.
Index Keywords: Electric power factor correction; Feedback; Optimization; State space methods; Voltage control; Single active switch converters; Power converters

Authors: Machin Nigel, Dekter Jurie
Title: New lossless clamp for single ended converters
Affiliations: Rectifier Technologies Pacific, Burwood
Authors with affiliations: Machin, Nigel, Rectifier Technologies Pacific, Burwood; Dekter, Jurie, Rectifier Technologies Pacific, Burwood
Abstract: A clamp for single ended converters is proposed which returns energy stored in the leakage inductance of the transformer to the supply. The clamp allows minimal voltage overshoot on the switch, without employing an additional switch. The well clamped converter allows the use of lower voltage switching devices, and improves reliability of the converter.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Reliability; Transformer windings; Leakage inductance; Power clamp windings; Power converters

Authors: Smith Craig
Title: DC generators for reserve power markets, economics, and technical advantages
Affiliations: Lucent Technologies, Mesquite, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Craig, Lucent Technologies, Mesquite, United States
Abstract: The paper focuses on the leading telecommunications markets for DC generators, and the economic and technical factors leading to the DC generator decision in each. DC generation is contrasted against other energy reserve schemes, both pro and con. Short and long term implications of using DC generators are also discussed. Some possible areas for future deployment are presented, with an economic case for each use category. Thermal management, packaging, fuel selection, fuel storage and redundancy, and fuel system design considerations will all be covered. Future technical directions for DC generator development will be highlighted, and the yet-unsolved technical roadblocks will be identified.
Index Keywords: Fuel storage; Industrial economics; Marketing; Packaging; Thermal management; Electric generators

Authors: Amjadi H., Sessler G.M.
Title: Charge storage in APCVD silicon nitride
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Amjadi, H., Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Sessler, G.M., Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Silicon nitride is widely used as a dielectric in semiconductor devices or as membrane material in micromachined sensors and actuators. In this paper, preliminary results on investigations of silicon nitride as an electret material are presented. 300 nm layers of Si3N4 were prepared by chemical vapor deposition at atmospheric pressure (APCVD) on silicon wafers of 5 cm diameter at 900 °C. The samples were charged positively and negatively by a point to grid corona apparatus. A charge density of up to ±1 μC/cm2, depending on the charging polarity, could be achieved. The charge stability was observed by isothermal charge decay at room temperature and at 300 °C. Open circuit TSC measurements after different charging steps were carried out and show discharge current peaks at temperatures around 410 °C for negatively charged samples.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric pressure; Chemical vapor deposition; Electrets; Electric energy storage; High temperature operations; Silicon wafers; Charge density; Isothermal charge decay; Silicon nitride

Authors: Kambe Arihi, Kurokawa Manabu, Chibani Ali, Nakaoka Mutsuo
Title: Novel resonant DC link circuit with two level PWM control scheme and its application to three-phase voltage-fed converter operating at new pulse vector modulation
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference - Nagaoka, PCC
Affiliations: Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kambe, Arihi, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Kurokawa, Manabu, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Chibani, Ali, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, Mutsuo, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a novel prototype of resonant DC link with two level PWM control scheme and a three-phase voltage-fed PWM inverter with this resonant DC link. This resonant DC link circuit capable of controlling two level PWM modes; a clamped supply voltage PWM and zero voltage PWM modes in DC bus line can operate under the principle of zero voltage and zero current soft-switching. The operating analysis is carried out and design procedure of this resonant DC link is described on the basis of simulation results. Three-phase voltage-fed inverter and converter using this unique resonant DC link are analyzed which operate at a new pulse vector modulation scheme and their performances for utility-interactive power processor for Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) are evaluated and discussed including reactive current compensator and active power falter using this resonant DC link.
Index Keywords: Active filters; Charging (batteries); Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric network topology; Pulse width modulation; Resonant circuits; Battery energy storage system (BESS); Pulse vector modulation; Resonant direct current (DC) link circuit; Electric inverters

Authors: Koch Bill
Title: Challenging battery storage for ride-through of power interruptions
Authors with affiliations: Koch, Bill
Abstract: Battery-based uninterruptible power supplies are the ultimate power-quality solution. However, they may be an unneeded expense for the vast majority of end users who find that voltage sags, rather than blackouts are the major power-equality problem. This is the reason why flywheel energy storage are again showing promise for customers that need to ride through voltage sags lasting from half a cycle to a few seconds. Vendors now offer several approaches to flywheel energy storage.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy storage; Process control; Queueing theory; Rotors; Technology; Active power; Continuous power supply; Induction coupling; International computer power; Power conditioner; Uninterruptible power supply; Voltage sag; Flywheels

Authors: Buckingham Gary A., Corey Garth P.
Title: Datalogging and control through a remote interface for a power quality system
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buckingham, Gary A., U.S. Dep of Energy, Albuquerque, United States; Corey, Garth P., U.S. Dep of Energy, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: The vast majority of all utility power quality problems consist of short duration surges, sags, and momentary power losses that wreak havoc among modern sensitive loads. To solve these power quality problems, a highly reliable, low-cost battery solution, the AC Battery PQ2000, developed with Department of Energy and Sandia National Laboratories assistance, is now available to eliminate these short duration power quality problems. Incorporated in this system is a communications interface which allows remote access over the telephone network using RS-232 protocol. The system is designed for standalone function without an operator present; however, because of the limited experience of utilities in the use of this type of battery energy storage system, capabilities have been incorporated to allow for datalogging and remote system control of the unit. This paper reviews power quality problems, outlines the system design philosophy from AC Battery Corporation, discusses the rationale for remote telemetering system design, and reviews the utility of this telemetry through the experience of a system installed in Georgia.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric power systems; Electric surges; Interfaces (computer); Network protocols; Remote control; Power quality systems; Telemetering

Authors: Kin Johnson, Gupta Munish, Mangione-Smith William H.
Title: Filter cache: An energy efficient memory structure
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual International Symposium on Microarchitecture
Affiliations: UCLA Electrical Engineering, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kin, Johnson, UCLA Electrical Engineering, Los Angeles, United States; Gupta, Munish, UCLA Electrical Engineering, Los Angeles, United States; Mangione-Smith, William H., UCLA Electrical Engineering, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: Most modern microprocessors employ one or two levels of on-chip caches in order to improve performance. These caches are typically implemented with static RAM cells and often occupy a large portion of the chip area. Not surprisingly, these caches often consume a significant amount of power. In many applications, such as portable devices, low power is more important than performance. We propose to trade performance for power consumption by filtering cache references through an unusually small L1 cache. An L2 cache, which is similar in size and structure to a typical L1 cache, is positioned behind the filter cache and serves to reduce the performance loss. Experimental results across a wide range of embedded applications show that the filter cache results in improved memory system energy efficiency. For example, a direct mapped 256-byte filter cache achieves a 58% power reduction while reducing performance by 21%, corresponding to a 51% reduction in the energy-delay product over a conventional design.
Index Keywords: Filter caches; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Microprocessor chips; Random access storage; Buffer storage

Authors: Schillig Josef B., Boenig Heinrich J., Ferner James A., Quissek Manfred K., Bogdan Ferenc, Linhofer Gerhard O., Eichler Markus, Kasper Gerhard, Marek Richard P., Martin Jeffrey R.
Title: Design and testing of a 320 MW pulsed power supply
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schillig, Josef B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Boenig, Heinrich J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Ferner, James A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Quissek, Manfred K., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bogdan, Ferenc, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Linhofer, Gerhard O., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Eichler, Markus, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Kasper, Gerhard, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Marek, Richard P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Martin, Jeffrey R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: For a 60 Tesla, 100 millisecond long pulse magnet five 64 MW (87.6 MVA) power converter modules have been installed. Each module provides a no-load voltage of 4.18 kV and a full load voltage of 3.20 k V at the rated current of 20 kA. The modules are connected to a 1430 MVA/650 MJ inertial energy storage generator set, which is operated at 21 kV and frequencies between 60 and 42 Hz. They are designed to provide the rated power output for 2 seconds once every hour. Each module consists of two 21 kV/3.1 kV cast coil transformers and two 6-pulse rectifiers connected in parallel without an interphase reactor, forming a 12-pulse converter module. As far as possible standard high power industrial converter components were used, operated closer to their allowable limits. The converters are controlled by three programmable high speed controllers. In this paper the design of the pulsed converters, including control and special considerations for protection schemes with the converters supplying a mutually coupled magnet system, is detailed. Test results of the converters driving an ohmic-inductive load for 2 seconds at 20 kA and 3.2 kV are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric equipment protection; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric transformers; Programmable logic controllers; Pulsed power converters; Power converters

Authors: Kim Hyosung, Choi Jaeho
Title: Design concept of DC filters for magnet power supplies
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference - Nagaoka, PCC
Affiliations: Cheonan Natl Technical Coll, Chungnam, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyosung, Cheonan Natl Technical Coll, Chungnam, South Korea; Choi, Jaeho, Cheonan Natl Technical Coll, Chungnam, South Korea
Abstract: Passive filters are essentially used for attenuating current/voltage harmonics generated from pulse-modulation type converters which are prevail in high-power magnet power supplies (MPS). But the passive filter limits the operation range of the output dc current, causes harmful filter resonance, and makes the system equation more complicate. This paper presents, a systematic and simple filter design method which considers not only filtering but also controlling the magnet current. The design algorithm is extended to the applications on superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Current voltage characteristics; Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Numerical methods; Pulse modulation; DC filters; Magnet power supplies; Superconducting magnetic energy storage system; Passive filters

Authors: Shimizu T., Kurokawa M., Nishida Y., Nakaoka M., Sugawara Y., Horiuchi T.
Title: Utility-interactive instantaneous sinewave space vector modulated bidirectional three phase power conditioner using resonant DC link
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimizu, T., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Kurokawa, M., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nishida, Y., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Sugawara, Y., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Horiuchi, T., Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes an operating principle and features of a parallel resonant DC link circuit with active voltage clamped PWM control strategy. In particular, a new conceptual design procedure of resonant DC Link treated here is discussed including a practical design example under a zero voltage and zero current soft switching condition. In this paper, bidirectional power flow controlled three phase voltage-fed type PWM converter with a resonant DC link which is connected for utility-interfaced battery energy storage system is analyzed and evaluated for load leveling, battery charging, instantaneous reactive current compensation and active power filtering schemes, together with their digital control implementation. Finally, the system performances in space vector modulated active PWM converter mode or inverter mode as well as the effectiveness of this resonant DC link circuit topology and resonant DC link voltage-fed three-phase power converter as interactive conditioner are demonstrated on the basis of the system simulation results in case of operating at multi-functional operation modes.
Index Keywords: Active filters; Digital control systems; Electric current control; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Pulse width modulation; Resonant circuits; Switching circuits; Bidirectional three phase power converters; Multifunctional operation modes; Sine wave space vectors; Utility interfaced battery energy storage systems; Power converters

Authors: Hara M., Miyama M., Satow T., Gerhold J.
Title: Insulation design of pool-boiling he-cooled superconducting coils coil parameters affecting insulation spacing
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; National Institute of Fusion Science, Nagoya, Japan; Graz Technical University, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Hara, M., Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Miyama, M., Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Satow, T., National Institute of Fusion Science, Nagoya, Japan; Gerhold, J., Graz Technical University, Graz, Austria
Abstract: An insulation design procedure for SC (superconducting) coils for electric power apparatus is proposed and applied to a small scale SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage system) consisting of two modules of pool-boiling helium-cooled SC coils. Coil operation parameters affecting insulation spaces are discussed on the basis of an estimated time-dependent ratio of insulation withstand voltage to induced voltage for different quenching states according to the proposed procedure. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Electric coils; Electric energy storage; Helium; Superconducting magnets; Pool boiling helium cooled superconducting coils; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) systems; Electric insulation

Authors: Sarjeant W.J., MacDougall F.W.
Title: Capacitors for high power electronics
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: High Power Electronics Inst, Buffalo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarjeant, W.J., High Power Electronics Inst, Buffalo, United States; MacDougall, F.W., High Power Electronics Inst, Buffalo, United States
Abstract: Many different types of capacitors are available today, most being designed for mounting on circuit boards or other electronic equipment. Generally these fall into the classes of ceramic, tantalum, electrolytic, or DC film capacitors. Larger sizes of capacitors are used in applications such as motor drives and kilowatt to multimegawatt average power, power conditioning equipment. These larger capacitors, operating to voltages in excess of 25 kilovolts, have traditionally been manufactured with paper or polypropylene films, or some combination therein, with or without a gas-excluding liquid impregnant. This paper is focused on defining the technology issues for next generation energy storage capacitors, starting from the current state-of-the art for large (over 5 kg) capacitors recently developed for modern pulsed power conditioning applications.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Dielectric materials; Electric discharges; Power electronics; Energy discharge capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Lewis Don J.
Title: Crashing
Source title: Proceedings - Annual SAFE Symposium (Survival and Flight Equipment Association)
Affiliations: Universal Propulsion Co Inc
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, Don J., Universal Propulsion Co Inc
Abstract: A typical vehicular crash event is analyzed by using graphs. The locations, movements, velocities and accelerations associated with the vehicle and its occupant are plotted vs. elapsed time during the crash event. Sample data is graphed to illustrate the methods and capabilities and it's ease of use as an effective analytical tool. The graphical method illustrated is being presented as a suggested method of introducing new engineers to crash analysis and occupant protection system design. It can quickly provide useful design and crash system performance predictive information. The graphical approach is of particular use in that it provides a `Feel' for the effect of the sensitivity of overall system performance as the various performance parameters are modified. The `Crashing' graphs provide quick evaluation of such variables as: crash sensor delay, restraint system function time, occupant/restraint system interface spacing, belt slack, restraint system stiffness, energy adsorption vs. energy storage, rebound and other system parameters. Both interior and exterior velocity and deceleration, relationships are readily analyzable. This facilitates evaluation of seat belt webbing and anchor loads, webbing stretch as well as head and other occupant elements positions within the vehicle.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Graphic methods; Vehicular crashing; Crashworthiness

Authors: Bergman Sten
Title: Visions of future distribution systems
Affiliations: ELFORSK AB, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bergman, Sten, ELFORSK AB, Sweden
Abstract: A future vision of the electrical transmission and distribution system is discussed in this paper. The content is based on the results from the ELFORSK project - Vision 21 performed during 1995-1996, where over 100 creative ideas were received from 45 participators. The visions are describing both system aspects, new business concepts, advanced components and customer services 20 -30 years ahead. This paper highlights and comments some of the visions. A brief analysis of some benefit value is also presented.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power transmission networks; Information technology; Research and development management; Technological forecasting; Flexible electrical power network; Power quality; Electric power distribution

Authors: Seymour Richard J.
Title: Undersea pumped storage for load leveling
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on California and the World Ocean
Affiliations: Univ of California San Diego, La Jolla, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seymour, Richard J., Univ of California San Diego, La Jolla, United States
Abstract: The supply of energy can be matched to changing demands by using pumped storage to achieve load leveling. Water is pumped uphill and stored in a reservoir during low demand periods and allowed to flow down through turbogenerators when demand is high. In the absence of conventional pumped storage capability, Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) is proposed as a potential candidate for electrical energy load leveling. In CAES, air is mechanically pressurized using surplus electric power into man-made subterranean caverns. To site a specific example, the 230 MW Offshore Compressed Air Energy Storage (OCAES) system at Carlsbad in California is described.
Index Keywords: Electric load management; Energy utilization; Offshore power plants; Pumped storage power plants; Reservoirs (water); Compressed air energy storage (CAES); Electric load leveling; Electric energy storage

Authors: Guillot F., Dézarnaud-Dandine C., Tronc M.
Title: X-ray absorption study of potential barrier effect in group 14 tetrachlorides (GeCl4, SnCl4) and group 15 trichlorides (PCl35, AsCl3)
Affiliations: Lab. Chim. Phys.: Matiere/R., Univ. Pierre et Marie Curie 11, rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Authors with affiliations: Guillot, F., Lab. Chim. Phys.: Matiere/R., Univ. Pierre et Marie Curie 11, rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Dézarnaud-Dandine, C., Lab. Chim. Phys.: Matiere/R., Univ. Pierre et Marie Curie 11, rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Tronc, M., Lab. Chim. Phys.: Matiere/R., Univ. Pierre et Marie Curie 11, rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Abstract: Inner-shell excitation spectra of GeCl4, SnCl4, PCl3 and AsCl3 were obtained in gas phase at room temperature with a total ion-yield technique at the LURE Super ACO and DCI storage rings in Orsay. The inner-shell excitation spectra include Ge 2p, Sn 2p, P 1s, As 2p, and Cl 1s in GeCl4, SnCl4, PCl2 and AsCl3, respectively, and are interpreted in the framework of the potential barrier concept, according to electric dipole selection rules. The well-resolved below-edge features in the metal 2p excitation spectra of GeCl4 and SnCl4 show a similar shape. Moreover, complementary experimental results of ETS with the support of MS-X α calculations are reported and correlated with the C 1s, Si 2p, Ge 2p and Sn 2p term values of the lowest vacant orbitals for CCl4, SiCl4, GeCl4 and SnCl4, respectively, in order to study the trend of the stabilization energy of the various empty orbitals in the neutral and in the core ionized molecules. The P 1s spectrum of PCl3 has been assigned and the As 2p spectrum of AsCl3 compared with the published P 2p spectrum of PCl3. The 1s excitation spectra of the chlorine ligand in the tetrachloride (GeCl4, SnCl4) and trichloride (PCl3, AsCl3) series are very sensitive to the change of symmetry and bonding. A linear correlation between (M-Cl) bond length (with M = Ge, Sn, P, As) and the energy of the Cl 1s → σ * (M-Cl) shape resonance observed above the Cl 1s ionization threshold has been obtained. © 1997 Elsevier Science B.V.

Authors: Swanson Dave, Ward Robert S., Cangiano Brandon, Oswald Sarah, Murray Maryanne
Title: Effects of hydrophilic and hydrophobic coatings and container shape on fluids and containers in a microgravity environment
Affiliations: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swanson, Dave, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States; Ward, Robert S., Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States; Cangiano, Brandon, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States; Oswald, Sarah, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States; Murray, Maryanne, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ, Daytona Beach, United States
Abstract: This experiment demonstrates the fluid property of hydrophilic attraction and hydrophobic repulsion and their relation to surface tension. This study gives an approximation of the amount of control that can be exerted passively over a mass system of fluid. By using cylinders of various sizes and shapes that are coated with various substances, in various patterns, containers along with baffles, a demonstration of the force of attraction between fluid and coating can be observed. The properties studied in this experiment are of great use to the aerospace industry. The control of fluids in a microgravity environment is of major concern to any space project. In the case of a rocket or similar launch vehicle, the fuel of the spacecraft can make up to 70 percent of the weight. If this fluid were to start oscillating, the results would be catastrophic. If the fluid, drifted away from the side of the fuel tank that the fuel need to be drawn from while in orbit, the spacecraft would have no way of using the fuel. Life support systems can also benefit from this technology. Water must be stored aboard just like fuel. In fact, the storage of water might be considered even more crucial because it is carried throughout the entire flight, where fuel is usually spent in the initial stages of the flight. Water and other life supporting fluids are a direct necessity for astronauts and cosmonauts and must be readily available. By studying the relationship between fluid, coatings of containers, and the shape of the container, NASA, the aerospace industry, and science in general will learn to control fluids passively, not actively, conserving energy weight, and increasing efficiency.
Index Keywords: Coatings; Fuel systems; Gravitational effects; Life support systems (spacecraft); Surface tension; Hydrophilic coatings; Hydrophobic coatings; Aerospace engineering

Authors: Jersch J., Demming F., Hildenhagen L.J., Dickmann K.
Title: Direct writing of nano patterns with nearfield enhanced laser radiation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: FH Muenster, FB Physikalische Technik, Stegerwaldstr. 39, D-48565 Steinfurt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Jersch, J., FH Muenster, FB Physikalische Technik, Stegerwaldstr. 39, D-48565 Steinfurt, Germany; Demming, F., FH Muenster, FB Physikalische Technik, Stegerwaldstr. 39, D-48565 Steinfurt, Germany; Hildenhagen, L.J., FH Muenster, FB Physikalische Technik, Stegerwaldstr. 39, D-48565 Steinfurt, Germany; Dickmann, K., FH Muenster, FB Physikalische Technik, Stegerwaldstr. 39, D-48565 Steinfurt, Germany
Abstract: Nano processing is a cornerstone technology for several future oriented applications, as for example in the fields of high density data storage, nano machining of X-ray fresnel optics, micro electronics, micro robotics and biomolecularic. However, as well known, processing in the nanometer range with laser radiation is not possible by lenses or mirrors due to diffraction limitation. Resent research work has shown, that "focusing" of laser radiation down to a few nanometer can be obtained by using lasers in combination with nearfield technology (e.g. SNOM - Scanning Nearfield Optical Microscopy, SPM - Scanning Probe Microscopy). Lateral externally illumination of SPM probe tips with laser radiation can cause tremendous intensity enhancement in the nearfield underneath the tip. A brief theoretical consideration of this effect and results of calculations based on boundary element method (BEM) is done. This kind of field energy concentration we named FOLANT-technique (FOcusing of LAserradiation in the Nearfield of a Tip). The interaction area with nanometer scale can be applied for material processing even down to atomic dimensions. Using FOLANT-technique hillocks, pits and grooves with lateral dimensions down to 10 nm have been obtained on conductive substrates as well as on dielectric materials (for example polycarbonate). Our experiments have shown, that FOLANT-technique is a promising tool for various applications in nanometer material processing.
Author Keywords: Laser material processing; Nanostructuring; Near field optics; Scanning probe technology
Index Keywords: Boundary element method; Data storage equipment; Dielectric materials; Electromagnetic wave diffraction; Laser beam effects; Machining; Microelectronics; Near field scanning optical microscopy; Robotics; X ray optics; Scanning probe microscopy; Nanotechnology

Authors: Voeikov V.L., Novikov C.N.
Title: Peculiarities of luminol- and lucigenin-dependent photon emission from nondiluted human blood
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Faculty of Biology, Moscow State University, Moscow 119899, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Voeikov, V.L., Faculty of Biology, Moscow State University, Moscow 119899, Russian Federation; Novikov, C.N., Faculty of Biology, Moscow State University, Moscow 119899, Russian Federation
Abstract: Comparison of lucigenin- and luminol-dependent chemiluminescence (LC-CL and LM-CL, respectively) in nondiluted healthy donors' blood revealed significant differences in their patterns. LM-CL was low in fresh blood and disappeared after it storage for 3 hours. LC-CL was already high in fresh blood and was steadily increasing with blood storage. Serial dilution of blood with saline after addition of chemiluminescence indicators resulted in elevation of LM-CL, but decrease in LC-CL. LM-CL elevation after the initiation of respiratory burst (RB) in blood with zymosan was observed only in aerated samples and immediately dropped down when air supply to a blood sample was ceased. On the contrary, LM-CL did not depend on air supply to a blood sample for about 30 min. after RB initiation. The results suggest that there are at least two mechanisms for reactive oxygen species production in nondiluted blood. The first one is reflected predominantly by LMCL. It is activated during RB and uses prevalently oxygen dissolved in cell medium. Another one is reflected predominantly by LC-LM. It does not depend upon initiation of RB in neutrophils, operates in blood constantly, and uses oxygen supplied by erythrocytes. It needs blood integrity for its manifestation.
Author Keywords: Chemiluminescence; Lucigenin; Luminol; Non-radiative energy transfer; Respiratory burst; Whole blood
Index Keywords: Blood; Cells; Dimers; Energy transfer; Free radicals; Luminol; Light emission

Authors: Zhang X., Wang Q., Zhao S., Sun L., Zhang S.
Title: Mode-locked characteristics of Nd:S-VAP crystal
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, X., Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China; Wang, Q., Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China; Zhao, S., Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China; Sun, L., Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China; Zhang, S., Optics Department, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China
Abstract: The performance of Nd:S-VAP mode-locked laser was reported using iodoethane solution of BDN dye. A small Nd:S-VAP crystal was found to realize mode-locking operation and generate fine ultrashort pulses. The results showed that Nd:S-VAP was a low-threshold high-efficiency crystal and will find wide applications in many fields.

Authors: Kraft S., Scholze F., Thornagel R., Ulm G., McDermott W.C., Kellogg E.M.
Title: High accuracy calibration of the HXDS HPGe detector at the PTB radiometry laboratory at BESSY
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kraft, S., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; Scholze, F., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; Thornagel, R., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; Ulm, G., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; McDermott, W.C., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; Kellogg, E.M., Physikalisck-Tech. Bundesanstalt, Abbestr. 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory is performing the calibration of the AXAF High Resolution Mirror Assembly (HRMA) at the Marshall Space Flight Center. In order to determine the absolute incoming photon flux at the calibration facility a High Purity Germanium (HPGe) detector and an identical spare detector have been choosen as flux monitor of the HRMA X-ray Detection System (HXDS). The detectors must thus be calibrated in the photon energy range between 700 eV and 10 keV. The calibration and characterization of the detectors was performed at the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) at the electron storage ring BESSY. Two methods have been applied for the determination of the detection efficiency. Firstly, the undispersed calculable synchrotron radiation emitted by a bending magnet of the primary source standard BESSY has been used. Secondly, the detection efficiency has been determined using monochromatized radiation and Si photodiodes as transfer detector standards. The photodiodes have been calibrated with a relative uncertainty of 0.5% in the photon energy range from 50 eV to 1500 eV against a cryogenic electrical substitution radiometer which is a primary detector standard. It will be shown that the determination of the detection efficiency in the whole desired spectral range is possible with a relative uncertainty between 1% and 2%, even in the photon energy range where the detection efficiency is affected by the x-ray absorption finestructures of the Al light blocking filter of the detector.
Author Keywords: Detector calibration; HPGe detector; Primary radiometric standards; Soft X-ray; Synchrotron radiation
Index Keywords: Astrophysics; Photodiodes; Photons; Radiometers; Synchrotron radiation; X ray analysis; High resolution mirror assembly (HRMA); Mirrors

Title: X-ray diffraction analysis of crystallization of SbxSey thin films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China
Authors with affiliations: Bao, H., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China; Ye, S., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China; Yuan, B., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China; Lan, M., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China; Zhou, S., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China; Wang, Q., Semiconductor/Micro-elec. Technol., School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, P.O. Box.328, Harbin 150001, China
Abstract: Chalcogenide alloys SbxSey are being applied to phase-change, reversible optical storage. The non-stoichiometric compound are researched displaying their interesting phenomena before and after anneal in a furnace, which were characterized by the X-ray diffraction technology. The composition of the Se richer than Sb will result the fill in amorphous state in the room temperature evaporation. The Sb2Se3 crystallized out from the non-stoichiometric alloys have the lower crystallization temperature compared with the stoichiometric alloys Sb2Se3. Double layers consisting of Sb film deposited on Se fill was investigated which revealed its special characteristics. The sublimation and the diffusion of the atoms during annealing in the lower temperature have the important effects on the material's crystallization behavior, the great kinetic energy of the atoms will result in the crystallization of Se and Sb2Se3 and, the lower crystallization temperature is just what we expected in the laser recording and for the optical-data storage. An important conclusion can be made from the experiments, the crystallization can be finished by adjacent atomic diffusion. The reason for optical crystallization is also discussed.
Author Keywords: Crystallization; Interface; Phase change; Thin film; X-ray diffraction

Authors: Beisker W., Klocke A.
Title: Fluorescence lifetime measurements in flow cytometry
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: GSF, Natl. Res. Center for Eviron./Hlth., Flow Cytometry Group, Ingolstaedter Landstr. 1, 85764 Neuherberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Beisker, W., GSF, Natl. Res. Center for Eviron./Hlth., Flow Cytometry Group, Ingolstaedter Landstr. 1, 85764 Neuherberg, Germany; Klocke, A., GSF, Natl. Res. Center for Eviron./Hlth., Flow Cytometry Group, Ingolstaedter Landstr. 1, 85764 Neuherberg, Germany
Abstract: Fluorescence lifetime measurements provide insights in the dynamic and structural properties of dyes and their micro-environment. The implementation of fluorescence lifetime measurements in flow cytometric systems allows to monitor large cell and particle populations with high statistical significance. In our system, a modulated laser beam (by acousto-optical modulation) is used for excitation and the phase shift of the fluorescence signal recorded with a fast computer controlled digital oscilloscope (up to 1 GHz) is processed digitally to determine the phase shift with respect to a reference beam by fast fourier transform. Total fluorescence intensity (peak and area) as well as other parameters can be determined simultaneously from the same fluorescence signal. We use the epi-illumination design to allow the use of high numerical apertures (up to N.A. = 1.25) to collect as much light as possible to ensure detection of even weak fluorescence. Data storage and processing is done comparable to slit-scan flow cytometric data using our Data Analysis System (DAS V4.36). The results are stored, displayed, combined with other parameters and analyzed as normal listmode data. In our report we discuss carefully the signal to noise ratio for analog and digital processed lifetime signals to evaluate the theoretical minimum fluorescence intensity for lifetime measurements. Applications to be presented include DNA staining (with intercalating and non-intercalating dyes), parameters of cell functions as well as different applications in non-mammalian cells such as algae.
Author Keywords: Digital signal processing; DNA staining; Energy transfer; Flow cytometry; Fluorescence lifetime measurements
Index Keywords: Algae; Cathode ray oscilloscopes; Cells; Computer control systems; Data reduction; Data storage equipment; DNA; Fast Fourier transforms; Laser beams; Phase shift; Statistical methods; Flow cytometry; Fluorescence

Authors: Walsh M.P., O'Malley M.J.
Title: Augmented hopfield network for unit commitment and economic dispatch
Affiliations: Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Walsh, M.P., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland; O'Malley, M.J., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland
Abstract: The Hopfield network has been applied to the economic dispatch problem with very promising results. However it has been found that the unit commitment problem cannot be tackled accurately within the framework of the conventional Hopfield network. This is due to the fact that both discrete and continuous terms must be considered to fully model the problem. This paper presents an augmented network architecture with a new form of interconnection between neurons giving a more general energy function containing both discrete and continuous terms. A comprehensive cost function for the unit commitment problem is developed and mapped to this energy function. Results show that this technique outperforms previous neural network methods. The new method also compares favourably with Lagrangian relaxation. Detailed results for a power system with thermal hydro and pumped storage units are presented. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Electric power systems; Functions; Mathematical models; Neural networks; Problem solving; Cost function; Economic dispatch; Energy function; Hopfield network; Lagrangian relaxation technique; Electric power transmission networks

Authors: Yuasa T., Akiba M., Takeda T., Kazama M., Hoshino A., Watanabe Y., Hyodo K., Dilmanian F.A., Akatsuka T., Itai Y.
Title: Incoherent-scatter computed tomography with monochromatic synchrotron X ray: Feasibility of multi-ct imaging system for simultaneous measurement of fluorescent and incoherent scatter X rays
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Yamagata University, Yonezawa, Yamagata, 992, Japan; Institute of Clinical Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Medical Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yuasa, T., Faculty of Engineering, Yamagata University, Yonezawa, Yamagata, 992, Japan; Akiba, M., Institute of Clinical Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Takeda, T., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kazama, M., Medical Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Hoshino, A., Faculty of Engineering, Yamagata University, Yonezawa, Yamagata, 992, Japan; Watanabe, Y., Institute of Clinical Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Hyodo, K., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Dilmanian, F.A., Medical Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Akatsuka, T., Faculty of Engineering, Yamagata University, Yonezawa, Yamagata, 992, Japan; Itai, Y., Institute of Clinical Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: We describe a new system of incoherent scatter computed tomography (ISCT) using monochromatic synchrotron X rays, and we discuss its potential to be used in in vivo imaging for medical use. The system operates on the basis of computed tomography (CT) of the first generation. The reconstruction method for ISCT uses the least squares method with singular value decomposition. The research was carried out at the BLNE5A bending magnet beam line of the Tristan Accumulation Ring in KEK, Japan. An acrylic cylindrical phantom of 20mm diameter containing a cross-shaped channel was imaged. The channel was filled with a diluted iodine solution with a concentration of 200 /ugl/ml. Spectra obtained with the system's high purity germanium (HPGe) detector separated the incoherent X-ray line from the other notable peaks, i. e., the Ka and K\ Xray fluorescent lines and the coherent scattering peak. CT images were reconstructed from projections generated by integrating the counts in the energy window centering around the incoherent scattering peak and whose width was approximately 2 keV. The reconstruction routine employed an X-ray attenuation correction algorithm. The resulting image showed more homogeneity than one without the attenuation correction. © 1997 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Computed tomography; Incoherent scatter; Least squares method; Monte carlo simulation; Singular value decomposition; Synchrotron radiation
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Diagnostic radiography; Electromagnetic wave attenuation; Electromagnetic wave scattering; Image reconstruction; Imaging systems; Least squares approximations; Monte Carlo methods; Radiation detectors; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; X ray radiography; Incoherent scatter computed tomography; Singular value decomposition method; Computerized tomography

Authors: Wu Y., Litvinenko V.N., Burnham B., Park S.H., Madey J.M.J.
Title: Performance and operation modes of the duke PEL storage ring
Affiliations: PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Y., PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Litvinenko, V.N., PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Burnham, B., PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Park, S.H., PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Madey, J.M.J., PEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: We present the recent status and performance of the Duke Free Electron Laser (PEL) storage ring. We report a large transverse and energy aperture observed in the storage ring. We describe the consequences of this large aperture on the operation of the storage ring. Several unusual phenomena are reported in this paper, including large amplitude transverse multibunch coherent oscillations (Saturn rings) and beam capture from outside the RF separatrix. We also present the established operation modes for the storage ring, including energy ramping, working point tuning, and different bunch-mode operations to optimize the ring as a synchrotron light source, an PEL, and a gamma-ray source. Finally, we summarize the achieved storage ring parameters since its first operation in November 1994. © 1997 IEEE.
Author Keywords: PEL; Storage ring; Synchrotron light source
Index Keywords: Electron sources; Free electron lasers; Gamma rays; Light sources; Oscillations; Synchrotron radiation; Free electron laser (FEL) storage rings; Storage rings

Authors: Kubota T., Ando K., Muramatsu S.
Title: The effect of the Floating Gate/tunnel SiO 2 interface on FLASH memory data retention reliability
Affiliations: ULSI Device Development Laboratories, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kubota, T., ULSI Device Development Laboratories, Japan; Ando, K., ULSI Device Development Laboratories, Japan; Muramatsu, S., ULSI Device Development Laboratories, Japan
Abstract: The influence of phosphorus at the Floating Gate (FG)/tunnel oxide interface on the FLASH memory data retention characteristics is investigated. By measuring the electrical characteristics of memory cells and MOS capacitors, a close relationship was found between the memory cell data retention and Stress Induced Leakage Current (SILC). Lowering the phosphorus density in the FG suppresses SILCand prolongs the data retention. Applying amorphous Si (a-Si) to the FG, in addition, is also found to improve SILC. Thus, the memory cell data retention characteristics is expected to be improved when a-Si is applied to the FG. This a-Si FG advantage is investigated by C-V characteristics, SIMS (Secondary Ion Mass Spectroscopy) and EDX (Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy) analysis. In spite of the high impurity activation ratio, the phosphorus concentration at the FG/tunnel oxide interface was confirmed to be lower for the a-Si FG than for the poly-Si FG. Applying a-Si therefore, is confirmed to have the same effect as lowering the phosphorus concentration in the FG but preventing the gate depletion effect. This attractive phenomenon for a-Si may be resulting from the lower phosphorus diffusion along the grain boundary. a-Si therefore will be considered as the promising material for high reliability FLASH memories.
Author Keywords: Amorphous Si (a-Si); FLASH; Floating gate; Gate oxide; Poly-Si; Reliability; Retention
Index Keywords: Amorphous silicon; Capacitors; Cellular arrays; Composition effects; Gates (transistor); Interfaces (materials); Leakage currents; MOS devices; Phosphorus; Secondary ion mass spectrometry; Silica; X ray spectroscopy; Energy dispersive X ray spectroscopy (EDX); Floating gates; Memory cell data retention; Data storage equipment

Authors: Sokal N.O., Redl R.
Title: Control algorithms and circuit designs for optimal flyback-charging of an energy-storage capacitor (e.g., for flash lamp or defibrillator)
Affiliations: IEEE, United States; Design Automation, Inc., Lexington, MA 02173-2404, United States; ELFI S. A., Onnens (FR), CH-1756, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Sokal, N.O., IEEE, United States, Design Automation, Inc., Lexington, MA 02173-2404, United States; Redl, R., IEEE, United States, ELFI S. A., Onnens (FR), CH-1756, Switzerland
Abstract: A flyback type of transformer-coupled dc/dc converter supplies a train of current pulses to charge an energy-storage capacitor to a desired high voltage, converting input dc power obtained from a lower voltage dc source. The energy-storage capacitor is charged to a specified voltage within a specified time with minimum peak and rms currents in the transistor, the rectifier diode, the transformer windings, and the dc power source, minimizing the i 2R losses. This is done by generating 1) energy-storage current pulses in the power transistor and the transformer primary winding in which the current increment from the beginning to the end of a pulse is only a small fraction of the final (peak) value and 2) energy-delivery flyback current pulses in the capacitor and the transformer secondary winding in which the current decrement from the beginning to the end of a pulse is only a small fraction of the initial (peak) value. Recommended methods are: 1) hysteretic current-mode control with current sensing in both transformer windings; 2) peak-current-commanding current-mode control with switching frequency or transistor-nonconducting time varying in a prescribed way during the charging; or 3) valley-current-commanding current-mode control with switching frequency or transistor-conducting time varying in a prescribed way during the charging. Compared with one nonoptimal method, peak currents are reduced by a factor of about 2 and i 2R power losses are reduced by a factor of about 1.33.
Author Keywords: Capacitor charger; Capacitor charging; Current-mode control; Defibrillator; Energy-storage capacitor; Feed forward control; Flash; Flyback charger; Flyback charging; Flyback converter; High voltage; Hysteretic current-mode control
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Capacitor storage; Electric current control; Electric network synthesis; Transformer windings; Transistors; Flyback charging; Power converters

Authors: Ehrlich G.M., Hellen R.M., Marsh Orndorh C., Dougherty T.A.
Title: Prismatic lithium-ion batteries
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Yardney Technical Products, Inc., United States; Yardney Technical Products, Inc., 82 Mechanic Street, Pawcatuck, CT 06379, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, G.M., Yardney Technical Products, Inc., United States, Yardney Technical Products, Inc., 82 Mechanic Street, Pawcatuck, CT 06379, United States; Hellen, R.M., Yardney Technical Products, Inc., United States, Yardney Technical Products, Inc., 82 Mechanic Street, Pawcatuck, CT 06379, United States; Marsh Orndorh, C., Yardney Technical Products, Inc., United States, Yardney Technical Products, Inc., 82 Mechanic Street, Pawcatuck, CT 06379, United States; Dougherty, T.A., Yardney Technical Products, Inc., United States, Yardney Technical Products, Inc., 82 Mechanic Street, Pawcatuck, CT 06379, United States
Abstract: Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries have demonstrated the ability to fulfill the energy storage needs of many new technologies. The most significant drawbacks of currently available technologies, such as LiCoO 2 based Li-ion cells, is their high cost and significant environmental hazards. Li-ion cells which use a lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4) spinel based cathode material should be much less costly and safer than LiCoO 2 based cells. Performance data from prismatic design cells which use a LiMn2O4 based cathode material is presented and shown to meet many military performance criteria. The most significant drawback of this technology, at the present time, is the short cycle life.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Lithium compounds; Prismatic lithium ion batteries; Lithium batteries

Authors: Korin E., Soifer L.
Title: Thermal analysis of the system KCl-LiCl by differential scanning calorimetry
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Korin, E., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel; Soifer, L., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel
Abstract: Thermal analysis of the binary system KCl-LiCl in the composition range 0.368-0.812 mol fraction of LiCl was studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). On the basis of the DSC curves, the experimental data for the phase-diagram, the latent heat of fusion, and the average specific heat in the liquid and solid states are presented as a function of the composition of the mixture. The experimental results compared with literature data. The following empirical correlation between the heat of fusion (ΔH) and of compositions of the mixture in mol fraction of LiCl (x) was obtained: ΔH=26.95-50.20x+43.06x2 with a minimum value of 11.8 kJ(g mol)-1 at the eutectic point of 0.587 mol fraction of LiCl at 354.4°C. These results are required as basic data to develop thermal energy storage materials, based on the phase change of a molten mixture of KCl-LiCl. © 1997 Akadémiai Kiadó.
Author Keywords: DSC; Eutectic composition; LiCl-KCl system; Phase diagram

Title: The design of laser texture media using acoustic emission measurements
Affiliations: StorMedia Inc., 385 Reed St, Santa Clara, CA 95050, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goh, W., StorMedia Inc., 385 Reed St, Santa Clara, CA 95050, United States; Jiaa, C., StorMedia Inc., 385 Reed St, Santa Clara, CA 95050, United States; Teng, E., StorMedia Inc., 385 Reed St, Santa Clara, CA 95050, United States; Eltoukhy, A., StorMedia Inc., 385 Reed St, Santa Clara, CA 95050, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates the flying and contact phenomena of proximity contact recording and flying sliders. The tribological performance of thin film laser textured media is studied with acoustic emission analysis. The laser bump height and density were controlled to achieve a desired tribological performance. The relationship between the laser bump height/density and acoustic emission energy during drag and start/stop testing for different slider designs was studied. Emphasis was also placed on identifying the critical parameters of media and slider designs for tribological performance improvements. Reliability and glide height avalanche testing results were found to correlate well with the acoustic emission energy data. © 1997 IEEE.

Authors: Sato A.
Title: Head-Disk Interface Design for In-Contact Recording using Wet Systems
Affiliations: Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, 4-1-1 Miyazaki, Miyamae-ku, Kawasaki 216, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, A., Functional Devices Res. Labs., NEC Corporation, 4-1-1 Miyazaki, Miyamae-ku, Kawasaki 216, Japan
Abstract: The authors have investigated head-disk interface design for in-contact recording using wet systems. The design concept of the wet systems is to realize a low bouncing height of sliders by using the meniscus attractive force of the lubricant between slider and disk. The lubricant offered high wear performance at the same time. It was found that lubricants with high surface energies suppressed the bouncing height of contact sliders. A bouncing height of 3 nm was achieved for a combination of 30 % contact sliders and lubricants of maleic anhydride modified polybutene. A contact slider design, with a meniscuscontrolled contact pad, is proposed for contact sliders using wet systems. The bouncing of the slider was suppressed by regulating the etching depth of the meniscus-controlled contact pad. High wear performance of the in-contact recording system was confirmed by both the drag test for disks and the seek test for heads. The large readback signal and the pulse width measured at 50% amplitude (PW50) for the incontact recording, compared with flying heads, has been demonstrated. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Interfaces (materials); Interfacial energy; Lubricants; Magnetic disk storage; Magnetic heads; Polybutenes; Wear of materials; In contact recording; Wet systems; Magnetic recording

Authors: Uwazumi H.
Title: Time decay of rémanent magnetization, rémanent coercivity, and readback signal of ultra-thin longitudinal CoCr12Ta2/Cr thin film media
Affiliations: R and D Department, Magnetic Disk Group, Fuji Electric Co.Ltd, Matsumoto, Nagano 390, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uwazumi, H., R and D Department, Magnetic Disk Group, Fuji Electric Co.Ltd, Matsumoto, Nagano 390, Japan
Abstract: The time decay of rémanent magnetization, rémanent coercivity, and readback signal of ultra-thin longitudinal CoCrnTa2/Cr thin film media have been studied experimentally with a VSM and a recording spin-stand tester using a MR read head. The time decay rate of the rémanent magnetization or magnetic viscosity S increases significantly with decreasing magnetic layer thickness, especially for a Mrt of less than 0.5 memu/cm2 and it is found to be strongly related to the strength of the magnetic interactions between grains. For such thin media (CoOTa=6 nm) with a Mrt = 0.36 memu/cm2, the readback signal amplitude decreases at a high decay rate of about 5 % per decade of time (sec) which is found to be essentially independent of the linear recording density from 2000 to 6000 fc/mm. To obtain CoCrizTa2/Cr media with a time decay rate of less than 10 % in 5 years, the value of the ratio of the anisotropy energy barrier to the thermal energy (Kv/kT) should be greater than 80 which corresponds to a CoCrTa thickness of greater than about 10 nm. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Chromium alloys; Cobalt alloys; Coercive force; Grain boundaries; Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic heads; Magnetization; Magnetometers; Magnetoresistance; Remanence; Ultrathin films; Vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM); Magnetic film storage

Authors: Tantawi S.G.
Title: Active high-power rf pulse compression using optically switched resonant delay lines
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC), Stanford University, Stanford CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tantawi, S.G., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC), Stanford University, Stanford CA, United States
Abstract: We present the design and a proof of principle experimental results of an optically controlled high-power RF pulse-compression system. In principle the design should handle a few hundreds of megawatts of power at Jf-band. The system is based on the switched resonant delay-line theory [1]. It employs resonant delay lines as a means of storing RF energy. The coupling to the lines is optimized for maximum energy storage during the charging phase. To discharge the lines a high-power microwave switch increases the coupling to the lines just before the start of the output pulse. The high-power microwave switch required for this system is realized using optical excitation of an electron-hole plasma layer on the surface of a pure silicon wafer. The switch is designed to operate in the TEoi mode in a circular waveguide to avoid the edge effects present at the interface between the silicon wafer and the supporting waveguide; thus enhancing its power handling capability. © 1997 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Photnic switching systems; Photoconductive devices; Pulse compression methods; Pulse generation
