Authors: Kapustjanenko G.G., Pignasty S.S., Sheyjakin S.N.
Title: THE THEORETICAL ANALYSIS of A MAGNETIC FLUX GENERATOR
Affiliations: Scientific Research Institute of New Physical and Applied Problems, 160/20 Frunze str, Kiev 254073, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Kapustjanenko, G.G., Scientific Research Institute of New Physical and Applied Problems, 160/20 Frunze str, Kiev 254073, Ukraine; Pignasty, S.S., Scientific Research Institute of New Physical and Applied Problems, 160/20 Frunze str, Kiev 254073, Ukraine; Sheyjakin, S.N., Scientific Research Institute of New Physical and Applied Problems, 160/20 Frunze str, Kiev 254073, Ukraine
Abstract: This paper deals with the air-core rotary magnetic flux generator (MFC) which is intended for storage of magnetic energy and for discharge of powerful pulse current. The principle of MFC operation is based on amplification of magnetic energy by means of cyclic magnetic flux compression under self-excitation condition. The mathematical model describes the dynamic and energy characteristics in the cyclic process of magnetic energy storage. In the model, winding heating and commutation processes are taken into account. Computation results and results of optimization of generator parameters are given. The computation results show the coefficient of magnetic energy amplification can be more than 1000 at a storage time of 10-50 ms depending on winding parameters and an initial rotor tip speed of about 300400 m/s. The magnetic energy density of a MFC with uncooled windings can be more than 1 J/g. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric commutation; Electric windings; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Optimization; Rotors; Magnetic energy storage; Magnetic flux generators; Rotating magnetic amplifiers

Authors: Alhamadi M.A., Demerdash N.A.
Title: Optimization of the skew angle of rotor magnetic poles in permanent magnet machines based on the inverse problem method
Source title: IEEE International Electric Machines and Drives Conference Record, IEMDC
Affiliations: Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar
Authors with affiliations: Alhamadi, M.A., Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar; Demerdash, N.A., Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar
Abstract: This paper presents optimization of the skew angle of rotor magnetic poles in permanent magnet class of machines. The skew angle optimization is achieved using the gradient based inverse problem methodology. The paper introduces the armature winding flux linkages and associated induced emfs for the first time as the object function. In the mean time, this object function involves the use of stored energy and excitation perturbation techniques. An example 1.2 hp permanent magnet brushless dc machine is used to demonstrate the validity and usefulness of the method.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric excitation; Inverse problems; Permanent magnets; Perturbation techniques; Rotors (windings); Electromotive forces; Skew angle; Reluctance motors

Authors: Nagao Michihiko, Harada Koosuke
Title: Power flow of photovoltaic system using buck-boost PWM power inverter
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Kumamoto Inst of Technology, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nagao, Michihiko, Kumamoto Inst of Technology, Kumamoto, Japan; Harada, Koosuke, Kumamoto Inst of Technology, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a buck-boost PWM power inverter and its application for residential photovoltaic system. The PWM power inverter is realized by combining two sets of a high frequency buck-boost chopper and by making it operate in the discontinuous conduction mode. Photovoltaic system with the power inverter has the following advantages: (1) the power generated by the photovoltaic array can be transferred to the load and the utility line under any array voltage, (2) isolation between the photovoltaic array and the utility line is performed by a small high frequency reactor operating as energy storage element, (3) unity power factor operation is provided, (4) there is no need of a reactor for interconnection with the utility line, (5) so the system configuration is very simple. The input-output characteristics of the system are analyzed. As a result, the ripple component of the array current and the power flow between the interface and the utility line are derived and verified experimentally.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Choppers (circuits); Electric load flow; Electric power factor correction; Solar cell arrays; Buck boost pulse width modulated power inverters; Photovoltaic systems; Power converters

Authors: Winwood R., Benstead R., Edwards R.
Title: Advanced fabric energy storage I: Review
Source title: Building Services Engineering Research and Technology
Affiliations: EA Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom; University of Manchester, Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Winwood, R., EA Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom, University of Manchester, Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Benstead, R., EA Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom; Edwards, R., University of Manchester, Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Abstract: This is the first of a series of four papers which describe a three-year research project into 'advanced fabric energy storage', which is defined to be the subgroup of fabric-energy-storage systems which pass ventilation air through a structural mass element for the purpose of heat exchange. The technique can reduce or eliminate a building's requirement for mechanical cooling and allow the heating requirement to be demand-shifted to the night-time cheap electricity tariff. The paper presents a literature survey of advanced fabric-energy-storage systems and describes the historical development of the 'FES-slab' - the leading commercial system. Subsequent papers describe the investigation of the slab with a computational-fluid-dynamics model, the theoretical analysis of the cfd results and the incorporation of a slab model into a full-building simulation and, finally, results from experimental monitoring of the first uk building to apply the FES-slab.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Computational fluid dynamics; Cooling; Heat exchangers; Research; Space heating; Ventilation; Advanced fabric energy storage; Mechanical cooling; Slab model; Structural mass element; Energy storage

Authors: Watanabe M., Tachikawa M., Osaka T.
Title: On the possibility of hydrogen intercalation of graphite-like carbon materials - Electrochemical and molecular orbital studies
Affiliations: Kagami Mem. Lab. Mat. Sci. Technol., Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, M.; Tachikawa, M.; Osaka, T., Kagami Mem. Lab. Mat. Sci. Technol., Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan
Abstract: Graphite-like carbon materials were investigated to learn whether they form hydrogen-graphite intercalation compounds (H-GICs), which would be useful as hydrogen storage materials in rechargeable batteries. The ability of graphite-like materials to absorb hydrogen was examined with cyclic voltammetry (CV) and constant-current charge and discharge tests in 6 mol dm-3 KOH. It was concluded that H-GICs did not form under our experimental conditions. In order to understand the difference between hydrogen and lithium ions in ability to form the intercalation compounds with graphite-like carbon materials, molecular orbital analyses were carried out. The results demonstrate that lithium-graphite intercalation compounds (Li-GICs) are stable because of the presence of lithium 2p-orbitals, whereas such stable graphite intercalation compounds do not form with hydrogen ions because no three-dimensional p-orbitals are available.
Author Keywords: Graphite intercalation compounds; Hydrogen; Lithium; Molecular orbital methods
Index Keywords: Cyclic voltammetry; Electric charge; Electron energy levels; Hydrogen; Intercalation compounds; Lithium; Molecular dynamics; Potassium compounds; Secondary batteries; Graphite like carbon materials; Hydrogen storage materials; Molecular orbitals; Carbon

Authors: Zukowski Charles A., Wang Shao-Yi
Title: Use of selective precharge for low-power on the match lines of content-addressable memories
Source title: Records of the IEEE International Workshop on Memory Technology, Design and Testing
Affiliations: Columbia Univ, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zukowski, Charles A., Columbia Univ, New York, United States; Wang, Shao-Yi, Columbia Univ, New York, United States
Abstract: In a CMOS content-addressable memory (CAM), a large amount of energy is generally expended charging and discharging most of the match lines on most cycles. In this paper we explore the use of selective precharge to significantly reduce this problem. The comparator/memory array is partitioned such that a small subset does a portion of each comparison calculation first, and each comparator in the main part of the array is only activated if still needed afterwards. It is shown that such an approach does not necessarily increase the cycle time, but it does affect the timing within a cycle. Estimates are given for the optimal partitioning and the resulting energy savings.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Comparator circuits; Computer circuits; Energy conservation; Logic gates; Match lines; Memory arrays; Associative storage

Authors: Pieronek Thomas J., Decker D.Kent, Spector Victor A.
Title: Spacecraft flywheel systems - benefits and issues
Source title: National Aerospace and Electronics Conference, Proceedings of the IEEE
Affiliations: TRW, Redondo Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pieronek, Thomas J., TRW, Redondo Beach, United States; Decker, D.Kent, TRW, Redondo Beach, United States; Spector, Victor A., TRW, Redondo Beach, United States
Abstract: Flywheels are electro-mechanical energy storage devices. Recent developments in magnetically levitated composite flywheels have produced systems with specific energies in excess of 20 watt-hours/pound. When compared with nickel-hydrogen battery technology, flywheels offer significant weight savings as an energy storage media for spacecraft. Additional weight savings are possible if the flywheel hardware can also be used for on-board attitude control and momentum management. This paper explores the challenges which accompany the insertion of flywheel systems into spacecraft power and attitude control subsystems.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electromechanical devices; Flight dynamics; Flywheel propulsion; Flywheels; Spacecraft flywheel systems; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Zukowski Charles A., Wang Shao-Yi
Title: Power reduction in large fan-in CMOS gates in logic arrays using selective precharge
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Great Lakes Symposium on VLSI
Affiliations: Columbia Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zukowski, Charles A., Columbia Univ, United States; Wang, Shao-Yi, Columbia Univ, United States
Abstract: A general technique to reduce the energy used by individual CMOS logic gates in large fan-in logic arrays is derived. A fairly small subset of the array inputs is used to do a partial calculation, the results of which can be used to significantly reduce energy use in the rest of the array by avoiding unnecessary charge/discharge cycles. This can be done without significantly reducing the speed, leading to a vastly improved energy-delay product in certain applications such as a PLA and a comparator array. Estimates of the optimal location for the partition and the performance gain as a function of various parameters of the logic array are provided.
Index Keywords: CMOS gates; Comparator arrays; Energy delay product; Logic arrays; Power reduction; Selective precharge; Associative storage; Calculations; CMOS integrated circuits; Comparator circuits; Computer simulation; Energy conservation; Logic design; Parameter estimation; Logic gates

Authors: Darambara D.G., Papadopoulos A.N., Spyrou N.M.
Title: Computer simulation of positron-induced radiation effects in dynamic RAMs
Source title: Radiation Effects and Defects in Solids
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, Surrey GU2 5XH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Darambara, D.G., Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, Surrey GU2 5XH, United Kingdom; Papadopoulos, A.N., Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, Surrey GU2 5XH, United Kingdom; Spyrou, N.M., Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, Surrey GU2 5XH, United Kingdom
Abstract: The sensitivity of computer memory devices to single event upsets (SEUs) caused by ionizing radiation provided the foundation for a proposed dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) based position sensitive radiation sensor, which is likely to be used for studying the movement of radiolabelled pharmaceuticals in biological tissues in vitro using positron emitting tracers. By making use of the ITS [8] Monte Carlo code, simulations of the positron interactions with the materials consisting a DRAM device have been carried out for four positron emitters, i e 18F, 13N, 11C and 15O, which are of interest in studying biological functions. The device geometry modelling and the positron energy spectra of the above emitters obtained by utilizing the Fermi-Kurie plots have been successfully applied. Finally, the energy deposition of positrons within the different layers of the DRAMs were investigated. The aim of this paper is to present and discuss the results of these simulations.
Author Keywords: Dynamic RAMs; In vitro PET; Ionizing radiation effects; Position sensitive positron detector; Radiation detection; Single event upsets

Authors: Morkoç H.
Title: Potential applications of III-V nitride semiconductors
Affiliations: Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Materials Research Laboratory, 104 S. Goodwin Ave., Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Wright Laboratory, Wright Patterson AFB, Dayton, OH 45433, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morkoç, H., Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Materials Research Laboratory, 104 S. Goodwin Ave., Urbana, IL 61801, United States, Wright Laboratory, Wright Patterson AFB, Dayton, OH 45433, United States
Abstract: Gallium nitride and its alloys with InN and AlN have recently emerged as important semiconductor materials with applications to yellow, green, blue and ultraviolet portions of the spectrum as emitters and detectors and high power temperature electronics. Blue and green nitride LEDs exhibit brightness levels and longevity well in excess of that required for outdoor applications. Combined with the available red LEDs, true full color all semiconductor displays can be attained for the first time. If used for traffic lights and illumination (pending further improvements in blue in some cases), these devices can outlast and outperform the incandescent light bulbs while saving precious energy. This material system is also intrinsically germane to short wavelength semiconductor lasers for increased data storage. Very recently, pulsed room temperature operation of 410 nm semiconductor lasers, the shortest wavelength ever from a semiconductor, have been reported. Nitrides are also conducive for high power devices/circuits, and sensors and detectors with applications in high temperature and unfriendly environments which leads to estimates that substantial weight savings can be achieved in aircraft and spacecraft. Moreover, the AlGaN alloy with bandgap above 5.5 eV shows negative electron affinity surfaces with applications to cold cathodes in general and flat panel displays in particular. © 1997 Elsevier Science S.A.
Author Keywords: Gallium nitride; Semiconductors; Temperature electronics
Index Keywords: Energy gap; Light emitting diodes; Nitrides; Photodetectors; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; Semiconducting indium compounds; Semiconductor lasers; Temperature electronics; Semiconducting gallium compounds

Authors: Cavallo Alfred J.
Title: Utility scale baseload wind energy plants
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Cavallo, Alfred J.
Abstract: Wind generated electricity can be transformed from an intermittent to a baseload power supply cost-effectively by taking advantage of the fundamental properties of wind and by the efficient utilization of compressed air energy storage (CAES) systems. A utility scale wind-CAES-transmission system can have a 95 percent capacity factor at a cost of delivered electricity that is about 15 percent greater than a conventional wind energy system with a 34 percent capacity factor. This approach has several compelling advantages. It is based on existing technology and makes best use of costly transmission lines. It produces electricity that is the technical equivalent of that from fossil fuel or nuclear power stations. It minimizes greenhouse gas and other fossil fuel pollution, and is an industrial scale system. And in many cases, the increased value of the plant output will more than compensate for the added cost of the storage system.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Electric power plants; Greenhouse effect; Compressed air energy storage (CAES) systems; Wind power

Authors: Gagnol P.
Title: Industrial batteries in the electric power system of 'Electricité de France'
Affiliations: Electricité de France, Direction des Etudes et Recherches, Les Renardières, BP 1, 77250 Moret-sur-Loing, France
Authors with affiliations: Gagnol, P., Electricité de France, Direction des Etudes et Recherches, Les Renardières, BP 1, 77250 Moret-sur-Loing, France
Abstract: More than 5000 industrial batteries are operating in the different power plants, substations and distribution centres of 'Electricité de France' (EDF). 2 V lead/acid and 1.2 V alkaline systems are used for different stationary stand-by applications: power station control, communication, etc. In nuclear plants, these batteries are part of the ultimate safety system ensuring the safe control of the reactor. The operating conditions of the industrial batteries at EDF, the different related battery technologies and the testing methods used to assess their operating ability are described. For selection, batteries undergo electric, seismic and ageing tests. Ageing sequences involve successive floating phases at a high temperature. Results on absorptive glass mat valve-regulated lead/acid battery testing are given. On-line monitoring methods are studied in order to evaluate the remaining available autonomy of the battery according to its state of ageing. In addition to these stand-by applications, EDF is also investigating the potential of future energy and quality applications of stationary batteries such as load levelling or storage of energy produced from renewable sources.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen evolution; Industrial batteries; Lead/acid batteries; Power systems; Sizing
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Electric power plants; Gas emissions; Hydrogen; Standby power systems; Valve regulated lead/acid batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Morales F.J., Romero C., Jimenez-Perez S.
Title: A kinetic study on 5-hydroxymethylfurfural formation in Spanish UHT milk stored at different temperatures
Source title: Journal of Food Science and Technology
Affiliations: Unidad de Products Lacteos, Instituto del Frio (CSIC), Ciudad Universitaria s/n, E-28040 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Morales, F.J., Unidad de Products Lacteos, Instituto del Frio (CSIC), Ciudad Universitaria s/n, E-28040 Madrid, Spain; Romero, C., Unidad de Products Lacteos, Instituto del Frio (CSIC), Ciudad Universitaria s/n, E-28040 Madrid, Spain; Jimenez-Perez, S., Unidad de Products Lacteos, Instituto del Frio (CSIC), Ciudad Universitaria s/n, E-28040 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) formed at different storage temperatures (below 50°C) in commercial ultra high temperature (UHT) milk was measured both by colorimetric and RP-HPLC techniques. Lowest HMF amounts were noted in all samples by RP-HPLC method. HMF level was found to be related to temperature and time of storage and increased at higher temperature, although small losses were detected at 6°C. Two stages of HMF formation could be differenciated, i.e., at an early stage till first 60 days and an advanced one from 60 days until 90 days. Zero order kinetics were obtained for both stages, along with higher activation energy values for UGT-indirect samples.
Author Keywords: 5-hydroxymethylfurfural; Browning; High performance liquid chromatography; Spanish milk; Stored milk; Ultra high temperature
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Colorimetry; Food storage; High performance liquid chromatography; Reaction kinetics; Thermal effects; Hydroxymethylfurfural; Spanish ultrahigh temperature (UHT) milk; Dairy products

Authors: Cheng W., Wilson D.G., Pfahnl A.C.
Title: Analytical efficiency comparison between gas turbine and gas turbine hybrid engines for passenger cars
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge,MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, W., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge,MA, United States; Wilson, D.G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge,MA, United States; Pfahnl, A.C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge,MA, United States
Abstract: The performance and emissions of two alternative types of gas turbine engine for a chosen family vehicle are compared. One engine is a regenerative 71 kW gas turbine; the other is a hybrid power plant composed of a 15 kW gas turbine and a 7 MJ flywheel. These engines would give generally similar vehicle performance to that produced by 71 kW spark ignition and compression ignition engines. (The turbine engines would be lighter and, with a free power turbine, would have a more favourable torquespeed curve (1), giving them some advantages.) Results predict that for long-distance trips the hybrid engine would have a considerably better fuel economy and would produce lower emissions than the piston engines, and that the 'straight' gas turbine would be even better. For shorter commuting trips the hybrid would be able to run entirely from energy acquired and stored from house electricity, and it could therefore be the preferred choice for automobiles used primarily for urban driving when environmental factors are taken into account. However, the degradation of remaining energy in flywheel batteries and thermal energy in the regenerator and other engine hot parts between use periods will result in more energy being used than for the straight gas turbine engine using normal liquid fuel. The higher initial cost and greater complexity of the hybrid engine will be additional disadvantages. © IMechE 1997.
Author Keywords: Automotive engines; Flywheel energy storage; Gas turbine engines; Highefficiency engines; Hybrid engines; Low-emission engines

Authors: Banerjee S., Saenger P., Hu M., Chen W., Barzilai N.
Title: Fat accretion and the regulation of insulin-mediated glycogen synthesis after puberty in rats
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Regulatory Integrative and Comparative Physiology
Affiliations: Division of Pediatrie Endocrinology, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Division of Endocrinology Metabolism, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Division of Endocrinology, Dept. of Medicine, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave., Bronx, NY 10461, United States
Authors with affiliations: Banerjee, S., Division of Pediatrie Endocrinology, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Saenger, P., Division of Pediatrie Endocrinology, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Hu, M., Division of Endocrinology Metabolism, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Chen, W., Division of Endocrinology Metabolism, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Barzilai, N., Division of Endocrinology Metabolism, Diabet. Research and Training Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States, Division of Endocrinology, Dept. of Medicine, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave., Bronx, NY 10461, United States
Abstract: Peripheral insulin sensitivity decreases after puberty in both humans and rodents and can be explained mostly by a reduction in insulin-mediated glycogen synthesis. We tested the hypothesis that the increase in postpubertal fat mass (FM), reflecting an alternative energy store, regulates a decrease in the capacity to store muscle glycogen. We studied Sprague- Dawley rats (n = 21) before puberty (Pre) or after puberty (at 4 mo of age) in groups that were either ad libitum fed (Post) or moderately caloric restricted (CR). FM (by 3H2O isotope dilution technique) was decreased by >40% in CR compared with Post. Glucose uptake (R(d), by 18 mU · kg-1 · min-1 hyperinsulinemic clamp) was 63 ± 8 mg · kg-1 · min-1 in Pre and decreased to 39 ± 2 mg · kg 6-1 · min-1 in Post (P < 0.001). However, it increased in CR to 53 ± 2 mg · kg-1 · min-1 (P < 0.001 vs. Post). This increase in R(d) was mainly accounted for by an increase in glycogen synthesis (R(d) glycolysis determined by the rate of conversion of 3H-labeled glucose to 3H2O) from 23 ± 2 in Post to 33 ± 2 mg · kg-1 · min-1 in CR (P < 0.001; 38 ± 7 mg · kg-1. min-1 in Pre). Correction of glycogen synthesis in CR to near-prepubertal levels was further supported by directly assayed muscle glycogen content after insulin stimulation that was 45% higher and by a 35% enhanced accumulation of [3H]glucose into glycogen. No changes in the enzyme kinetics of glycogen synthase or phosphorylase were observed. An additional group of 2-mo-old postpubertal ad libitum-fed rats was matched with CR for lean body mass but had more FM. This group demonstrated 25% lower rates of insulin-mediated glycogen synthesis compared with CR, further supporting the notion that a moderate reduction of FM prevents the decline in insulin responsiveness and glycogen synthesis occurring after puberty. These data suggest a cause- effect relationship between the increased deposition of fat and the reduced ability to store glucose in skeletal muscle after puberty.
Author Keywords: Calorie restriction; Glycolysis; Insulin responsiveness
Index Keywords: fat; glycogen; insulin; animal experiment; animal tissue; article; caloric restriction; controlled study; glucose intolerance; glycogen synthesis; hyperinsulinemia; insulin resistance; insulin sensitivity; lipid storage; male; nonhuman; priority journal; puberty; rat

Authors: Caldwell Darwin G., Medrano-Cerda G.A., Bowler C.J.
Title: Investigation of bipedal robot locomotion using pneumatic muscle actuators
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
Affiliations: Univ of Salford, Salford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Caldwell, Darwin G., Univ of Salford, Salford, United Kingdom; Medrano-Cerda, G.A., Univ of Salford, Salford, United Kingdom; Bowler, C.J., Univ of Salford, Salford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Bipedal locomotion and particularly the human gait is a highly automated and complex process involving large numbers of actuators. Unfortunately actuator technology is an area of robotics with many conflicting requirements such as: high power density, high power to weight ratio, rapid response, accurate repeatable control, cleanliness, high efficiency, and low cost, which make selection complex. Pneumatic Muscle Actuators (based on the McKibben Muscle) which can provide position and force control better than 1% have been applied to upper limbs with some success and with contractile forces in excess of 1000 N (in units weighing less than 50 g) there is considerable potential for use in bipedal locomotion. This paper will explore the design of a bipedal robot to take advantage of the potential of these actuators. Muscle co-ordination and control sequences will be considered for striding and standing activities and it will be shown that in terms of the energy requirements PMAs are very capable of providing a reliable bipedal drive source with linear actuation, low mass, fast response, compliant energy storage and simple construction.
Index Keywords: Actuators; Force control; Pneumatic control equipment; Position control; Bipedal robot locomotion; Pneumatic muscle actuators; Mobile robots

Authors: Ito K., Shiba T., Yokoyama R.
Title: Optimal capacity planning of thermal storage tanks installed into energy supply systems
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: Dept. of Energy Systems Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1, Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 593, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, K., Dept. of Energy Systems Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1, Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 593, Japan; Shiba, T., Dept. of Energy Systems Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1, Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 593, Japan; Yokoyama, R., Dept. of Energy Systems Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1, Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 593, Japan
Abstract: An optimal capacity planning problem is discussed for energy supply systems including thermal storage tanks. Equipment capacities and utility maximum demands are determined so as to minimize the annual total cost in consideration of the system's operational strategy for energy demand varying hourly in a year. This optimization problem is solved using a hierarchical optimization method on the basis of a penalty one. The operational strategy for hourly energy demand is determined so as to minimize the daily operational cost. This optimal operational problem is solved efficiently from the viewpoint of computation time by a proposed approximate method. Lastly, a numerical study is carried out for three types of district heating and cooling systems to be compared. Through the study, the effectiveness of the proposed method is ascertained.
Author Keywords: Economic evaluation; Energy storage; Optimal capacity planning; Optimal operation; Thermal storage
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Cooling systems; Cost effectiveness; District heating; Numerical analysis; Optimization; Problem solving; Optimal capacity planning; Optimal operation; Thermal storage tanks; Heat storage

Authors: Collins Jr. E.Randolph, Mansoor Arshad
Title: Effects of voltage sags on AC motor drives
Source title: IEEE Annual Textile, Fiber and Film Industry Technical Conference
Affiliations: Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins Jr., E.Randolph, Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States; Mansoor, Arshad, Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States
Abstract: Voltage sags are normally described by magnitude variation land duration. In addition to these quantifies, sags are also characterized by unbalance (asymmetry), non-sinusoidal waveshapes, and phase angle shift (phase jump). These Factors are important for determining the behavior of ac motor drives during sags. Voltage unbalance and phase angle shifts cause large unbalanced source currents to, excessive voltage ripple in the dc-link, and reduced dc-link average voltage. The response of the motor and drive to these varies considerably. Experimental results clearly show the load-dependent behavior of a typical drive. The ability of the drived to ride-through a voltage sag is dependent upon the energy storage capacity of the dc-link capacitor, the speed and inertia of the load, the power consumed by the load, and the trip point settings of the drive. The control system of the drive has a great impact on the behavior of the drive during the sag and after recovery. The trip point settings of many drives can by field-adjusted and greatly improve many nuisance trips resulting from minor voltage sags.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Capacitors; Control systems; Electric energy storage; Electric field effects; Frequency response; Voltage sag; Electric drives

Authors: Hicks Patrick, Walnock Matthew, Owens Robert Michael
Title: Analysis of power consumption in memory hierarchies
Source title: International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hicks, Patrick, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, United States; Walnock, Matthew, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, United States; Owens, Robert Michael, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we note and analyze a key trade-off: as the complexity of caches increases (higher set-associativity, larger block size, and larger overall size), the power consumed by a cache access increases. However, because the hit rate also increases, the number of main memory accesses decreases and thus the power consumed by a memory access decreases. Recent papers which consider the power consumption of caches tend to ignore hit rates. This is unfortunate, because it is undesirable to have energy-efficient caches which are also very slow. Hit rates also play a key role in truly evaluating the energy efficiency of a cache, because low hit rates lead to more frequent main memory accesses which consume more power than cache accesses.
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Hierarchical systems; Mathematical models; Storage allocation (computer); Energy efficient caches; Buffer storage

Authors: Svec F.
Title: Ageing and adrenal cortical function
Affiliations: Section of Endocrinology, Louisiana State University, Medical School, 1542 Tulane Avenue, New Orleans, LA 70112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Svec, F., Section of Endocrinology, Louisiana State University, Medical School, 1542 Tulane Avenue, New Orleans, LA 70112, United States
Abstract: Ageing is associated with changes in the secretion of adrenal cortical steroids. In the elderly, cortisol secretion increases after stimulation, while the secretion of dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) decreases. Each of these hormones influences the age-related processes of energy metabolism, fat depot distribution, immune function and neurodegeneration. In animals the effects of adrenal steroids are dramatic and easily measured. are more subtle. This review summarizes these actions and emphasizes the differences of dosages used in various experimental designs. It is concluded that adrenal hormones may play a significant role in human ageing, but research is hindered because the molecular pathways of DHEA action are not known.
Author Keywords: Adrenal gland; Ageing; Cortisol; Dehydroepiandrosterone; Dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate
Index Keywords: corticosteroid; prasterone; adrenal cortex function; aged; aging; corticosteroid release; energy metabolism; lipid storage; nerve degeneration; review

Authors: Aero Eron L.
Title: Nonlinear dynamics of liquid crystals as visco - elastic media with controllable properties
Source title: International Conference on Control of Oscillations and Chaos, Proceedings
Affiliations: Inst of Problems of Mechanical, Engineering, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Aero, Eron L., Inst of Problems of Mechanical, Engineering, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The continuum theory of elasticity of nematic liquid crystals (NLC) is reviewed. NLC do not possess shear elasticity at all as fluids do. However, NLC fluidity does not take place in equilibrium state and they behave as elastic media with reversible energy storage. In fact, elastic equations of NLC are conditions of moment but not force equilibrium. Consequently, the NLC properties may be controlled by external field especially effective in thin layers. This famous nature of NLC is a basis for construction of NLC electrooptic devices.
Index Keywords: Anisotropy; Continuum mechanics; Energy storage; Phase equilibria; Viscoelasticity; Shear elasticity; Nematic liquid crystals

Authors: Wakasugi M., Inabe N., Kubo T., Okuno H., Tanihata I., Watanabe Y., Yano Y., Yoshida A., Hies M., Katayama T., Ozawa S.

Abstract: As part of the RIKEN RIBF (RI beam factory) program, high-resolution X-ray spectroscopy for highly-charged radioactive isotope beams, is proposed in order to make a systematic study of the mean-square nuclear charge radii and moments of short lived radioactive isotopes far from the line of stability. To examine the feasibility of the experiment, we are now performing a test experiment using a laser beam and Li-like ion beams from RIKEN ring cyclotron. The D1 resonance line of a 11B2+ beam was clearly observed for the first time.
Index Keywords: Boron; Cyclotrons; Laser applications; Laser beams; Radioisotopes; Resonance; Storage rings; X ray spectroscopy; Collinear laser spectroscopy; Radioactive isotope beams; Ion beams

Authors: Schuch R., DeWitt D.R., Gao H., Mannervik S., Zong W., Badnell N.R.
Title: Recombination studies of highly charged ions in the cooler ring CRYRING
Affiliations: Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Schuch, R., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; DeWitt, D.R., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Gao, H., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Mannervik, S., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Zong, W., Department of Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Badnell, N.R., Department of Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cooler-storage ring facilities offer unique experimental possibilities for studies of electron-ion recombination processes at low relative energies by employing the electron cooler as a target. Through the use of an adiabatically expanded electron beam in the cooler of CRYRING, collisions down to 10-4eV relative energies were measured with highly charged ions stored in the ring at around 15 MeV/amu energies. Examples of recombination measurements for C4+ and Ar15+ ions at an energy resolution of as low as 10-2eV FWHM are presented and compared with calculations of the energies and resonance strength for dielectronic recombination using multiconfiguration Breit-Pauli approximations. They agree in spectral shape and absolute cross section but show some deviation for lower n in the Rydberg series.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Argon; Carbon; Electron beams; Resonance; Storage rings; Targets; Breit Pauli approximations; Cooler storage rings; Electron ion recombination processes; Full width at half maximum (FWHM); Rydberg series; Ions

Authors: Hillmer F., Wirth G., Haibach P., Frey U., Kluge Th., Jakob G., Adrian H.
Title: Flux pinning by columnar defects in Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8-thin films
Affiliations: Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Gesell. fur Schwerionenforschung, Planckstr. 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hillmer, F., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Wirth, G., Gesell. fur Schwerionenforschung, Planckstr. 1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Haibach, P., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Frey, U., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Kluge, Th., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Jakob, G., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Adrian, H., Institut für Physik, Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Staudinger Weg 7, D-55099 Mainz, Germany
Abstract: In Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8-thin films continuous amorphous columnar defects were created by heavy ion irradiation. Three of four identical striplines on the same sample were irradiated in a different way which includes irradiations under different angles with respect to the film c→-axis. After irradiation the normal state resistivity is enlarged and the films exhibit a reduction of Tc proportional to the volume of the damaged material. Furthermore the activation energy for flux movement shows an enhancement which is best for magnetic fields close to the matching field. Measurements of the transport critical current density, the activation energy and the irreversibility field in dependence of the angle between magnetic field and the film c→-axis show no anisotropic pinning due to the induced columnar defects. This can be related to the intrinsic two-dimensionality of Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8.
Author Keywords: Bi-2212 (High Temperature Superconductor) Thin Films; Columnar Defects; High Energy Heavy Ion Irradiation; Pinning; Transport Measurements
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Critical current density (superconductivity); Electric conductivity of solids; High temperature superconductors; Ion bombardment; Magnetic field effects; Magnetic film storage; Oxide superconductors; Strip telecommunication lines; Columnar defects; Flux planning; Superconducting films

Authors: Prairie M.R., Pacheco J.E., Kolb G.J., Sutherland J.P.
Title: Molten salt solar central receivers for utility electricity: Energy storage and dispatchability
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: Solar Thermal Technology Department, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0703, United States; Southern California Edison Company, Irwindale, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prairie, M.R., Solar Thermal Technology Department, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0703, United States; Pacheco, J.E., Solar Thermal Technology Department, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0703, United States; Kolb, G.J., Solar Thermal Technology Department, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0703, United States; Sutherland, J.P., Solar Thermal Technology Department, Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM 87185-0703, United States, Southern California Edison Company, Irwindale, CA, United States
Abstract: Solar power towers offer the only source of utility-scale solar electricity with cost-effective thermal energy storage. This is achieved most effectively using molten nitrate salt as the energy storage and heat transfer medium. Other options exist, e.g., liquid sodium or air with ceramic storage, but are either less developed, less efficient, or more expensive. The 10 MWe Solar Two power tower plant will illustrate the feasibility and effectiveness of molten-nitrate-salt technology.
Author Keywords: Energy dispatchability; Energy storage; Energy transport; Molten salt solar central receivers; Utility electricity

Authors: Drees Kirk H., Braun James E.
Title: Development and evaluation of a rule-based control strategy for ice storage systems
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drees, Kirk H., Johnson Controls, Milwaukee, United States; Braun, James E., Johnson Controls, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the development and evaluation of a near-optimal control strategy for ice storage systems. The strategy is based upon simple heuristics that were developed from daily and monthly simulations of cooling systems with internal melt, area-constrained ice storage tanks. Dynamic programming was used to obtain the optimal control trajectories which minimized an integrated energy and demand cost function for both the daily and monthly simulations. In addition to leading to simple heuristics, the monthly optimal control results were used as benchmarks to evaluate the performance of both conventional and the new control strategy. For a range of partial-storage systems, load profiles, and utility rate structures, the monthly electrical costs for the rule-based control strategy were, on average, within about 3% of the optimal costs. In contrast, the monthly electrical costs associated with the most common conventional control strategy, chiller-priority control, were as much as 20% greater than optimal, whereas a simple storage-priority strategy yielded costs that were within about 6% of optimal. The rule-based strategy can be easily implemented within a small micro-processor controller and only requires measurements of the system cooling requirement, building electrical usage, and state-of-charge of storage.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cooling systems; Costs; Dynamic programming; Energy utilization; Functions; Heuristic methods; Ice; Knowledge based systems; Melting; Optimal control systems; Tanks (containers); Chillers; Electrical costs; Ice storage systems; Cold storage

Authors: Zhang Qingyuan, Ishihara Osamu, Hayashi Tetsuo
Title: Development of residence with solar heating, earth cooling, and air circulation
Affiliations: Tsukuba Coll of Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Qingyuan, Tsukuba Coll of Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Ishihara, Osamu, Tsukuba Coll of Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Hayashi, Tetsuo, Tsukuba Coll of Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: A new type of residence (the SEA house) has been proposed. In winter, the house is heated by solar energy. Thermal insulation, heat storage, and air circulation are used to maintain the room temperature at a comfortable level and to reduce the temperature difference between the south side and the north side of the house. In summer, earth tubes are used for the purpose of cooling the proposed house. The thermal performance of the house was simulated by a computer program called PSSP, which can predict room temperature in a multiroom system. It is estimated that in Tokyo, the room temperature can be maintained at less than 28°C (82.4°F) in summer and more than 18°C (64.4°F) during most hours in winter without air-conditioning equipment.
Index Keywords: Buoyancy; Computer simulation; Computer software; Cooling; Heat storage; Performance; Solar heating; Temperature distribution; Thermal insulation; Ventilation; Air circulation; Earth cooling; Earth tubes; Residence; Winter performance; Houses

Authors: Gibson Gerald L.
Title: Supervisory controller for optimization of building central cooling systems
Affiliations: Science Applications Int Corp, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gibson, Gerald L., Science Applications Int Corp, San Diego, United States
Abstract: A personal-computer-based supervisory controller is currently being demonstrated that works with a building's energy management and control system to optimize cooling equipment operation. The system provides decision support to determine when to operate central cooling equipment to minimize costs under real-time pricing or conventional time-of-use electric rates. An artificial neural network (ANN) is used to model the dynamic behavior of the building and energy equipment while an evolutionary-based search routine, a genetic algorithm (GA), is used for optimization. A prototype system is installed and operating at a high school in southern California to control a thermal energy storage system, a conventional screw-type chiller, and a gas-fired, engine-driven chiller. This paper describes the neural network and genetic algorithm and discusses how the two have been integrated into a working system. Emphasis is placed on lessons learned during the developmental process and on insights gained in the practical application of both GA and ANN technologies.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Computer simulation; Control systems; Costs; Decision support systems; Energy management; Genetic algorithms; Neural networks; Optimization; Personal computers; Building central cooling systems; Chillers; Thermal energy storage system; Cooling systems

Authors: Su S.T.
Title: Integrated pumped storage and water supply operations
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Hydropower - Waterpower
Affiliations: Harza Engineering Co of California, Oakland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Su, S.T., Harza Engineering Co of California, Oakland, United States
Abstract: Municipal water supply systems may realize significant economic benefits by integrating a small-capacity pumped storage operation with its water supply functions. The difference in time value of the base and peak energy demands may justify modifications to the water supply delivery schedule to achieve an optimal integrated operations which would be the most cost-effective. This paper presents a case study using the process and results of an investigation conducted for a urban utility system in southern California: The City of Anaheim's Walnut Canyon Reservoir Project. Specific features and findings which will be discussed in the paper include: Existing Water Supply Operations; Benefits of Pumped Storage Operations; Constraints of integrated operations; Site Potential Assessment; Project Arrangement and Principal Features; and Implementation considerations.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Economic and social effects; Project management; Site selection; Water supply systems; Integrated pumped storage operations; Reservoirs (water)

Authors: Harper Karen A., Berkemeier Matthew D., Grace Sheryl
Title: Decreasing the energy costs of swimming robots through passive elastic elements
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
Affiliations: Boston Univ, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harper, Karen A., Boston Univ, Boston, United States; Berkemeier, Matthew D., Boston Univ, Boston, United States; Grace, Sheryl, Boston Univ, Boston, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates the potential benefit of elastic energy storage in the propulsion of a swimming robot. A discussion of Sears' and Lighthill's hydrodynamic models are presented and are followed by an analysis of the input power required for cases with and without elastic energy storage. It is concluded that the addition of linear springs to the system provides a means to reduce the energy required of the power supply. A transfer function for the system is also derived for purposes of controlling a swimming robot.
Index Keywords: Elasticity; Energy storage; Hydrodynamics; Mathematical models; Springs (components); Transfer functions; Passive elastic elements; Swimming robots; Mobile robots

Authors: Hubbard Gregory A., Youcef-Toumi Kamal
Title: Modeling and simulation of a hybrid-electric vehicle drivetrain
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: General Motors Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hubbard, Gregory A., General Motors Corp, United States; Youcef-Toumi, Kamal, General Motors Corp, United States
Abstract: The drivetrain of a hybrid-electric vehicle is modeled and simulated from a system level approach. The need for accurate dynamic models for developing control algorithms is motivated. Detailed models capable of describing both transient and steady-state operation of each of the key drivetrain components are constructed. Bond graphs are the tool of choice for modeling because they focus on mechanisms of energy generation, storage, and dissipation. Further, they permit integration of submodels, give insight into component interaction, and allow straightforward derivation of governing equations. The following component models are presented: transmission, vehicle chassis/body, three-phase AC induction motor, lead-acid battery, and four cycle, four stroke, spark ignited internal combustion engine. Simulation results for these components are presented.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Control system analysis; Mathematical models; Mechanical variables control; Vehicle parts and equipment; Hybrid electric vehicle drivetrain; Electric vehicles

Authors: Hall Christopher D.
Title: High speed flywheels for integrated energy storage and attitude control
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Air Force Inst of Technology/ENY, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hall, Christopher D., Air Force Inst of Technology/ENY, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, United States
Abstract: We present new results on attitude control of spacecraft with flywheels, where the wheels are also used to store energy as `mechanical batteries.' A brief review of the literature of this concept is given. The nonlinear equations of motion for a gyrostat model are given in dimensionless form, and recognized as a noncanonical Hamiltonian system. Decomposition of the space of internal torques separates the attitude control function from the energy storage function. A class of control laws is developed to execute large-angle rotational maneuvers while simultaneously performing energy storage and extraction operations.
Index Keywords: Control theory; Energy storage; Equations of motion; Mathematical models; Nonlinear equations; Spacecraft; Attitude control; Hamiltonian systems; Flywheels

Authors: Le Gall J.M., Nabil R., Sonier F., Voigt H.D.
Title: Full field modelling of a gas storage and power plant coupling
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Gaz de France, La-Plaine-Saint-Denis, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Gall, J.M., Gaz de France, La-Plaine-Saint-Denis, France; Nabil, R., Gaz de France, La-Plaine-Saint-Denis, France; Sonier, F., Gaz de France, La-Plaine-Saint-Denis, France; Voigt, H.D., Gaz de France, La-Plaine-Saint-Denis, France
Abstract: When a depleted gas field converted into a gas storage is used to feed a power plant, the gas-mixing phenomenon in the reservoir leads to gas calorific value fluctuations with time. However, since the power plant is supplying a constant power, it requires a constant `energy rate' from the storage. In order to design the storage, the modelling has to meet this particular constraint, while having a correct handling of the well to surface connections. To demonstrate the feasibility of such a project, Gaz de France has developed a new feature in its in-house multi-gas/water reservoir simulator, which already includes a reservoir to surface network coupling. In various scenarios of power plant needs, we manage to minimize the number of infill wells and to minimize the yearly injected gas quantity. Finally, the technical and economical feasibility of dedicating a gas storage to a power plant has been proven. This numerical development has been applied to the actual power plant development project at the German depleted field of Behringen. This correct and rigorous way of handling production controls allows a quick study of many design options. Therefore, the new concept of power plant gas storage coupling will be applied to several other sites.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Mixing; Full field modeling; In house multi gas/water reservoir; Natural gas wells

Authors: Bao Yixing, Perlack Robert D., Sale Michael J.
Title: Evaluating and improving flow duration analysis method to determine headwater benefits
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Hydropower - Waterpower
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bao, Yixing, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Perlack, Robert D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Sale, Michael J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Headwater benefits are energy gains at a downstream hydropower project that are directly realized from installation of upstream reservoirs. The high costs of making headwater benefits determinations prohibit the use of a complicated model in basins where the magnitude of the benefits is expected to be small. A simple alternative method, such as flow duration analysis (FDA), is needed to reduce the assessment costs. This paper evaluates the application of the FDA method for determining energy gains in these smaller basins. The standard FDA method is enhanced by (1) using an appropriate flow step in the numerical integration, (2) replacing a power-to-turbine flow ratio by a variable flow-head-efficiency relationship, and (3) expanding FDA to derive the unregulated flows based on regulated flow and reservoir storage changes. A computer model (HWBFDA) was developed to automate the process of applying the this enhanced FDA method. The enhancements significantly improve the accuracy of the FDA method and efficiency in application. The model has been applied in various river basins.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Integration; Numerical methods; Flow duration analysis (FDA); Software package HWBFDA; Hydroelectric power

Authors: Havenhill Douglas D., Robinson Wilf, Hanks James, Gisler Gary, Spina Len, Ginter Steve
Title: Spacecraft energy storage systems
Source title: National Aerospace and Electronics Conference, Proceedings of the IEEE
Affiliations: SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States
Authors with affiliations: Havenhill, Douglas D., SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States; Robinson, Wilf, SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States; Hanks, James, SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States; Gisler, Gary, SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States; Spina, Len, SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States; Ginter, Steve, SatCon Technology Corp, Tucson, United States
Abstract: Flywheel Energy Storage Systems represent an exciting alternative to traditional battery storage systems used to power satellites during periods of eclipse. The increasing demand for reliable communication and data access is driving explosive growth in the number of satellite systems being developed as well as their performance requirements. Power on orbit is the key to this performance, and batteries are becoming increasingly unattractive as an energy storage media. Flywheel systems offer very attractive characteristics for both energy storage, in terms of energy density and the number of charge/discharge cycles, and the important side benefit of spacecraft attitude control.
Index Keywords: Communication satellites; Electric energy storage; Flywheels; Magnetic bearings; Flywheel energy storage systems; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Gebotys Catherine H.
Title: Efficient model for DSP code generation: Performance, code size, estimated energy
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on System Synthesis
Affiliations: Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gebotys, Catherine H., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada
Abstract: This paper presents a model for simultaneous instruction selection, compaction, and register allocation. An arc mapping model along with logical propositions is used to create an optimization model. Code is generated in fast cpu times and is optimized for minimum code size, maximum performance or estimated energy dissipation. Code generated for realistic DSP applications provide performance and code size improvements from 1.09 up to 2.18 times for the TMS320C2x processor compared to previous research and a commercial compiler. In all examples up to 106 instructions are generated in under one cpu minute. This research is important for industry since DSP code can be efficiently generated with constraints on code size, performance, energy dissipation.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computer architecture; Mathematical models; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Storage allocation (computer); Code generation; Digital signal processing

Authors: Kirk J.A., Schmidt Jr. J.R., Sullivan G.E., Hromada L.P.
Title: Open core rotator design methodology
Source title: National Aerospace and Electronics Conference, Proceedings of the IEEE
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, J.A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Schmidt Jr., J.R., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Sullivan, G.E., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Hromada, L.P., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: In low earth orbit [LEO] satellite applications, spacecraft power is provided by photovoltaic cells and batteries. To overcome battery shortcomings, FARE, Inc., working in cooperation with the University of Maryland [UOM] and the NASA Lewis Research Center, has developed an open core magnetically-suspended graphite-epoxy flywheel for energy storage applications. This flywheel energy storage system, called the Open Core Rotator [OCR], was designed to meet specifications set forth by NASA. NASA's primary design requirement called for an OCR system capable of delivering 50 Wh of energy. FARE's OCR is based on and builds upon the fundamental research that has been carried out at the University of Maryland since 1977. The UOM presently has an operational 500 Wh Open Core Composite Flywheel [OCCF]. FARE's OCR is a scaled-down version of the UOM's OCCF. Specifically, this paper discusses the procedure followed by FARE in designing its 50 Wh OCR, including how the resultant dimensions and component topology were obtained.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Flywheels; Magnetic bearings; Open core composite flywheels (OCCF); Open core rotator (OCR); Spacecraft power supplies

Abstract: The paper is the last in a series of four which describe a three-year research project into advanced fabric-energy-storage (FES) systems. It presents experimental monitoring of the first uk building to put the FES-slab into practice, showing the building's thermal performance and energy consumption during 1995. The results are discussed and recommendations made to improve the building's operation during 1996.

Authors: Walls W.A., Pratap S.B., Chryssomallis G.
Title: Pulsed rotating machine power supplies for electro-thermal-chemical guns
Affiliations: University of Texas, Austin Center for Electromechanics, Austin, TX, United States; Sci. Applic. Intl. Corporation, Bloomington, MN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walls, W.A., University of Texas, Austin Center for Electromechanics, Austin, TX, United States; Pratap, S.B., Sci. Applic. Intl. Corporation, Bloomington, MN, United States; Chryssomallis, G., Sci. Applic. Intl. Corporation, Bloomington, MN, United States
Abstract: With the recent successes in the development of electro-thermal-chemical cartridge technology, the need for an advanced repetitive fire power supply has become a more nearterm problem. While capacitor banks have provided the singleshot capability necessary for optimizing charge design and the required electrical pulse shape, it is not clear that it is the best power supply for a fielded system. The primary disadvantage of the capacitor approach is the requirement for recharging the bank between shots. Conceptually, the required charging is accomplished with either a high voltage alternator and rectifier, or a battery bank which requires power conditioning (D-D converters, etc.) to achieve the required 15 to 20 kV charging voltage. In the case of the alternator-rectifier system, energy storage for multiple shots can be built into the alternator rotor (or by adding an energy storage flywheel). Since battery charging system design is typically driven by power considerations, the battery needed to perform the charging will generally store sufficient energy for several shots. In either case, the pulsed power system is composed of two distinct components: A capacitor based pulse forming network (PFN) and an energy storage/charging power supply. Rotating machines provide the advantage of combining the two functions described above into a single smaller package. Under U.S. and Marine Corps funding, the Center for Electromechanics has been developing compact, lightweight pulsed rotating machines (compensated pulsed alternators, or compulsators) for electromagnetic guns for the past 10 years. Air-core and iron-core variants of these machines have demonstrated an ability to efficiently drive low impedance pulsed loads. Other advantages of these machines over PFNs include lower operating voltages, higher burst firing rates, and the ability to store a substantial number of shots in rotor energy. In addition, a wide variety of pulse shapes are possible and the current profile can be varied from shot to shot if needed. This paper describes the important rotating machine power supply design considerations for two operational ETC missions. Aspects of energy storage for burst firing and prime power averaging, pulse shaping capabilities, and switching requirements are also discussed. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric current control; Electromagnetic launchers; Fire control systems; Machine design; Pulse circuits; Rotating machinery; Switching networks; Burst firing rates; Pulse forming networks (PFN); Pulsed rotating machine power supply systems; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Zukowski Charles A., Wang Shao-Yi
Title: Use of selective precharge for low-power content-addressable memories
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Columbia Univ, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zukowski, Charles A., Columbia Univ, New York, United States; Wang, Shao-Yi, Columbia Univ, New York, United States
Abstract: A general technique to reduce the energy used by individual CMOS logic gates in large fan-in logic arrays is derived, and applied to the comparators in a content-addressable memory (CAM), an important application where power dissipation is often large and the technique works particularly well. A small subset of the inputs are removed from the large parallel pulldown switch and used to control the precharge instead, greatly reducing the number of cycles requiring a full charge/discharge sequence in many cases, with only a modest delay penalty. Estimates of the optimal number of bits to remove and the performance gain as a function of various parameters are provided.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Comparator circuits; Data storage equipment; Electric charge; Low power content addressable memories (CAM); Logic gates

Authors: Clarkson Joseph B., Shackelford Peter R., Vega Luis A.
Title: Design and construction of the PICHTR renewable hybrid village power demonstration and training facility
Affiliations: Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clarkson, Joseph B., Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States; Shackelford, Peter R., Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States; Vega, Luis A., Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States
Abstract: The design and construction of a 360 kWh/day hybrid village power system consisting of PV modules, battery storage, wind turbine generators, power converter (inverter/controller) and diesel generator is now complete. The integrated system was designed for Pacific Island applications and will be used to evaluate components as well as to train potential users of similar systems. The demonstration and training facility is located at Kahua Ranch on the Big Island of Hawaii. The ranch provides housing for the workers, and their electrical power consumption patterns are similar to those found in remote villages throughout the Pacific. Given the long term wind and solar data records available at the site, the system was designed to produce approximately 80% of the ranch's electrical load with renewables and the balance with the diesel generator.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric loads; Energy utilization; Photovoltaic effects; Power converters; Wind turbines; Battery storage; Diesel generator; Wind turbine generators; Electric power systems

Authors: Hernandez Horvin R., Gonzalez Jorge E., Khan Arshad Y.
Title: Parametric study of solar-assisted air conditioning and dehumidification systems operating in the Caribbean region
Affiliations: Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico
Authors with affiliations: Hernandez, Horvin R., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico; Gonzalez, Jorge E., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico; Khan, Arshad Y., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico
Abstract: This study tests the feasibility of different arrangements of solar-assisted air conditioning systems for applications in Puerto Rico and the Caribbean. The thermodynamic performance of a single-effect absorption system alone and coupled to a liquid desiccant dehumidification system, both powered by high performance flat-plate collectors, was investigated under variable cooling load conditions. The modeling for the absorption system was based on performing heat and mass balances on each of its component while the liquid desiccant system was simulated using a cooling tower effectiveness model. A detailed heat transfer analysis was used to model the solar collector array. Systems variables were optimized as function of geographic location and maximum cooling load. Variables investigated and optimized included collectors' surface area, collectors' inclination angle, and thermal storage to collector surface area ratio. Three cities within the Caribbean were taken as a basis for this study: two in Puerto Rico, and one in Trinidad. Results for maximum cooling loads ranging from 18 to 176 kW indicate that average annual solar fractions exceeding 70 percent can be achieved at these cities for the absorption system alone as well as for the absorption/desiccant hybrid system. The absorption/desiccant systems tends to require higher solar collector areas and increase their performance at high latent loads.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling towers; Heat transfer; Solar energy; Tropics; Dehumidification systems; Liquid desiccant system; Solar assisted air conditioning; Solar collectors

Authors: McNab I.R.
Title: Homopolar generators for electric guns
Affiliations: Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 4030-2 West Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5329, United States
Authors with affiliations: McNab, I.R., Institute for Advanced Technology, University of Texas at Austin, 4030-2 West Braker Lane, Austin, TX 78759-5329, United States
Abstract: Low voltage homopolar generators combined with magnetic energy storage inductors were used to power several early experimental railguns. Over the last 10 years this arrangement has fallen into disfavor for future high-energy railgun systems compared with multipole AC generators, largely because of the need for an opening switch to both transfer high current and open against voltages of a few kV. Basic features of homopolar generators are examined and factors relating to their potential for future electrothermalchemical (ETC) gun systems are considered briefly. The energy and current requirements for such guns are substantially less than for high energy railguns, so that homopolar generators (HPGs) may prove feasible. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: AC generators; Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Rail guns; Homopolar generators; Magnetic energy storage; Electric generators

Authors: Sarjeant W.J., Suny A.B., Buffalo N.Y., Larson D.W.

Abstract: Over the last decade, significant increases in capacitor reliability have been achieved through a combination of advanced manufacturing techniques, new materials, and diagnostic methodologies to provide requisite life-cycle reliability for high energy pulse applications. Recent innovations in analysis of aging, including dimensional analysis, are introduced for predicting component performance and fault tolerance. In addition, voltage scaling issues that may drive bank fault-tolerance performance are described. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Capacitor storage; Electronic equipment manufacture; Dimensional analysis; Capacitors

Authors: Weck W., Ehrhart P., Müller A., Reiner G.
Title: Superconducting inductive pulsed power supply for electromagnetic launchers: design aspects and experimental investigation of laboratory set-up
Affiliations: Magnet-Motor GmbH, Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weck, W., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany; Ehrhart, P., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany; Müller, A., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany; Reiner, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany
Abstract: The principle of the superconducting inductive energy storage and of superconducting pulse switching is reviewed. Design criteria are discussed by introducing two different laboratory set-ups. Special emphasis will be laid on the methods of charging the energy storage and on the pulse switching. The layout and dimensioning of an experimental pulsed power supply with an energy capacity of 4 MJ are described. First experimental results are presented and future development steps are discussed. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Critical current density (superconductivity); Electric energy storage; Electromagnetic launchers; Pulse circuits; Superconducting devices; Superconducting materials; Superconducting inductive pulse power supply; Superconducting pulse switching; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Mongeau P.
Title: Combustion driven pulsed linear generators for electric gun applications
Affiliations: Kaman Electromagnetics Corp., 2 Fox Road, Hudson, MA 01749, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mongeau, P., Kaman Electromagnetics Corp., 2 Fox Road, Hudson, MA 01749, United States
Abstract: Energy storage and pulse forming for electromagnetic and electro-thermal chemical guns has historically been accomplished through the use of complex power trains. Such power trains typical involve a prime power source, electrical or mechanical power conversion devices, capacitive or flywheel energy storage devices, and sophisticated switching and control elements. Kaman Electromagnetics (KEC) has developed concepts for simpler pulse power systems where chemical energy is converted more directly into an electrical output which can be utilized by an electric gun load without further conditioning. One family of devices which has shown considerable promise is the linear flux compressor. Early work with flux compressors used explosives and was suited only for microsecond duration pulses. More recent efforts utilizing propellants and even conventional hydrocarbon fuels can provide millisecond duration pulses which are well suited for electric gun type loads. Internally funded efforts indicate linear flux compressor pulse power supplies can be considerable smaller and lighter than conventional systems. This paper will present the operational principles and design issues of linear flux compressors suitable for EM guns. Point designs, performance simulations and general scaling relationships will also be presented. © 1997 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Flywheels; Propellants; Rail guns; Linear flux compressors; Pulsed linear generators; Electric generators

Authors: Kawabata Hiroaki, Zhang Zhong, Kanagawa Akihiro, Takahashi Hiromitsu, Kuwaki Hiroshi
Title: Associative memories in cellular neural networks using a singular value decomposition

Affiliations: Okayama Prefectural Univ, Soja, Japan

Abstract: Using various templates, many applications of cellular neural network (CNN), such as a feature extraction, an edge detection and a pattern classification have been considered. In a Hopfield network, an image to be stored corresponds to the minimum value of the energy of the network. However, in CNN, an image corresponds to the equilibrium state of a differential equation. A synthesis procedure for designing a CNN that will store a set of desired vectors as memory points using a singular value matrix decomposition is considered. Also analyzed here is the indeterminate phenomenon of the equilibrium states of some cells that arise in the case in which more than two similar patterns are stored for Chinese characters.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Differential equations; Digital image storage; Edge detection; Electric network synthesis; Feature extraction; Matrix algebra; Pattern recognition; Singular value decomposition; Template matrix; Cellular neural networks

Authors: Stöhlker Th.
Title: Lamb shift experiments on high-Z ions performed at the ESR storage ring
Affiliations: Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, August-Euler-Straße 6, D-60486 Frankfurt, Germany; GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstr.1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Stöhlker, Th., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, August-Euler-Straße 6, D-60486 Frankfurt, Germany, GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstr.1, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The ESR storage ring offers unique conditions for precision investigations in the field of atomic physics. In this review, special emphasis is given to the experiments which address the study of the effects of quantum electrodynamics (QED) in high-Z hydrogen-like systems, e.g. uranium. Here, due to the strong Coulomb field of the nucleus, higher-order radiative corrections can be investigated that are not accessible by experiments for low-Z ions. Since these corrections are largest for the ground-state, the experiments are discussed that are aiming at a precise determination of the ground-state transition energies in heavy hydrogen-like ions. With respect to future experimental perspectives, the deceleration capabilities of the ESR are discussed in detail as well.
Index Keywords: Atomic physics; Electrodynamics; Electron energy levels; Electron transitions; Paramagnetic resonance; Quantum theory; Storage rings; Lamb shift; Quantum electrodynamics (QED); Ions

Authors: Pawlik Th., Spaeth J.-M.

Affiliations: University of Paderborn, Warburger Str. 100, D-33098 Paderborn, Germany

Abstract: We present Cs2NaYF6:Ce3+,Pr3+ as a new promising X-ray storage phosphor. The radiation damage centers upon X-irradiation at 10K and 300K were investigated in pure and activator (Ce3+, Pr3+, Sb3+) - doped Cs2NaYF6 using magnetooptical and magnetic resonance spectroscopy. At low temperatures VK centers and HA- type centers as well as Pr4+ hole trap centers were identified and F centers as electron trap centers. For the activator Pr3+ it could be shown that upon room temperature X-irradiation only F centers and Pr4+ hole trap centers are involved in the information storage and readout process.
